Scotland is a foreign country.
Its linguistic idioms, its mores, its architecture, its urbanism are alien, strange, often beguiling.
It is foreign because of its very familiarity.
We've all heard about Aberdeen and the oil industry.
Long before I came here, the very name of this city used to haunt me.
Used to cause me to suffer a recurring nightmare.
This is an Aberdeen Angus.
And here's that creature, having been evolved to the stage of meat.
And here is that beef, subjected to industrial salting.
It's now bully beef, corned beef, the ineffable, utterly disgusting evil twin of salt beef who ran away to the wrong side of the tracks.
Corned beef is the twin who went to the bad and never came back.
Since earliest childhood, this school lunch staple had repulsed me.
This stuff was bad.
My suspicions were confirmed in May 1964.
Actually, no... not salad days.
That month, Aberdeen suffered Britain's worst outbreak of typhoid of the 20th Century.

It was caused by Argentinian corned beef which had been cooled in the Rio Mierda's faecally abundant waters and sold in an early supermarket on Union Street owned by William Low, a chain based in Dundee, of all places.
There had always been a certain rivalry between the two cities, but this was overstepping the mark.
There is no shadow of doubt that this outbreak started from a tin of corned beef.
An excitable press, led on by an equally excitable Medical Officer of Health, was busily rehearsing for future food scares and supposed pandemics - listeria, salmonella, swine fever.
Its estimate of the number of potential victims was, as has become the norm, grossly exaggerated.
As it happened, fewer than 500 people would be infected and only three would die.
But apocalyptic panic had been unchained.
Aberdeen was stigmatised as a bogey town.
Its inhabitants were calumnised as plague carriers.
Anyone with an Aberdonian accent in Glasgow was courteously advised to breathe elsewhere.
North-east Scotland's tourism industry collapsed.
Two years later, Sir Alf Ramsey accused Argentinians of acting like...
Animals.
And proving that it really is best eaten cold, 18 years later Argentina invaded the Falklands.
I had a recurring nightmare.
I was running for my life through a nocturnal labyrinthine city to escape a school meal of corned beef which would kill me.
Slow death by tinned poison.
The horror was compounded by a pop song of that summer called Juliet - simpering doggerel, mawkish going on the full mawk.
The city in this nightmare was not, of course, Aberdeen, which I had never been to.
It was somewhere I had been, but which my conscious brain hadn't processed.
Thus the decor of our dreams is akin to flipped photographs - places seen in mirrors.
12 years later I came here.
I survived, I returned.
I inhaled without fear.
There is, supposedly, no memorial to the events of the summer of 1964.
But I wonder.
Somewhere, in this provisional labyrinth, there is a monument to contamination by corned beef.
Conspiracy theorists with a sideline in Nostradamian signalling must note that Aberdeen 'is a city where the memorial precedes the event.'
Prince Albert, Victoria's consort, died of typhoid in 1861 and was commemorated in Baron Carlo Marochetti's statue.
His death had nothing, so far as is known, to do with corned beef.
Nonetheless, Marochetti presciently posed him on a plinth of petrified corned beef.

Wilted flowers, yews, black granite headstones, green enviro-glass chips recycled from bottlebank arisings at £1.70 per kilo, amputee angels, burghers' mausolea fit to burst like tins full of fermenting herrings, mournful cypresses...
A city may lack these precise features but a city - any city, the Granite City - is a sprawling cemetery taken over by humans, rather than by feral cats, and rats and bats.
We are mere squatters, at best stewards, of streets and buildings that have become unwitting tombs, that time has changed into accidental monuments to forgotten lives.
Lives which, no matter how physically close we are to where they were led and where they ended, are hidden.
We can touch the same stones they touched.
We shiver like they did at quarter irons grinding on cobbles, but we cannot know them, no matter how thorough our investigations, no matter how strenuous our imagination.
Cobbles are, actually, mute.
It is pathetically fallacious to believe that they can.
Stones, and bricks and girders and breeze blocks, are inanimate.
Chunks of quarried mineral are mute.
They have nothing to say.
But they were disposed by our forbears in a particular order in a particular combination for particular purposes.
So they could be said to tell a sort of story, but it's not linear and it's forever fluctuating.
The city is an eternal jigsaw puzzle, whose successive generations of designers don't know the shape of.
They don't know what it represents.
What we squat in are the most tangible vestiges of distant cultures, in cities layered like a geological cassata.
If they are alien to us it is because they come from far away, far away in time rather than space, from a place which precludes migration where souls rest in nothingness.
We do not, today, commonly trade as fleshers, cairds, tranters, chaloners, lardners, catchpoles, haywards, higglers, mathers... though some of us bear the names of those who did.
We do not travel in Broughams or Landaus.
We do not dress in crinolines or untreated pelts like berserkers.
And what a blouse I'd look in either.
'We speak a language different to that of Harry Lauder, let alone 'that of The Scottish Play, let alone that of old Macbeth himself.'
We don't dance polkas or minuets.

We don't impose the death penalty - the last man to be hanged in Scotland, for a crime passionel in Jackson Terrace as it happens, was executed here at Craiginches prison in Aberdeen on August 15, 1963.
Our food, our diseases, our gadgets, our licence, our manners... 'all of these would bemuse a revenant from only 50 years ago.
'That hanged man would be foxed by what he has missed.'

Yet were his great-great-great grandparents also to pop their spectral head round the portal of the ages and peer into the present, they would have no difficulty whatsoever in recognising much of the built fabric of the cities where they lived then and where we live now - the spires, the dormers, the pediments, the railings, the doorsteps, would all be utterly familiar.
We are, apparently, culturally programmed to bemoan the loss of buildings that disappeared before we were born.
In our dubious grief and handwringing and fretting about what no longer exists, we lazily overlook what does exist, what has survived.
We overlook the wonderful gift of the ordinary, because there's so much of it.
If we live on a beach, we take sand for granted.
If we live near a hospital, we take seeping sacks of operation waste for granted.
What must seem ordinary to Aberdonian eyes is extraordinary to mine.
This is a city where dormer windows are omnipresent like nowhere else.
They have been the defining quirk of Aberdeen's domestic architecture for at least two and a half centuries.
Irrespective of the idiom the rest of it displayed, a house or terrace would be equipped with dormers.
'Many of these houses are akin to the Bordelais building type called l'echoppe - 'a priori single storeyed, but with a recessed, dormered attic, and sometimes a basement.'
A sort of bungalow that owed nothing to Bengali precedent.
This was a question of habit.
Aberdeen developed separately from the cities of the central belt.
It may feel foreign to a Glaswegian.
Like being in Scandanavia, one told me.

We fail to acknowledge that in an old country on the edge of an old continent there exists a vast store of old buildings apart from those which now belong to the tourism and heritage larks - the castles, the palaces, the fortresses, the cathedrals and so on - these official markers of the past are actually atypical.
All around us there are concentrations of the unofficial, the typical, the overlooked.
Humble buildings, which form the townscapes we walk through every day without a second glance.
The decor of normality, which is not the same as banality unless we want to make it so.
The decor of normality, which is perpetually under threat.
Buildings, which though they have been adapted down the years, remain substantially unchanged.
In Aberdeen, the extent to which they are unchanged is without peer in Scotland, indeed without peer in the still, just United, Kingdom.
This is entirely due to the properties of granite.

That epithet invokes toughness, uncompromising strength, Irn Bru turned to stone, a city built in the physical image of the doughty riggers and rugged matelots who frequent it and in the moral image of the stern and unyielding rectitude of the manse.
Its architecture must surely reflect these qualities.
There are several Aberdeens, several cities, not all of them granite, linked only by name and adjacence, otherwise quite unrelated to each other.
The word "forbidding", which is routinely applied to granite buildings, is really only apt for those of the stylistic free-for-all of the later 19th century.
This is due to granite's unsuitability for ornamental puposes.
There's an evident disharmony between the material and the end to which it has been carved.
But the butchness is more comical than it is forbidding.
It's theatrical - it's all workboots and leather aprons.
It's about as threatening as a cardboard halbard.
"Threatening" and "forbidding" are for the most part, wide of the mark.
Taut, elegant, surprisingly douce, sometimes almost effete.
It possesses the restraint of dandyism.
There are other cities which are defined by a building material.
Clermont Ferrand and Catania are all black volcanic tufa.
Besancon's baby pink and baby blue limestone lends it the appearance of a stately nursery.
But these cities look their age.
Unlike Aberdeen.
Granite's supreme quality as a building material is that it doesn't weather, it's impervious to time and climate.
It doesn't grow old gracefully - it doesn't grow old at all.
It's the stone whose pituitary gland was excised in some hideous experiement.
Forever young.
When the sun shines, the mica and quartz in the granite glint.
That's not often.
Although Aberdeen is one of several places that claims to be the sunniest in Scotland, you're not going to need SPF 60.
In dull weather - the Aberdonian norm - granite is matt, unreflective, light absorbent.
It is a city of brand-new buildings that are two and three hundred years old.
Which, far from looking like they are made from stone, might have been constructed from XXXL chunks of the industrial confectionery called Black Jacks, which are grey.
Or from an eraser.
Or from putty.
Or from Dunlopillo.
The actuality of Aberdeen is uncannily like its representation in a computer-generated 3D rendering.

To contemporary eyes, Aberdeen might be a model of itself, a full-scale model, a naturalistic impostor, a gigantic pastiche, a sort of mega-Poundbury, but one wrought by inspired designers rather than crass hacks.
Buildings of different centuries might be of the same century.
These baths were built in the 1930s.
While the former Town School was built to John Smith's design 100 years previously.
Aberdeen's stones give the illusion of being recently quarried.

They make the city look newer than the new towns, the crumbling, stained, neglected post-war attempts at urbanism where the possibility that even utopia might require upkeep was catastrophically overlooked.
They might have fared better had they been built of granite.
Its neo-classicism is so fresh, it needs an extra neo.
Neo-neo-classical and neo-neo-gothic.
And neo-neo-baroque - this is the Freemasons' Temple.
The importance to Aberdeen of the stonemason's craft - a key word in the lexicon of the brotherhood - is ubiquitously apparent.
But their ritual remains based in that trade.
The stonemason's tools - the square and compass - are central.
They are used figuratively or symbolically, though quite what they symbolise is disputable.
Here, the stonemason's tools are, equally, used literally, to fashion a building which is a virtuoso display of craft, of stereotomic prowess.
Stereotomy is the science of making sections, of cutting stones to fit perfectly with one another and another and another.
The novice mason is deemed akin to a block of unworked stone.
Through education and civility, he attains the ashlared polished perfection of the master mason.
As quarrying technology became mechanised, so did the technology of cutting advance.
The quantity of stone that could be ashlared increased exponentially.
Aberdeen's characteristic appearance was eventually indebted as much to steam saws and hydraulic saws as it was to masons and architects.
What had once been slow and painstaking, and hence a luxury material employed only in the grandest projects, became widely available.
Smooth surfaces were, if you like, democratised, just as education and civility were.
The possibilities of the early 19th century's new stone cutting technologies were enthusiastically exploited by two notable architects, John Smith and Archibald Simpson.
They changed the face of the city, but they did not disfigure it.
Though they relied on one material, their work was stylistically various.
However, Smith and Simpson were predominantly exponents of the classical idiom, which was as dominant in Scotland as it was in Germany and endured far longer than it did in England.
In Scotland, the Greek revival was more a survival.
It endured for getting on 70 years longer than it did in England, where it was just another ephemeral craze.
Its endurance may have been due to that very fact that England discarded it.
It was, plausibly, a token of Scottish national identity until baronial bombast pushed it aside.
Simpson and Smith were far from doctrinaire.
Their spirit and intentions were picturesque.
Smith even acquired the pseudonym Tudor Johnnie because of his fondness for approximate revivals of that dynasty's supposed style.
And Simpson built a tour de force in, of all materials, brick which the Hanseatic style of the Triple Kirk demanded.
Their practice of providing the city with such emphases as spires, steeples, towers and finials set an example that was followed in Aberdeen throughout the 19th century, perhaps unwittingly.

The 1843 Disruption, when the Free Church seceded from the Church of Scotland, was merely the most dramatic of countless instances of doctrinal headbutting and liturgical mud wrestling which prompted schisms.
Every new congregation, every new denomination, built a church to rival that of the one it had just split from.

Even if the profusion of sacred buildings suggests that Aberdeen was some sort of theocratic city-state governed by eldritch gypers - Scottish for hideous mullahs - their high spires had an enduringly beneficent effect.
They are punctuation marks in a townscape.
They relieve the horizontal.
They obviously signal divisions of denomination, but at the same time they suggest all the competing denominations speak a common language.
They define different neighbourhoods and distinguish different parishes, yet they bind them together as a coherent whole.
They punctuate the homogeneity of the 19th century city's granite spread.
It would be less coherent, less legible, were it not articulated by these landmarks.
The 19th century city is the predominant Aberdeen, the public Aberdeen.
It has predecessors and successors which are as notable, as visually satisfying, as attractive.
The estate agents' contention that cities are composed of villages is, usually, a fib, guilelessly at odds with the actuality.
The majority of cities - and most of Aberdeen is no exception - are composed of sometimes colliding, sometimes eliding suburbs.

Why, though, should we treat that as a virtue and seek to preserve, let alone emulate, the bucolic horror, the numbing boredom, the prying intimacy, the enforced mateyness, the illiterate poverty, the silage stench and the bestiality workshops which characterised village life.
Real villages are why we live in cities.
Old Aberdeen is, mercifully, an unreal village.
Although its northernmost quarter is cut off from the rest by a road built with, let us say, Glaswegian sensitivity to townscape, as a whole, it's isolated from the city around it.
It is a survival of pre-consumerism, a combination of collegiate backwater and cathedral close.
Cobbles, quadrangles, second-hand bookshops, the former town houses of the north-eastern gentry, secret gardens, gatehouses, dotty follies, high walls.
The stones may be old but they are far from mellow.
Granite places do not lend themselves to the saccharine quaintness which afflicts those built of limestone or sandstone, materials which push the picturesque into tweeness.

One of the most consistently beguiling features of Scottish towns, indeed a feature unique to this country, is the way in which one building will face the street whilst its neighbour turns its side to the street, so to speak.
Thus, there's a constant interplay of angles, silhouettes and widths.
The Town House might have been built yesterday, save that yesterday there was no architect alive capable of designing it.
There are few places with such an intense concentration of good, though not outstanding, secular buildings whose sum is more than its parts.
Satisfying townscape is not achieved by wall to wall tours de force.
When I worked in central Rome, I felt sated by the unyielding diet of masterpieces and yearned for streetscape infected by ordinariness.
The sacred buildings here are different.
Within a few hundred yards of each other are three churches of the highest order.
The devil got the best tunes, God got the best buildings.
The most recent and the smallest is an early work from the 1890s of Ninian Comper, the Aberdonian who would become Britain's greatest religious architect of the early 20th century.
It is a mere fragment of the building he intended.
There is total congruence between the heavily buttressed building and the granite it stands on.
The chapel of King's College.
The crown on the tower is a Scottish peculiar.
It is the most benign of landmarks, though typically, it's hardly visible from outside Old Aberdeen.
The House of God is a house of high craft.
The workmanship in the carved screen and choir is remarkable, intricate, bold.
St Machar is thought to have been Irish, a follower of St Columba who he accompanied to Iona, and a missionary who converted the people of Mull, petrified a pig and cured lepers.
St Machar's Cathedral is as unusual as its dedicatee.
It's an extraordinary essay, but in what?
Many of Aberdeen's buildings are difficult to date because of granite's perpetual youth.
Here it's because the idiom, or rather the combination of idioms, the confusion of idioms.
The blind buttressed, crenulated towers belong to belligerent architecture, or at least to secular fortification.
They are originally of the early 1400s.
So, astonishingly, is the fragile nave.
It's being muscled by them, as if it's helping with enquiries.
The gable end reads as a blank pediment.
The seven lancet lights make this a west front unlike any other.
Architecture, being an essentially plagiaristic enterprise, seldom offers us a feature that is unique, that is to say without either precedent or copies.
Though they're exactly contemporary with the towers, the lancets, which are dwarfed by the towers, might be of a different building, of a different era, from a different country.
The lack of consensus and the lurch in scale are dramatic in the extreme and, incidentally, show the futility of the insistence that we should build in keeping.
The spires were added a century later in the 1520s, though they might well be of the very earliest gothic revival of 1700.
They disproportionately squat and they again add to the allusion that the church belongs to some order of celestial bodging, that it's a miracle of bricolage.
Not the least extraordinary thing about it is that it was intended to look like this.
Fittie wasn't intended to look like this.
It lies on a spur of land between the North Sea and the harbour.
The fishing village that was here in 1800 was composed of rudimentary, unsanitary dwellings which flooded.
Life was tough and short.
Men wore skirts and drowned.
Women were crippled by the weight of creels.
Endogamy, illiteracy and disease were normal.
Soon after John Smith was appointed to the post of City Architect in 1807, he undertook improvements for reasons that were humanitarian rather than architectural.
He rebuilt the place as a series of squares and streets of single storey houses.
They were not, perhaps, as toxically quaint as those which they replaced.
Fittie would become, and it remains, a site of continuous improvisation.
Houses grew taller, they were individualised.
Some of them gained dormer windows - an Aberdonian speciality down the years, indeed, an Aberdonian fixation.
And everywhere between the houses and in the former squares, sheds have sprung up.
Potting sheds, net huts, extra rooms.
Some of them tarred against the rude climate, others toshed as brightly as ships and dockyard buildings.
Fittie and, to a greater extent, the harbour are polychrome relief in a monochrome city.
This is, of course, not their purpose but an unintended consequence of vessels not being built of granite and of a human yearning for colour.
Picts were so called because they painted themselves.
Despite the ancient folklore, despite the Levitical proscription, despite the Koranic scholars' insistence that both tattooist and subject are cursed, their descendents do the same.
The urge to colour and to decorate is more powerful than folkloric superstitions, especially powerful in a uniformly grey city.
There are seven thriving tattooing businesses.
The contrast between harbour and city is, however, more than a question of just a few splashes of colour, of applied highlights.
Aberdeen is a Presbyterian city.
Presbyterianism is not fun.

In a Presbyterian city a zone of tolerance is a necessity.
A place to escape to, a place which has the key to probity's shackles.
A zone of tolerance... the expression is both euphemism and lie.

The vessels, the anchors, the cranes, the chains, the bollards, the reservoirs, the pumps, the tanks.

The abstract beauty of the useful, of things which represent nothing but that purpose.
The oil industry missed an open goal when it overlooked the make-believe rigs and parodic refineries of Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano.

What more appropriate monuments could it have bequeathed to Aberdeen?

I mean, fortuitous monuments, monuments as unintended consequences, in the manner of the churches of defunct denominations, the factories of obsolete products, the cottages once occupied by a now extinct caste of fishing folk whose descendants have moved up the coast.
Aberdeen is a boom town, maybe.
How such things are determined is unclear, but it has, for forty years, been known as the Oil Capital of Europe.
It has at times throughout that period been very prosperous and will no doubt remain so until the oil runs out.
And, who knows, even after that unthinkable moment.
The hundreds of companies based here and involved in oil exploitation are not entirely dependent on what may or may not be found beneath Scottish waters.
They train and provide support workers for the energy industry all over the world.
They've developed technologies which have more than local application.
Yet, when it is all over, they'll disappear leaving few physical traces and none of any architectural note.
Those who work in the oil industry are referred to, not altogether benevolently, as travellers.
Companies come to Aberdeen to make money.
Home is elsewhere.
Though companies may build here, they don't build with pride or with any sort of obligation to urbanistic felicity.
It's all short-termism, cut corners and corporate greed.
Had they any sense of history, or of civic decency, they might reflect on the architecture which makes Aberdeen so remarkable a city.
They might look at the planting effected by people who would never see their trees approach even adolescence.
Impermanence apart, the oil industry established itself here at a time when Scottish architecture was in a dismal state, all apologetic contrition and self-abnegation.
Modernism had run out of steam.
Instead of reinventing itself it attempted to compromise, to placate with silly gestures.
The oil industry's buildings are works of the most hackneyed mediocrity.
They contemptuously overlook architecture's public obligation.
They loutishly ignore the fact that for the rest of us, buildings are scenery.
But it didn't have to continue that way.
The city's ex-urban industrial estates and science parks, conference villages and enterprise valleys are a blight.
The architecture remains timorous, insipid, over polite.
The size of the buildings only exacerbates their lack of nerve and imagination.
If Stavanger, a city of the same population, could equip itself with a swathe of high quality new buildings, why not Aberdeen?

Money goes hand in hand with an affection for bloated 4x4 vehicles.
No doubt these inadequates feel an obligation to guzzle their own gas.

There is currently a proposal to effect a wholesale transformation of Aberdeen's very core.

No sooner had it been granted planning permission than Sir Ian Wood, a billionaire oil tycoon with £50 million to spare, countered with his grandiose vision - to cover this valley with a vast roof, and on that roof create a public space which would be a cross between a mini Central Park and a grand Italian piazza.
And beneath that roof?

With the fact that this intervention, philanthropic or plutocratic according to taste, is, let us say, most unorthodox?

With the catch in the small print, Wood expects the ratepayers to stump up another £50 million to achieve his vainglorious vision.
Besides all this, the last thing Aberdeen needs is more shops.

And then there's the matter of the unique cityscape which will be irreparably damaged.
This is a sort of amphitheatre, 250 metres long and between 35 and 50 metres wide.

What it is proposed to replace it with is a simple, not to say simplistic, space.
A grandiloquent void which is entirely contrary to the nature of Aberdonian cityscape.
It's blind to the genius loci.
This is a city that thrives on confusions and jagged encounters.

The sum of the various ways in which the stone is used is thrillingly impure.

Much of Aberdeen's architecture may be classical, but the form in which it is deployed, the urbanistic pattern, is far from classical in the regimented mould of Bath and Nancy, Bordeaux and Edinburgh.
Their formal repertoire of squares, circuses and crescents is seldom to be found.

What Aberdeen does possess in Union Street, its latitudinal spine, is a prospect in the sense of a constructed view, an artificial landscape of buildings, an avenue which goes beyond the functional to a terminal or vanishing point.
It occurs in small towns such as Elgin, even in smaller ones such as Keith.
It is ceremonial and public.
There is an equation of civic probity with visual felicity, of civility with architectural considerateness.
It is not dictated by commerce.
Aberdeen is certainly composed of formal buildings.
But Union Street apart, their relationship to each other is, as they used to say, without benefit of clergy.
Informal, unsanctioned, chaotic, unchaste.
This is a city that succeeds because of failure.
Those who have sought to impose their vision - generally, as in this current instance, not the correct word - have failed.
The free trading buccaneers, the socialist improvers, the municipal heroes, the urban regenerators.
They may be ideologically opposed to each other, but they are united in their desire for change, whether for profit, or polity or posthumous prestige.
Even John Smith and Archibald Simpson failed.
They failed to defeat the undulating site and make it level.
They did not erase ancestral footprints.
They did not bury the perpetual presence of previous Aberdeens.
It is making cities tidy that causes them to die.
Aberdeen is so thrivingly alive because its order is tempered by randomness.
There is a balance between regulation and chaos.
It is contradictory and imperfect.
