What we know we learnt ourselves.
What happens if a gypsy girl goes astray and ends up getting pregnant?
Well, we try to look after her, but if it's a boy that's been fetched up as well as he should be, he takes the responsibility, otherwise the family looks after their own problems.
The mother and father never abandons the girl, never kicks them out.
If she has a baby, we look after it and fetch it up and love it as much as we love our own daughters.
The morality as strict and as necessary as that of any beleaguered nomadic minority.
But they tell fortunes, they're astrologers and mystical, often deeply religious too.
Well, we might look barbaric...
Is that the word?
I can't pronounce these fancy words you keep telling me.
We might look mad, you know, wild... but deep down in every one of them, there's only one God.
And the word for it is "monya".
Some make out not to be, but they are.
Is going to church part of a gypsy's religion?
That's the best church of the lot.
We've lost, shall we say, language and quite a few of our small customs of marriage and things like this, whereas the gypsy people abroad have kept them.
What do you think you're losing in the way of gypsy marriages?
It's hard to describe.
I don't accept that the old marriage over the broomstick was how our parents used to say it was.
What was it supposed to be like?
Basically, gypsies are made up into tribes and each tribe will follow a different custom.
In some cases, they'd jump the besom broom, then the others would jump the fire, this type of thing.
This was to solemnise the marriage, but a lot of this is, shall we say, in romantic folklore and quite a bit of it isn't to be accepted as gospel.
Are there still traditional gypsy weddings which have nothing to do with ordinary society?
Not in England.
I've never come across it among our own community.
You do with foreign tribes of gypsy people like Lovari and Kalderash where they have very strong wedding traditions of giving of money and this type of thing.
The English gypsy way of life has got so Gorgiofied that one more or less follows it.
That's non-gypsies - somebody is Gorgiofied.
Gorgio means a non-gypsy or living like a non-gypsy.
And what about the traditional gypsy funeral, the custom of burning the caravan?
With today's prices, you can't afford to burn the caravan.
The tendency now is to sell the caravan.
Caravans are often traditionally destroyed because of the feeling within the community that the spirit of the person who has died still haunts it and they would object to other people living there.
Some caravans are worth a lot of money and there are some families who, if they burned the caravan, would have no means of getting another one in that sense.
You get some families who will actually sell them up the country out the way, so they won't come back normally within...anywhere near the family.
Off a back road, along a lane, down a track and back to the very roots of the gypsies, a family who live in a tent, anachronistically with a car battery for the TV set and record player.
Violet Smith married her husband Bill Parker under Romani law 50 years ago and they kept their own names.
They may be the last gypsy family in this country to live like this.
She makes pegs.
He was a knife-grinder.
They might seem depressingly poor, but they've lived like this all their lives, as did their parents and grandparents.
And they've raised six children.
Did you have a midwife or a doctor come to you?
Nobody helped you at all?
Only my husband's mother.
And she knew enough to...?
Oh, yes.
Are there still people like her around?
Well, maybe one here or there.
It's difficult enough rearing children at the best of times, but imagine bringing up six in a tent in the middle of winter.
How did you manage about such things as nappies, for instance?
I shouldn't waste money like people now on bundles of wool.
Some white sheets cut up in squares have the same purpose.
Once they'd been weaned, how did you feed them?
You didn't buy little tins of baby food.
I used to boil bread.
When the children get a bit older, to five or six, house dwellers sigh a deep sigh of relief and send them off to school.
What did you do with yours?
It ain't funny sending children to school.
Probably wouldn't come back anyway!
What did you teach them to do?
What sort of things?
Well...
It's hard to say what they could do.
Well, I tried to teach them to make pegs, but they'd run out of it.
If you could go back again, would you still live in a tent?
Oh, yeah, of course I would.
Violet Smith is in her late 60s, her husband is 72.
Now they're getting older, they're on the local council waiting list, but they have no priority.
Do you want to stay here or go and live in a house?
You wouldn't mind a house?
As long as it was out in a village, I don't mind.
Too many people.
They get under your feet.
A lot of travellers don't like towns and don't like houses either.
They think they're unhealthy.
All depends how you look at it.
If you make yourself miserable, well...
You wouldn't be miserable in a house?
I can be miserable if I like, but I know I wouldn't be.
Back in the 20th century and another surprise - gypsies who can and do afford caravans costing upwards of £16,000.
At the big fairs like Cambridge, they like to put on a show, to cut a bit of a dash.
They tend to keep cash in their pockets in wads, to treat caravans, horses, cars, possessions as savings accounts and pension funds.
No less logical, really, than a union investing in rare paintings for its members' pensions.
You see chrome-plated trailers.
As one person pointed out to me, "With the money you spent on them, you could buy a house!"
But far more important than possessions, the family - not the two-point-something children of the colour supplements, but five, six, seven or more.
One of the great problems, I'd have thought, living in a caravan when there are lots of children - eight or nine or ten - is for the parents to get any privacy.
Well, as a rule, we've always got two caravans.
One for mother and father, one for the kids.
We call them our kitchens, but really they're for convenience.
Sometimes we'll have three caravans.
So you wouldn't very often find a case where there was a mother and father and five or six children...
Oh, no, that's not very often done.
Unless it's a really poor family that can't afford any better.
In many places, like East Anglia, prejudice against the gypsies is intense.
The Race Relations Board would have something to say if any pub said "No blacks".
For the gypsies, deafening silence.
The landlord told us that if a gypsy went in there, he'd serve him and turn on anyone causing trouble, whether they were gypsy or not.
Well, I've been in there and been refused service.
It was quite a few months ago.
Maybe it's a new landlord since then, but it's obvious from the sign what the intentions of the pub are.
He says he's only been there a few months and the sign was just there.
He has every opportunity to take it down.
It's not in fashion to have that on the wall.
We're a racial ethnic minority and entitled to the use of the Race Relations Act and the benefit of that.
And we challenge local breweries and pubs who actually display these signs.
They must feel they have good reason to refuse to serve travellers.
They tend to drink too much?
No, I don't accept that.
With every community, the settle community as well as the travelling, if a man causes trouble as part of a crowd, by all means evict him.
But to pick on a group of people and say, "We won't have any of that group in the public house," this is wrong.
You feel discriminated against, as though it's not fair and people pick on us, so you react, and that's where you get problems.
They didn't wait in case they got trouble from people before evicting the individuals.
They actually picked on everybody and refused service.
Gypsies who have gone onto sites, many for the sake of the children, have given up a lot.
They've given up independence, freedom, the uncluttered life, and they have not gained the one thing most of them crave - freedom from harassment.
On occasion when we've had the police come on to the ground, between two and three in the morning we've had them checking vehicles and they, in turn, wake the children up.
They'll come with 19 or 20 cars in some cases.
We accept that anybody who commits crimes has got to be arrested, but we don't accept that the innocent should be labelled guilty, disturbed, distress caused to children and older people.
To be honest, this is why we came on the sites, to get away from this harassment and being pushed about.
You can no longer be hung for being a gypsy in this country, but there are still a lot of laws that affect gypsy people and which are derogatory from the gypsy point of view.
You can legislate against things, but not for how people feel.
Under the 1968 Act, counties had to provide sites and district councils the services.
They haven't and even if they had gypsies feel their problems wouldn't have been solved.
Once local authorities fulfil their statutory obligations they can move gypsies on out of their area.
Dorset is the first county to have done this.

They say we'll have full facility sites, transit sites and official stopping places, but they're going to say, "It's a permanent site and we won't have anyone else moving around the area," so if everybody else gets this idea, which we feel they will be doing, the time will come when nobody will be able to move.
There will be enough sites allocated.

They've said many times if I want to move from here to Doncaster or Leeds or London I will have to make sure that there's a place available for me at the site I wish to go to and get permission to move.
One answer would be for the gypsies to stop travelling.
It's an answer, but it will be many, many years.
We hope once they get settled the next step is to get them into housing.
Where they want housing, we try to accommodate them.
But under the growing problem of shortage of housing, it's not going to be easy in future.
The Department of the Environment thinks sites are the answer and says gypsies who choose not to live on sites will have opted out of state aid.
But there aren't enough sites or transit pitches.
Until there are, the Department says officious harassment should stop and local authorities should hope gypsies buy or lease land for their own use.
One couple who have reached the end of the road are Chris and Emily Butler, just two of the 50,000 gypsies estimated to have moved into houses.
They brought up eight children on the road.
The Butlers have lived in a council house for four years.
Well, I don't mind it, but the missus don't fancy it.
I shall never make a home dweller.
Why not?
Travelling blood.
I can't settle.
They'll never stop travellers.
Do you spend much time actually in the house?
Mostly I'm out the back with my little grandson.
I can't breathe in them properly.
I sleep with the bedroom window open all night.
I must have fresh air.
I'd never survive if I didn't!
'Those that have moved into houses' a lot have come back out onto the road, or onto sites.
A lot go into houses over winter and come back out for summer.
But why is that?
Cos I think you miss something of being with your own community.
You can open your door here and it's all your own people around.
You watch each other's children.
From tent to caravan to house, the whole gypsy experience in one man.
'You have to start from scratch and work your way up.
'We had a tent, I was a scissor grinder.
'We used to make our own tent every night.
We saved and saved, me and the missus working.
'We bought ourselves a pony, I bought a dray and I built my own caravans.
'From then we went on to eight horses.'
If you went back to travelling...?
I'd like my horse and wagon again!
The roads ain't made for horses like they used to be.
There's no keep for them, I mean.
Not like there used to be, anyway.
All the old lanes and places, they're fencing them off.
There's nowhere to stop now.
To us, the house dwellers, it may seem a dream of impossible romance.
To the gypsies, it's simpler than that - just freedom.
The fear of the gypsies and the hope of officialdom is that they are coming to the end of a road.
There are 50 million of us and it says something about our insecurities that we feel hostility and intolerance towards such a tiny minority who want only not to conform.
I've been on this site for nearly 30 years and now they've decided to refurbish the site.
It's more comfortable now in a lot of ways and with the improvements it will be better still.
I'm glad the site's getting done, Pete.
About time an' all.
I think there's always more improvements you could do.
There's no facilities for children to play, for instance.
They could at least have done something where the children could associate and play around and have a play area such as swings.
You have to provide your own.
Mr Peter Mercer, for services to the Gypsy Council for Education.
You looked a bit nervous, Peter!
More like a garden gnome!
Certainly, he was very pleasant.
Made you feel as though you were getting something worthwhile.
And the MBE is an honour for somebody like myself.
To be honest, I felt proud of you getting your award, but I felt uncomfortable being there.
It's all pomp and circumstance.
I love being spoiled!
Look at the state of me!
I walk like a docker!
You should get your hair cut.
So this is the trailers we have now.
We've got no glass cupboards in here, nowhere to put your pots up.
You've only got a little shelf.
I've had to find things to put on the shelf.
Before it was all grandeur.
We seem to have gone off that and started to get these sorts of trailers.
This is where I come and do my jigsaws!
I can do what I want to do for an hour.
Because we have come off the road and onto a site, I often think now we're getting older I could see myself living in a little bungalow.
I couldn't stand the stairs and anybody being above me.
I'd like to try a little bungalow.
Maybe one day.
How many pieces in that?
A thousand?
Good God.
That might be the bungalow we live in when I get older!
I might not like it, but I'd like to give it a go.
You wouldn't like it.
You're just saying that.
'I grew up here all my life from being a baby.
'Then when I met my partner he came to live here with me.
'When my first son was six months old, I moved off.
I was 20.'
I would have stayed here at that time, but there was no room.
And it's not something you want to do.
You don't want to live with your mum and dad when you first set up on your own.
Hi, Charmayne.
I just popped over before I fetch the kids back.
She gets under my feet!
'It was horrible when I first got my house.'
I cried.
I was all excited when I was doing it and getting moved in to it.
After a week, I started crying.
There's no room to move back on this site.
I grew up here and so did lots of others.
The site's not big enough for us all to live on it.
I'd like my children to be brought back to get more of a sense of who they are and... how we are as a community, but, on the other hand, it's not the same as what it was for me now.
For a short while, not very long.
How short?
I never had much time to go.
There was too many in our family!
'The kids have all gone to school' and they've done all right.
Their kids are going to school as well!
So I think they've had opportunities like I never had.
Today's a different world completely, isn't it?
Everybody's got to be able to read and write today to get anywhere anyway.
Mizelley's got your Dr Who pen?
I said, "You have!"
That doesn't mean to say she's got it, just because she's laughing.
'Both of the older children now 'they're wanting to go to college to learn a trade.'
That's the only way they're going to get on.
That way of life, the way we used to be, is finished.
You can't do what we used to do, just move round... and work wherever you were.
It's completely different.
Yeah?
You should have started from the end.
'We have a big intake of travelling children.
'Sometimes we have eight or nine.
It depends on what the intake for that year is.
'There's better respect between the children.
They're getting to know our culture and ways 'and our children get to respect what they do and their ways.'
Now we've been doing it for the last 14 years and I've encouraged children off the site.
They'll keep coming now.
Families come here, their children come here, their children will keep coming here because they've got the trust of the school and the staff.
'I'd like to see our children go on to secondary school and be able to take good jobs, 'to do whatever they want instead of saying, "I can't read or write" or "I can't do this".
'I'd like to see them achieve.'
There's not many go on to secondary school.
Because of what they're taught and what parents see.
Children hanging around the streets with cans of beer, smoking, they're taught sex education.
We do whatever we can to try to encourage them in, but we've still got a long way to go.

When he'd left school and wanted to...find a job he said nobody out there, from what he's heard in papers and on telly and he knows people perceive us as thieves, "Mum," he said, "I'm not going to get a job out there."
He said, "I'm going in the army."
I said, "Do you really want to?"
He said yes, he did, because his dad had been in the army and his granddad and everything else.
He went into the Grenadier Guards.
And he's been there seven years now.
How's Sam getting on up there?
OK.
He was flooded out, wasn't he?
It nearly happened again this year.
We still don't have, at the present time, real security of tenure.
We only own a licence and have no more right to claim this piece of ground than anybody.
The council could say that they want the lot, they want to turn it into a car park.
And as far as the law says, this land is still local authority and they can have possession.
If you live in a council house or even a private home, or mobile homes, you've got some security where you can say, "I don't think it's fair."
And you can object and take the issue to court.
As a community, we want the same rights as other people.
If you had security of tenure, you could do a lot more that you don't feel inclined to when, at the end of the day, the authority, for any reason, can have you off.
I would hate to see this go because of what we've spent on it.
And if I was to leave the site now, we'd have to leave that behind.
I'm attending a meeting in Southampton, where I will be meeting with other gypsy representatives from different groups in the southern area of the UK.
Today there are a couple of issues which we will be discussing and that includes the security of tenure.
There was an email sent out about that comment on the document.
General feeling is they're against being tied in with the Act.
It's going to have a knock-on effect on people's movement and other issues.
As you know, the government is now going on a refurbishment programme for sites and building new sites and I feel when they've done all that, we'll get the security of tenure, but not what we want.
It'll be tied in with the Mobile Homes Act.
We want our own act.
..The specialism about gypsy sites and that there has to be that separateness so that we don't lose gypsy sites for the future, we don't lose what we've got in the mush...
'It is working.

It will have its critics in the early stages 'because some of the initiatives haven't worked,' but now we find out that with dialogue and using the law, we're achieving something, more than we have in the past.
The future is, hopefully, good.
There's one or two other places that were just as good.
This was one of our favourites.
But that time's gone now.
We'll never get that back again, even if we did pull back on the road and be able to pull freely where we wanted to go.
You get done for criminal damage and things like that.
You'll never get them good old days back.
You had plenty of wood for your fire, there's plenty of trees you can hang your washing on, you can go and catch a rabbit and put it in the stewing pot.
What better place to start than the West Midlands village of Meriden, which for the last 500 years has laid claim to being slap-bang in the middle of the country.
I'll travel from Meriden to Ryton-on-Dunsmore, then on to Stoneleigh and south to Moreton Morrell, where I'll follow the Roman Fosse Way to Shipton-on-Stour.
And along the way, I'll be looking back at the very best of the BBC's rural programmes from this part of the world.
Welcome to Country Tracks.
This peaceful little village lies between Coventry and Birmingham, surrounded by the industrial West Midlands.
Not surprising, perhaps, that it earned the title of being the centre of England.
Just to get you into a little secret, recent analysis by the Ordnance Survey found that the true centre of England lies 18km north-east of here, on a farm in Leicestershire.
And Meriden is famous for more than its geography.
I'm meeting a group of unusual cyclists to find out why this village is so important to those on two wheels.
David, Phil and Paul are members of the Veteran Cycle Club.
I'm soaked to the skin.
My hands are freezing.
And it looks like I'm not the only crazy person out on a bike today.
You're riding out in all kinds of weather today!
We're used to riding in wet weather.
What is it about this area and cycling?
Meriden is very near Coventry, and Coventry was the home of the bicycle in the 1860s onwards.
By the 1880s, many of the inventions that happened came from Coventry.
The invention of the bicycle really changed society.
What it meant was that, for the ordinary person, they could go further than just their own village.
And what that meant was that we got a much wider gene pool, starting from there.
And the antique classic we've all heard of has to be this one.
The penny-farthing looks quite cumbersome and almost a little bit daft.
Why did that design even come about?
That design came about because the only way to make the penny-farthing go faster and farther was to make the wheel bigger, because effectively that was the only way they could manipulate the gearing.
There was no gearing at all on the penny-farthing because the pedals were attached to the front wheel.
And why was it called a penny-farthing?
Because in the old coinage, the penny was quite a big coin and the farthing, which was a quarter-penny, was a very small coin.
So obviously, the bicycle looks like a penny and a farthing close together.

They may be old, a bit stiff and not the easiest things to manoeuvre, but penny-farthings, or grand old ordinaries as they're also known, are still popular with braver bikers, inspiring many marathons around the country.
The rain has eased up enough for us to brave the bikes.
We're joined by some fellow Veteran Cycle Club members and one of them has got a penny-farthing.
It's not exactly what I had in mind when I pictured a cycle ride around Meriden.
Traffic, rain and slippery road surfaces.
The vintage bikes are beautiful but I must admit I wouldn't swap my mountain bike in this weather.
Bit worried about the others.
Malcolm's lost his pedal.
Malcolm Young has been riding his penny-farthing for 30 years, usually with two pedals.
As the rest of us drowned rats press on, he pulls over and hunts around for the screw to his pedal.
There it is, Malcolm!
After a quick repair job, Malcolm is back on the road.
Meriden has long held a special place in the hearts of cyclists across Britain.
This monument is dedicated to those who fell during the two world wars.
It was built by cyclists for cyclists and a memorial service takes place every year to remember them.
The rain may have stopped absolutely chucking down but the next part of my route takes me along some very cycle-unfriendly roads.
In fact, Birmingham Airport is only six miles from here, so I've decided it's much safer to swap two wheels for four.
I'm continuing my journey to Ryton-on-Dunsmore.
It was here in 2001 that a trial of genetically-modified crops was causing great concern.
They look just the same as other plants but cause a lot more controversy.
Currently, 75 field-scale trials of GM oilseed rape, maize and sugar-beet have been given the go-ahead.
When the history of genetically-modified crops is finally written, New Farm at Woolston in Warwickshire may well get a whole chapter to itself.
This farm has been approved to grow a trial crop of genetically-modified maize.
It's been inspected and meets all the scientific criteria.
There's, though, a problem.
I'm just 2.7km from the farm at the Henry Doubleday Research Association.
This is one of Europe's leading centres studying organic plants and crops and people here are very worried about the trial.
They're about to plant out organic sweetcorn and have been warned that if this GM trial goes ahead, they may lose their organic status.
So there's a chance that pollen will be carried on the wind from the GM crop to our sweetcorn growing in the gardens and on our research area.
And nobody can guarantee to us that there will be no contamination.
So how is it that a GM trial can be approved so near to the Henry Doubleday Organic Centre at Ryton?
This whole process is governed by an EU directive, as well as British Government legislation and regulations.
So the trial crop must be a certain distance away from other crops to try to stop contamination.
But as you can see, not everyone is convinced by those safeguards.
I don't want to see GM, here or anywhere.
We're messing with nature far too much.
Nature looks after itself without us getting involved and messing it about and causing all these problems.
This row has gone beyond local concerns.
The Secretary of State for the Environment, Michael Meacher, wants this site reviewed.
He's told the scientific steering committee, which oversees the trial programme, to reconsider.
But groups campaigning against GM trials say this case reveals fundamental problems in the system.
The reality is that the chemical industry get together a list of sites.

They then put it to a scientific steering committee, which has some very responsible scientists on it, but they're given no information about these sites, so the scientific steering committee had no idea that Ryton was near this particular maize field when they looked at it.
I think that's scandalous.
But Mr Thomas followed the same procedure as any other farmer interested in hosting a GM trial.
Firstly, he was approached by Aventis, the company which developed the GM seed.
Once he agreed to take part, his details were passed on to the industry body for GM crops, called SCIMAC.
It checks that the farmer knows how to grow the crop and that the land's suitable, but doesn't look much beyond the farmer's field.
He should talk to his neighbours about what he's going to do, let them know what's going on, just good neighbourliness of what's actually happening in that area.
But if somebody objects, that doesn't necessarily mean he can't go ahead with the trial, from your point of view?
No, it would depend on the reasons why he's objecting.
There have been some cases where local farmers have raised reasonable concerns and the site hasn't gone ahead.
It's to do, really, with rotations and neighbourliness and it's all what I call village politics.
So under those tests, Mr Thomas's farm gets a green light.
Once approved by SCIMAC, his details are passed on down the chain to the scientists.
They've been contracted by the Government to inspect potential sites and monitor the trials.
They're looking for a mix of farms and types of land but one of the scientists leading the study admits that what's on the other side of the hedge is mainly outside their remit.

In the immediate vicinity, like the next field, the other side of the hedge, as you say, we record what's there because we're interested, obviously, if it's something like a workshop or work area like that, concrete, it'll have very little insect life on it, whereas if it's, say, a wildflower meadow, that would have a lot.
And we'd expect, obviously, a lot of things to come out of a wildflower meadow, not much to come out of a concrete area.
So we'd need to know that.
But that's really as far as the scientific study goes.
That's really as far as we go.
So why don't you take what's outside the field into consideration?
And ours is to get a selection of fields that we can do the proper science on.
Another green light and Mr Thomas' details are passed on to the scientific steering committee.
The scientific steering committee's role is to oversee the trials and advise the Government.
It's made up of scientists and conservationists, including people from both English Nature and the RSPB.
The RSPB says if GM maize is planted here, it'll leave the committee.
It claims Mr Thomas' farm was only given the go-ahead because no one realised how close to Ryton Organic Centre it is.
Other members of the committee argue all the relevant information was considered.
What the scientists actually look at is really quite limited.
They're interested in the science.
Now the protesters say that's where this whole system is flawed, because nobody is really worrying about what happens outside the trial site.
I don't think the trial should be taking place at all.
The risk of genetic contamination is too great to justify them.
But does the GM industry still think it's got the right system?
It's a unique set of experiments being done.
Britain has a pioneering role in there and I think they're doing them to the right sort of standards.
GM trials have been controversial since they started.
What this case highlights is the confusion within the various groups which run the trial programme as to what criteria test sites ought to meet.
Controversy still surrounds genetically-modified food.
And I've stopped off at Ryton-on-Dunsmore to update the story.
Eight years ago, shortly after that film was made, the GM trials were stopped and the Henry Doubleday Research Association, now Garden Organic, is still here, organic status intact.
Throughout the late nineties and early noughties, there were mass protests against GM crops and so-called frankenfoods.
Fears over health, damage to the environment and claims that genetic engineering companies wanted to take over the food chain all contributed to consumer suspicion.
But today we live in a very different world.
Climate change, drought and a global growing population are all contributing to an increase in demand for and limited supply of food.
Worldwide, murmurs that GM crops may be the answer are getting louder.
But Garden Organic is still a passionate voice of opposition.
So have opinions here changed over the years about GM crops?
Not very much, actually, because we haven't had any major evidence that GM crops do work.
There hasn't been much coming up in the meantime and we still hold to our principles, the organic principles, of maintaining integrity and working in harmony with nature.

And we still have our concerns about contamination and pollution to humans, in terms of ingesting a genetically-modified food and the environment, as well as concerns about how farmers can access these seeds.
The world's population is predicted to hit 9.1 billion by 2050.
And genetically-modified crops like soya, maize and oilseed rape, to name a few, are being grown by more than 13 million farmers in 25 different countries.
But Garden Organic believe there's an alternative.
They're working with farmers in the Caribbean on GM-free projects like rainwater-harvesting to boost crop yields.
They say it creates overall drought-resistant farms, as opposed to a single drought-resistant GM crop.
Across the world, farming faces significant challenges in the future.
Back on British soil, Garden Organic is also looking to the past, with a seed library aimed more at gardeners with a vegetable patch than large-scale arable farms.
In order for a vegetable to be sold commercially, it has to be registered.
But most of these dropped off the registration list years ago, so they haven't been grown, sold or eaten since, but the experts here at Ryton are bringing them back to our gardens.
So, Vicky, where do all these seeds come from?
We get some of them donated by families.
They've often grown them in their family since time immemorial and they've been passed down through grandfather to father to son and then we get them.

Some are ex-commercial varieties, ones that were once on the National List but have been dropped either through lack of commercial sales or sometimes when seed companies merge or close down, then they'll drop their whole catalogue, so we'll pick up a lot of those, too.
So, what benefits do growers have from these seeds over the standard seeds you can buy in a regular garden centre?
Often these will have been grown in a particular locality for an awfully long time.
That means that, over the generations, they've had a chance to adapt to particular micro-climates or particular soils in a region.
Also, these will have been saved for reasons that are more suitable for the home garden.
So instead of being large agricultural seeds, they're for small-scale growing.
An example of that would be peas.

Normally, all peas now or dwarf peas so they're easier to harvest and combine through a field, whereas there used to be hundreds of climbing peas varieties because they're more productive in a small space.
So we've lost a lot of tall peas from the National List.
There must be quite a lot of work keeping this library of seeds here.
We're a living collection.
So everything in this room will be grown out every three to five years depending on seed longevity.
The Heritage Seed Library relies on gardeners donating the seeds from their prize vegetables.
I've got beans in this case.
And then it's up to Garden Organic members to plant them.
It all keeps the cycle going and ensures that these varieties aren't lost for ever.
Other welcome visitors to our gardens are butterflies, and close by in Stratford-upon-Avon hundreds are living under one roof under the watchful eye of butterfly enthusiast Richard Lamb.
I was fascinated even before I can remember.
All through school, I always concentrated on biology.
I took it to university, where I did a degree in entomology.
After that, I got a job on a conservation project.
That then led into a job at a butterfly farm, which led to this butterfly farm here, one of the biggest ones in the country.
I love all butterflies, but one of my real favourites is the blue morpho.
Dull brown on the underside but bright electric blue on the upper side.
A real flash of electric blue.
All these different butterflies have different arrangements of different coloured scales to make up this pattern and all have different reasons for the colours and patterns.
Maybe camouflage or warning colours or mating colours.
All sorts of different reasons.
We have suppliers in many different countries in the tropics, lots of different types of supplier.
One is in Kenya.
And there's a lot of the villages around a National Forest, and to protect the natural forest the project was set up and got the villagers involved in breeding butterflies.
This helps protect the forest, because the locals that live next to the forest don't cut it down for bush wood.
They realise it's a sustainable resource and they earn hard US dollars for the butterfly pupae they produce, which we buy from them.
This is our emerging cage, and this is where we hang the pupae.
We hang them up on sticks with Copydex and the caterpillar completes its metamorphosis inside the pupa.
Then it breaks out and expands its wings and then flies away to lay eggs, start the cycle all over again.
So, this is the final result.
Butterflies from all round the tropics, Central, South America, Africa, the Far East, all together in one place, the whole world here in Stratford-Upon-Avon.
Leaving the butterflies of Stratford-upon-Avon behind, my journey through the heart of England continues, winding south through Warwickshire to Stoneleigh.
This is Stoneleigh, for nearly half a century, home to the world famous Royal Show.
Prize-winning sheep, champion bulls and magnificent horses sporting colourful rosettes as a testament to Warwickshire's farming heritage.
But this year was the last ever Royal Show.
With visitor numbers starting to dwindle, the organisers decided to call it a day.
Traditionally, it was the Grand Ring that was the show's focal point, and Countryfile was no stranger to the ringside.
So, let's take a fun look back at some of the best bits of the Royal Show.
The summer of 1989 marked the show's 150th anniversary.
Organisers the Royal Agricultural Society of England rolled out the red carpet for Her Majesty the Queen and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.
Highlights of this year's show included a truly regal opening by the Prime Minister - recognition indeed from Whitehall of the importance on the political agenda of all things environmental.
The following year, in 1990, John Craven reported from the Royal Show for the first time for Countryfile.
It was one of many visits to Stoneleigh for John, and surely there's no better way to view the showground than from the air.
This is a wonderful way of seeing the Royal Show, from the basket of a hot air balloon.
You see how large the showground is.
There's about 20 or so balloons flying at the moment.
We're nearly hitting a tree!
More recently, John has been joined by fellow presenters, Adam Henson and Charlotte Smith, who made the most of their day out.
Cor, I'm being attacked by a big soldier!
I tell you what I am interested in, is one of those front-end loaders over there.
Come and have a look.
No, I'm going over here cos there's men in uniform.
You haven't got any mirrors or anything, have you?
In the summer of 2009, this long-standing agricultural tradition came to an end.
It was a sad farewell, but memories of the Royal Show will easily last for another 170 years.
I'm driving through the Heart of England on my way to Moreton Morrell.
In keeping with the agricultural theme, I'm on my way to Warwickshire College, where students can spend up to five years learning the historical art of blacksmithing and farriery.
I'm meeting apprentice, Luke Cain.
How long have you been on this course?
I've still got another two years.
A four-year course, quite a long time.
What made you decide to do it in the first place?
I saw someone shoe a horse one day and thought, "I'll have a go at doing that."
Do you have any concerns, when you're qualified, about the amount of work that's out there?
I think there's quite a few farriers out there at the moment, so everyone's fighting for a bit of work.
Once you start the course, how long is it until you're in the fire and hands on?
When you come to college it's pretty much the first day.
There are some fierce temperatures there, you must be boiling!
It's pretty hot.
When you first started learning, was it more wracking being in the fire, or around the back of a horse?
A bit of both, really.
I've been round horses a bit.
You tend to learn what horses can do.
They get a bit frightened of the smoke and the hot shoes and jump around a bit, but at the beginning I think everyone is a bit nervy.
Have you ever had any slightly badly behaved horses, when you've been shoeing them?
And you learn how to deal with that in training?
Yeah, I think that's why the apprenticeship is four years.
So you can deal with anything when you qualify, you know how to deal with everything.
Luke's very kindly letting me have a go.
Pull that shoe out there.
Hold it tightly in your other hand and keep brushing it on each side.
Turn it over and do the other side as well.
Look at my technique, such an amateur!
That will be good enough.
It doesn't feel complete, unless I dunk it in water.
I wish that was my work, but that's Luke's beautiful craftsmanship.
Fabulous.
The relationship between people and horses goes back centuries, from fighting battles to pulling royal carriages, racing derbies to policing our streets.
It makes farriery one of the oldest careers in the world.
Traditionally it's a job for the guys, but I'm about to meet a female blacksmith, who has made her mark in a man's world.
Have you faced any particular challenges because you're a woman?
I probably did very initially when I started training in college.
It was a little bit dark ages, there was a bit of sexism, but it's moved on, I don't think it's in existence now.
A really daft question now, but what's the difference between a blacksmith and a farrier?
Farriers shoe horses, blacksmiths don't.
Traditionally, the blacksmith would have done anything to do with metal, including shoeing horses.
But it's changed, and it's been changed for a long time.
Farriers train to shoe and they tend to specifically just shoe, and they don't smith and blacksmiths do everything but shoe.
Michelle's metal work mastery has earned her a place among the worshipful company of blacksmiths.
She's the first ever woman to join their ranks in its 700-year history.
The sheer number of courses available here is a reminder of how much work there is in the countryside.
As long as we've got horses, we'll need farriers.
And as long as farmers plough their fields we'll need tractor engineers.
But there is one course I can't find in this prospectus, and that's buffalo farming.
That's one that could come in handy around here as we discovered a few years ago.
The Asian water buffalo, at home in the rivers and the lakes of the Indian subcontinent.
Beasts with more transcendental tranquillity than a meditating Yogi.
But hang on a second, this isn't India and it's not the monsoon season, it's just a damp day in the English Cotswolds.
So, what are these animals doing here?
Well, the story began eight years ago when a farmer decided he wanted to get into milk, but he thought he'd try something a bit different.
One big advantage, you don't need to buy expensive milk quota.
These exotic animals are outside the system.
They prefer mudbaths to European red tape.
So does Robert Palmer, who has now got more than 250 buffalo on his farm.
A big herd considering he's started virtually from scratch.
At first, we brought, I think it was 12 buffalos, not much bigger than these into the country, because we didn't really know at that stage whether they would even survive under UK conditions.
There's no reason why they wouldn't, because they're pretty hardy animals and they live in a variety of climates and they can be farmed high up in the Himalayas.
In those early days, we only had a very small amount of milk, so what we did was, we processed it ourselves here into buffalo mozzarella and it was very much a cottage industry then.
Like dairy cows, Buffalo need to be milked twice daily.
For stockman, Adam Smith, working with buffaloes was a novel experience.
He was used to ordinary cows.
Buffaloes are better, he says, they're much easier to handle.
Touch wood, we've never had a nasty buffalo in the parlour.
Whereas I've managed 300 cowherds and we might kick 10 heifers out a year for temperament.
So when you look at these with their big horns, and people think they look scary, they've very placid.
After milking, what could be nicer than a cold shower?
In fact, the only thing that seemed to upset them today was walking past the camera.
But within seconds, they put it all behind them.
The easy bit's actually getting it into the tank.
The hard part is co-ordinating the marketing and distribution of the milk.
At the moment we ship milk as far apart as London to Preston.
It goes into a range of products and it goes into traditional matured cheese, it goes into buffalo mozzarella, it goes into yoghurt, its uses are limitless, really.
This morning, Robert is making a local delivery.
Just a few churns of buffalo milk to a nearby company that turns it into yoghurt.
The process takes about an hour from start to finish.
It's all scientifically controlled.
The end result is an extra creamy luxurious yoghurt.
But it's expensive.
Buffalo's produce less milk than cows, but Robert can sell it for three times the price, and there are other bonuses.
Of all domesticated species, they're probably the one that's most ignored by man.
They still have a lot of the primitive instincts there.
The major thing is that we don't have any problems with mastitis, we don't have any problems, we don't have any foot problems.
We've had our calves, over 160 calves here, we've never had to assist at one calving.
They just don't seem to have any illnesses.
The animals can remain productive for up to 20 years.
Buffalo milk is high in fat but low in cholesterol.
And demand is growing.
The best thing about Buffalo to be honest is that they appreciate the attention which you can spend on them.
Unlike cows which are seen to be totally blase about the fact that you're doing everything for their creature comforts.
I'm quite convinced of that.
Do you think they're more intelligent than dairy cows?
Definitely, there's no doubt about it.
The intelligence level of a buffalo is far superior to a normal cow.
Will the British countryside soon be covered by herds of super-intelligent but placid buffalo?
Robert Palmer says we could see many more here, if other people discover the basic benefits of buffalo farming.
Much easier to handle and a lot more farmer friendly than the conventional cow, really.
You try making a television film with buffalo.
Hey, get off.
That bull has managed to hook my belt, you know, I'm going to fall off any moment now.
And you'll be pleased to know those cheeky buffalo are still grazing the fields around Shipston on Stour today.
This green county is perfect for all kinds of grazing animals, and I'm on my way now to meet another unusual Warwickshire herd.
After leaving the almost centre of England in Meriden, I travelled south to Moreton Morrell and now I've joined the ancient Roman road known as the Fosse Way.
It's a typically straight Roman road and its name, Fosse, comes from the Latin word, fossa, meaning ditch.
I'm on my way to a farm-come-circus to meet some Middle-Eastern visitors to Warwickshire.
Now, we've tried all kinds of ways of getting around on Country Tracks, but I can definitely say riding camels is a first.
Make sure I close the gate, I don't want them to escape.
Come on, babies.
Their owner and my guide is Joe Fossett.
He comes from the oldest circus family in the UK.
Generations of performers and animal trainers who have been entertaining the public since the 16th century.
They're famous for bareback riding and dazzling showmanship.
So, where did you get the idea from circus life to, I know, I'll have a camel farm?
I have always loved camels.
They have always been one of my favourite animals.
I'm giving up the circus, this is all over, I thought, what will I do next?
I thought I want to do something with animals, camels are the perfect animal to work with.
I saw loads of advertisements for horse trekking, so I thought, why can't we do camel trekking?
Can I approach?
I've never been this close to a camel, they're much bigger than I imagine.
They're the nicest animals you can imagine.
They've got this terrible reputation for biting and spitting, but they don't.
My secret with camels is carrots.
So they aren't grumpy at all?
I've ridden horses before, which I love, but I've obviously never ridden a camel before, and they're really quite big.
I'm really quite nervous.
Right, I'm just going to lie her down for you, are you ready for this?
That's amazing.
If you swing your leg over, hold on to the handles on the hump harness.
Are you ready?
Don't look so worried.
Go on, up, there we go.
I'm on top of the world up here.
You're taking me off!
Even better than across the desert.
The camels here are a mixture of Bactrians and Dromedary, native to the Middle East, Mongolia, Northern China and the Gobi Desert.
But judging by our relaxed pace, I think they feel pretty at home in rural Warwickshire too.
So, Joe, is this reminiscent of circus life up here?
It's what I've done all my life, really.
But it's different.
These animals, as you can see, they're free, they live in the fields, they spend the night in stables, they eat lots of food, they go trekking.
I have arrived in Shipston on Stour on the back of a camel.
I'm sure the region's coaching inns have seen plenty of weary horses and their riders over the decades.
Camels may remain more of a welcome novelty.
Cheers, that was a brilliant ride, thank you.
One of Warwickshire's most famous sons is, of course, William Shakespeare.
400 years ago, he set forth on a journey to London on foot, of course.
John Craven retraced his steps.
Today I'm going to be walking along a trail that was taken by a young man more than 400 years ago.
It led him from the sleepy home town on the banks of this river to the theatres of London where he found fame, a fame which today is stronger than ever.
He was born here at Stratford upon-Avon, he was of course, William Shakespeare.
Named in his honour, the Shakespeare Way, 146 miles long, leads from Stratford to the Globe Theatre, now reconstructed in south-east London.
The great man is buried here at Holy Trinity Church in Stratford.
Here it is, look, in the sanctuary, just a slab of stone, with not even a name on it to mark him.
Even today, people from all over the world still send flowers to Shakespeare's grave.
Next to it is the grave of his wife, Anne Hathaway, which is also unmarked.
Before I start off on my walk, I'm going to find out a little bit more about Shakespeare's early days here in Stratford.
William was born in this house in the middle of town.
It's now one of the centrepieces of the Shakespeare tourist industry.
How much is known about his early life here in Stratford?
There are very few facts to go on in Shakespeare's life, but one of the certain things is that he was baptised in Holy Trinity Church within the parish towards the end of April, 1564.
And therefore, born a few days before that, we assume.
One of the things we do know about the year 1564 is that it was a year when there was a severe outbreak of plague in Stratford.

It hadn't actually broken out at the time of his birth, but certainly, up to one-third of the population was affected by plague during the rest of the year, so in a sense, we're quite fortunate that Shakespeare survived.
Do we know when he left Stratford for London?

He had his first child born here soon after the marriage, and twins a couple of years later, so he must have been in and around Stratford at that time, but by the early 1590s, we have record of him being an established playwright and actor, so he must have been in London for a few years before that in order to establish that reputation.
That would have been in his mid-twenties, would it?
He was born in 1564, so he was about 20 when we assume he left Stratford.
One reason that has been put forward for his departure from Stratford would have made it a rather sudden one.

About five miles outside of town is this beautiful building, Charlecote Park, the home then as now of the Lucy family, and legend has it that young Will was caught poaching on the estate and brought up in front of Sir Thomas Lucy.
As with so many other things to do with Shakespeare, there's no evidence of this, but if it had happened, he might have had to leave town rather quickly to avoid any punishment.
But I've no real need to hurry, and soon the Shakespeare Way is leading me through verdant countryside.
It probably hasn't changed very much since young Will walked along this river bank.
I've been joined now by Peter Titchmarsh who designed the routes of the Shakespeare Way.
How did you do it?
I talked to a number of Shakespearean scholars and after long discussion it became reasonably clear to me that he must have walked to Oxford to start with.
Well, he had a great friend who kept a pub in Oxford.
In fact the pub is still there behind modern frontage.
Because nobody knows exactly which way he'd have taken?
That's right, that's why I've subtitled my guidebook "A Journey Of Imagination", to cover myself.
How long do you reckon it would have taken William to walk it?
Well I took twelve days when I eventually did walk it as one go, but he'd probably have done it in six.
And what kind of people do you reckon he might have met along the way?
I think he might have walked alone, because that's the way I like to do it, but, however, many people think he may have joined up with the strolling players, possibly even from Warwickshire.
That could well have given him his inspiration then, for writing plays.
I've now reached the border between Warwickshire and Oxfordshire.
Down there is the village of Long Compton in Warwickshire.
Just over here is something that Will Shakespeare would've been bound to have seen as he walked by, because this stone has been here since prehistoric times.
It's part of a series of stones which were put up round about the same time as Stonehenge.
This one is called the King's stone.
It's been protected by railings for a long time now, because drovers as they went by used to chip away and take pieces of stone to bring them good luck.
So, the whole thing was in danger of falling over.
Well, these are known as the Rollright stones, aren't they, Don?
No-one knows why they're here, John.
There are three parts.
The stone circle that we're in at the moment is just a bit older than Stonehenge.
Across the field over there is the Whispering Knights.
Across the road where you've been, the King's Stone, that's only 3,500 years old, it's quite young!
When it was built, it was a sort of wall with only one entrance, unlike Stonehenge or Avebury.
What are the legends surrounding this place?
Well, there are two main legends.
The first is you can't count the stones.
If you can count them three times in a row and get the same number, you can have any wish you want.
We actually have two sets of archaeological drawings and they don't agree with one another.
What about the other legend then?
The other legend is why they're here.
King Rollo of Denmark was invading England trying to conquer it all and camped here for the night.
The stones here represent his army.
Then a witch showed up and said, "Let's do a deal.
"If seven long strides you can take, Long Compton thou shall see.
"King Of England thou shall be".
The army said, "Oh, no!
He took the long strides, one, two...
Just as he got to the seventh stride, she made the ground jump up in front of them.
And when you were at the King Stone, you couldn't see Long Compton.
You can't see it to this day, in fact.
And she then turned him, and the King's army and the Whispering Knights, into stone and she turned into an elder tree.
Onwards along the Shakespeare Way and in the village of Woodstock is one of Britain's most famous stately homes, the Palace of Blenheim.
It's certainly a magnificent sight, isn't it?
A major feature of British history, but not for William Shakespeare, because it didn't come until 100 years after his death.
This is the piece which is so important to the Bard.
This is the plinth which marks the site of the Royal Palace of Woodstock, which stood here for 400 years right up to and beyond his time.
He would see the magnificent palace here built by the English kings and used by the Tudors as a hunting park for deer.
You know the story of William and the deer...
He might have been tempted to do a bit of poaching as he walked by.
Anyway, I think we can conjure that we're standing somewhere near his steps because this would be a major feature of the countryside in his day.
Of course, the palace itself was the birthplace of another famous Englishman, wasn't it?

After the war when he was in his seventies, Richard Burton, the great Shakespearean actor, recounts this little moment, he's at the Old Vic, he's doing Hamlet and Churchill comes to watch and he comes round to see him beforehand.
Then he goes to sit in the audience, front stalls, of course, and the play begins.
Then Burton's conscious of something and he realises what's happening is that Churchill knows the play by heart and he's saying it with him as he speaks.
But a major irritation for Burton, I think.
And very off-putting.
And here, just a couple of miles from Blenheim in the churchyard of the parish church in the village of Bladon Winston Churchill lies buried next to his wife, Clemmy.
A BBC poll voted him the Greatest Ever Britain.
William Shakespeare came 5th.
So, my walk started at the final resting place of our greatest ever playwright.
It's ending here at the tomb of arguably our greatest ever statesman.
The two men, you know, had one thing in common, they were both supreme masters of the English language.
The Shakespeare trail winds on from here for another 98 miles until it reaches the Globe Theatre in London.
From the West Midlands village of Meriden to Ryton-On-Dunsmore and the Agricultural Showground at Stoneleigh.
I visited a farriery at Moreton Morrell then followed the fossway to Shipston-On-Stour.
Now I've arrived at the university city of Oxford and night is falling.
2009 is the international year of astronomy.
It's 400 years since Galileo, the father of modern astronomy, developed a telescope which gave us the first views into our universe.
Now a project called Galaxy Zoo is posting astounding modern images like these on to the internet and asking the public to go online and help classify a million galaxies.

Suitably inspired, I'm being taken by a member of the Oxford University team behind the website to a special location just outside the city where local astronomers are training their telescopes at the stars.
How's the star-gazing this evening?
A few more clouds than we'd have liked, but otherwise not too bad.
This is a very impressive-looking telescope.
This one right here?
Actually, I'm not sure if I'm looking at it right because I can't see anything!
It's not looking at anything because it's cloudy.
But what have you seen tonight?
We were looking at Saturn earlier and the Moon.
Then we tried to look for some of the brighter galaxies, but unfortunately they were a bit washed out by the Moon.
Maybe I'll have better luck on telescope number two.
We've got this scope...
Mm-hm.
There's definitely something there.
What's been your best ever sighting in the Heavens?
Well, the way this telescope's pointing at the moment, this is the best theatre there is at night...facing south.
As the night goes on, it moves from left to right and there's such a lot in there.
After the tiniest glimpse of Saturn, I'm hoping the third telescope will reveal more.
I've just caught the Moon.
It's just come through the clouds and it's quite a nice view at the moment.
You'll have to kneel down, it's a little bit low.
What an incredible amount of detail.
What range does this telescope have?
It ranges in terms of magnifications.
It'll go up to about, in practice about 300 is a good view, because if you go any higher than that, you have to move the telescope so fast to keep up with the things as they move around the sky.
Can I move it slightly?
Ah, that's just amazing.
I think the Moon is definitely my favourite.
Can you see the small craters in the sea?
Moving out of the town has enabled me to look into the night sky and it's the perfect place to reflect on my journey through the heart of England.
This landlocked region may lack the rugged beauty of our national parks and coastlines, but my travels through it have shown me why for so many people it's a place close to their hearts.
God gave me a marvellous gift, and I can shoot babies out.
My sperm cells, they'd bounce off the root canal and they'd be straight into the egg, boy.
I decided I didn't want to forget my kids and the only way to do it is engrave their names on my body.
Scar myself, tattoo myself, call it what you want, so I decided to have this family tree done.

One to the first girlfriend, seven to the first wife, three to the second wife.

Once a thriving mining town, the area now has one of the highest unemployment rates in the UK.
Well, I grew up in the valleys and followed my father down the coal mine and hated every bloody minute of it.

The South Downs covers more than 600 square miles of south-east England.
It's part of London's commuter belt, and it borders many of southern England's seaside resorts.
After years and years, the South Downs was actually confirmed as a national park in March, but the news hasn't been welcomed by everyone.
On one side of the fence are those who want to protect the natural beauty.
On the other, are those that manage the land commercially.
The precise boundary still hasn't been agreed, but the new national park will cover areas of East Hampshire and Sussex.
The decision to go ahead is a victory for the people who have been campaigning for it for decades.
Margaret, how long have people been interested in protecting the South Downs?
It really started at the end of the 19th Century, when people were concerned about development around Brighton, and bought up land around that area, around Devil's Dyke.
And then in the early part of the '20s, Peacehaven was being built.
And people were so horrified by what they saw that they decided they had to do something to protect the area.

Some of the earliest conservation groups were set up at that time to protect the area.
