Well, just look at it, it's very beautiful, as you can see.
The chalk hills with their unimproved grassland, full of different varieties of plants, and so on.
And here in the weald, you've got these ridges of woodland, you've got a necklace of heathland going through from east to west and, of course, these chalk vales.
People forget that we're within an hour of London here, and there's pressure on an area like this.
Huge pressure on an area like this within easy commuting distance of London and the south coast towns.
The development pressure is absolutely extraordinary on these areas, so without protection they could simply disappear under concrete.
The new national park doesn't have mountains, huge areas of moorland or large forests like other protected areas.
85% of it is managed farmland, intensively farmed on a commercial basis.
Tom Tupper's farm is slap-bang in the middle of the new national park.
Like many farmers, he's concerned about the extra bureaucracy and red tape that could come when the National Park Authority takes control of the area's strategic planning.
This is the old milking parlour on the site, which is now a redundant building looking for a use.
One of the possible uses is to convert it for temporary accommodation for seasonal workers on the farm.
But this could become a more controversial issue for the planners under the National Park Authority.
But the key is, it's not just a lovely place for people to come and visit, it is a working environment.
Farmers like Tom hope their concerns about planning will be addressed.
Phil Belden is part of the South Downs Joint Committee, and one of those supervising the transition to national park status.
Will a farmer be able to build an outhouse, any building, that will help them farm their land properly, are you going to stop them doing that?

It's not me, the National Park Planning Authority working with the Local Authority, would judge each case on its merits, and to me, outhouses, anything that helps farming diversification, is going to help rural tourism, is going to be a good thing.
Farmers are understandably nettled and concerned.
You've given them some assurances, but they've got nothing in writing that things aren't going to change.
They need to sit at the table as well with the DEFRA establishment teams various local authorities, everybody gets round the table together.
Crucial thing now is to craft, to mould something that is actually right for the South Downs.
Can commerce and conservation, in your opinion, work?
But another concern is housing.
Will more rigorous planning restrictions mean that future development is relegated to the outskirts of the park?
The housing that's planned will happen anyway, and that's a Central Government policy.
You're not pushing them out into a big ring?
You can't push them out, it is a living landscape.

It's not fossilising the Downs by saying no more development, there will be development in the Downs, but crucially it must reflect that national designation, so it's got to be good, attractive buildings, stuff like that.
There are challenges, affordable housing is a classic one.
How do we keep the workers on the land, living in the local area?
There are some big challenges to face.
The South Downs is a beautiful part of the country.
As the newest national park, it will be fully operational in 2011.
Later, I'll be deep in the South Downs woodland making the charcoal that will fire our barbecues this summer.
But now Matt's finding out about a threat to this landscape that not even national park status can protect it from.
That threat comes from the sea itself.
After 70 miles of undulating land-based scenery, the South Downs meet the sea and its underlying rock, chalk, is exposed in a spectacular way.
The white cliffs of the Seven Sisters are one of our most well-known views of British scenery, but they're only kept this white, almost as if they've been painted, because of erosion by the sea.
That's usually a gradual process and takes centuries, but here it's happening much faster.
It doesn't just erode the chalk face and keep it white, it also rapidly undermines the cliff foundations.
In parts, it's as much as half a metre a year.
Just to give you an idea of that rate of erosion, by the time my two-year-old son is driving, the cliffs will be back to here.
I hope he passes his test first time!
By the time I've done as many Countryfile programmes as John Craven has, believe it or not, in parts, this coastline will be back to here.
By the time the Seven Sisters have moved way up there, this spot is going to look very different.
We're sat here making the most of this cup of tea, aren't we, Rory, because in a few years time this bit won't exist.
You're right, Matt.
If you look over the last 130 years, we've lost 75 metres from the edge of the cliff line, here.
It's going at a considerable rate.
The question is, then, how can the sea, way down there, how is it eroding cliffs that are really quite high?
Yes, just behind us they are 85 metres high, and yet the whole cliff is going.
Where we've got the pure chalk cliffs, the waves do get to the base of the cliff and create an undercut, a so-called notch, which is part of the process.
And whenever we get rainstorms, as well as storms at sea, attacking the cliffs, the combination of all of those factors is creating cliff collapse.
That's what happened nearby at Beachy Head in winter storms ten years ago.
It's one of Britain's most famous natural landmarks, but now there's a great deal less of it.

Thousands of tons of rock from Beachy Head in East Sussex have collapsed into the sea, and the rubble has now almost filled the Channel between the 500 feet cliff and its unmanned, offshore lighthouse.
But it's not just the waves hitting the cliffs causing erosion - the continual movement of the flint pebbles on the beach is just as damaging.
Rory, we've obviously got a classic example of cliff erosion here so tell us what's been going on.
Matt, what's so beautiful about this bit of cliff is that we've got a flint gravel beach.

When the tide comes in, the energy from the breaking waves goes through the flint gravel beach to the base of the cliff and the pieces, these particles of flint, actually start to rotate at the base of the cliff.
And they erode the base of the cliff, that's continually happening when the tide's high.
We're now about 80 metres up, aren't we, and there is a frightening crack just behind us.
It's literally just hovering there in position, ready to go.
It could go in the next half-hour while we're standing here or it could go tomorrow morning, depending whether we're going to have a rainstorm overnight or not, that would probably determine it.
But you certainly should not stand the other side of a crack like that anywhere along this cliff.
Later on, I'll be down at sea level with a lady who is delighted that these cliffs are eroding.
But first, each week we're going to be turning our spotlight onto Your Country Life.
Mildred Cookson is the country's only female watermiller, and she's on a mission to preserve this ancient way of life.
This is Mapledurham Watermill.
It's the last working mill on the Thames.
One of only 28 mills in the country that are still grinding commercially by wind and water power.
I'm a miller and I've been here 28 years and hopefully will continue for many more years to come.
Today, everything is perfect for milling.
This is called a rack and pinion, a very simple arrangement.
By pulling on this... ..the water now hits the paddles at the bottom, pushes the wheel round and away we go.
It's quite physical - lifting 25kg bags of grain, so you get quite fit.
I come from Lancashire and was surrounded by about 15 windmills.
Watching the sails turn on some of those was wonderful.
From where I worked in my office, I could look at a windmill working.
I wondered why I was sat there when I could be over there.
Unfortunately, there are no windmills in the Thames Valley, just watermills.
I'll open a small shoot and let the grain come down into this hopper.
The problem is we had a very bad harvest last year.
It looks like there won't be much English wheat available.
You can't grow enough in England at the moment.
We've got the grain here ready to start milling to turn it into flour.
That's done by the grain travelling from here down to the mill stones, one on top of the other, with a gap between them.
The grain will go between them and get cut finer and finer until it gets pushed to the edge and drops down a hole at the front into the flour bags below.
You all right?
What would you like?
Once the flour's milled, it gets bagged up for bakers and visitors or for local shops and farmers' markets.
The mill's mentioned in the Domesday Book in '86.
A miller's life traditionally was a lonely one.
The Miller of Dee - "I care for nobody, because nobody cares for me."
Basically, he had two sides to him.
One was his honest side to the lord of the manor.
The other side was his dishonest side where he used to steal flour from his customers.
My husband's always relieved when I get home at night all in one piece.
He's a bit scared of it, I think.
Thinks it's big machinery for a little lady to be running.
The mill will decide when it's had enough of me probably.
I say to friends that they'll have to carry me out of here... when the time comes!
In the heart of what will be the South Downs National Park is this area of woodland.
100 acres managed by a man who's devoted his life to looking after the countryside.
Ben Law has lived and worked at Prickly Nut Woods in West Sussex for over 18 years.
He also earns his living from the woodland that he manages.
On a day like today, it's stupid to ask why you'd want to live here.
It's pretty self-explanatory!
All those years ago, what appealed to you about this kind of lifestyle?
It's getting back in touch a bit more with nature really.
Woods are the life force of our planet.
Unless we look after them and manage them well, we're going to have more problems further down the line.
When you start working with woods and forestry, it's a lifetime thing.
I'm often looking to the next generation or the one beyond.
When I plant a tree, I'll never see the end result of it.
That way of thinking is a way of looking after the planet and thinking ahead to the next generation.
Ben has spent winter cutting back trees to promote new growth - coppicing.
He turns the waste wood into charcoal that we use for barbecues.
This is one of my kilns.
Best part of a ton in this one.
To start with, I light it like a normal fire.
If I left it like that, it would go up in smoke.
Once the fire spreads out, I start to control it with earth and restrict the supply of oxygen.
You end up with something close to pure carbon.
So, lid on?
That's next.
Right.
I'd like you to push that right the way into the centre of the kiln.
We'll do a couple more of those.
She's on fire now.
95% of the charcoal we buy is imported.
Buying British means it's from a sustainable source and reduces carbon emissions by 85% because it doesn't travel as far.
There are other benefits too.
We're lucky in the UK as the wood we grow here has that ring structure.
It means you can't light imported charcoal with newspaper as you can with UK charcoal.
It actually works out cheaper to use UK charcoal.
You don't need fire lighters and you don't get that horrible food tainting as well.
Can we satisfy demand in this country?
The way Ben produces it is fantastic on a small scale, but if we're increasing production, we need to look at technologies that can re-burn some gases and make the process more efficient.
How long before this batch is ready, Ben?
It'll be about...well, about 12 hours before I shut down the burn.
Then it'll need to cool off for about a day and a half.
If you open it up too early, the oxygen gets back in and the whole thing can reignite.
When dealing with fire, you're dealing with natural elements.
Most of the time, I get it right, but I'd never say you can master fire.
Later, Ben puts his charcoal to good use, barbecuing a meal with a difference.
Coming up on Countryfile, plant expert James Wong has some tips for the country's 12 million hay fever sufferers.
We'll be testing out Nordic walking, the fitness phenomenon that's sweeping the nation.
If you're out and about in the countryside this week, don't miss our five-day weather forecast.
Now, Europe is starting to work out a new fisheries policy.
At the moment, vast quantities of fish that could be eaten are going to waste.
John is along the coast in Hastings with this week's Countryfile investigation.
British fishermen are forced by law to limit what and how much they catch.
Catch too much or the wrong sort and it has to be discarded, to be thrown away.
Fish and chips may be our national dish, but for every cod that ends up on a plate from an EU boat, another gets dumped, dead, into the sea.
The EU say quotas are vital to protect stocks, but fishermen say their nets tell a different story.
Out here in the North Sea, British trawlers are allowed to catch a total of around 11,000 tons of cod a year.
They complain that's not enough and that quotas are forcing them out of business.
Yet, conservationists argue that limits don't go far enough to protect a critically-endangered species of fish.
It's not just big boys having problems.
I've come to Hastings where there's a fleet of small inshore boats.
The sea is calm right now, but the fishermen tell me they're having a rough time.
The 600 small boats here in the southeast say that their total quota for the whole year was only 23 tons.
They caught that in just four days.
Any cod they catch now, they have to throw back.
To find out how this is affecting their business, I'm heading to sea with Paul Joy.
How far off do you reckon we are?
It's before dawn when we leave Hastings.
Paul and a two-man crew are hoping the nets they left overnight will now have trapped fish such as sole, which they can legally take back to shore.
Sole is a long, thin fish with no bone structure, so they just slide through quite easy.
So, you're not allowed to land cod, are you?
The quota system is intended, isn't it, to preserve the stocks?
This does no preservation of stocks, you're catching it anyway.
You're just not allowed to keep it.
We're not looking for it, but we will catch it by accident.
To dump it back over the side dead is a crime.
At this time of year, there isn't much cod around, so we'd been catching mainly sole.
This is a cod that you've caught, is it?
So, that will just have to go back.
How do you feel having to throw back a good-sized cod like that?
If that cod can survive and live, it's OK.
If we could continually do that, it's not too bad.
These will die.
Once that's come up through the water, the swim bladder will rupture and it will die.
It's a waste of a fish and a waste of a good feed.
So, it's got nothing to do with conservation - throwing back cod?
It won't survive.
During the six hours we spent on the boat, we caught only three cod.
In the winter months, at the height of the cod season, Paul tells me they catch hundreds of them and nearly all have to be thrown back.
The very fact that we have these quotas, isn't that because scientists say that you can't just take it all out of the sea and land it, you have to restrict the catches?
Quotas have to be realistic.
If you bring it down to monetary value, a boat is allowed to earn £7 a week.
That is ludicrous!
How can you run a fishing vessel on £7?!
Joining us on this trip is Tom Rossiter, who works for a research group called SeaFish, funded by the government and the fishing industry.
Underwater cameras help investigate how changes in net design could help fishermen like Paul catch only what they're allowed.
You're now attaching the camera to the net.
Really, we're looking for two things.
One is to see how the net interacts with the sea bed.
The second thing we're really interested in is the behaviour of the fish around the gear.
With the camera firmly attached to the net, it's lowered down and its position is marked.
So, on our way back home to shore, we just have to collect it and see what the fish made of it.
Sadly, on this trip, technology failed us and nothing was recorded.
But, this video, taken on an earlier trip on the net of a trawler shows how the camera can help researchers discover the ways fish try to escape - vital information when it comes to net design.
The biggest problem for inshore fishermen when it comes to avoiding cod is the size of the nets they're allocated by the EU.
Fishing for smaller species like sole needs a small mesh.
As we head back to shore, I want to find out what conservationists think should be done to stop so many fish being wasted.
What's your reply to fishermen here who say there's plenty of cod and they shouldn't have to throw it back again?
Scientists still say that stocks are at critically-endangered levels.
We need a long-term approach so that fishermen using their nets can catch fish in the future.
Does that mean they have to keep throwing them dead back to the sea?
It's our view they should use the right gear to catch the target fish such as sole, so they don't catch as much cod in the first place.
The fishermen say that when it comes to solutions to their problems, the politicians never listen to them.
I don't believe that.
Actually, politicians listen to them too much and take a short-term view of the policy.
Would that mean areas where nobody could fish?
Protecting the environment will allow fish stocks to recover and these guys will see an improvement in their industry.
It's not just cod that's an endangered species.
That same fate could await thousands of fishermen if quotas are cut back even more.
Here in Hastings, frustration spreads way beyond the fishing crews.
This cafe is within sight of boats landing their catches, but owner Maggie has to get much of her cod from far afield.
Cod and chips is your business.
How do you feel not being able to use local fish?
Well, I'm not very happy about it obviously.
There's not a lot we can do though.
They just have to keep throwing it back in the water.
Well, it's dreadful.
Dead fish being thrown away and being washed to the shore.
My customers ask what it's all doing just laying there.
Your customers, are they ordering less cod these days?
They do like the cod.
They try to give them pork or other fish, but they're not interested really.
Three days ago, the European Commission released its green paper.
It's the document for discussion on the reform of the current fisheries policy.
So, with conservation and quotas back on the agenda, should we look outside EU waters for a solution?
This is Norway, which many observers say is one of the best examples of sustainable fishing.
Fishermen who break the rules can be fined, have their catches confiscated, but never ever is fish wasted, thrown away back into the sea.
Next week, I'll be taking Hastings fisherman Paul Joy to see the Norwegian way of doing things.
Could it save the livelihood of men like him?
Today, Countryfile has come to the newly designated South Downs National Park.
I'm at the chalk face, where it's not development or tourism that's wearing away the park boundaries, it's the sea.
That's not necessarily bad.
In places, the erosive power of the sea is cutting into the cliffs as fast as half a metre a year.
That helps create a valuable habitat for marine life on the beach.
There's lots of different things.
This is a very special little chap!
This is a purple topshell.
You can see it's got this really lovely mother of pearl on top and these fantastic purple stripes just underneath.
Really beautiful.
He is a climate change indicator.
He's got a typically western distribution.
Certainly up until about 15 years ago, you wouldn't find this here.
It seems to be marching steadily eastwards and we regularly find these every time we come rockpooling, which is quite a good indication that sea temperatures are rising.
It basically looks like this because of the limpets that live on it.
They're essentially marine animals, so when the tide goes out, they're doing everything they can to try and stay cold and wet.
They clamp down very tightly onto the rock.

To make themselves really close to the rock, they do a little bit of grinding and they use acid secretions to dissolve the soft chalk around them, so that their shell fits absolutely tightly to the rock.
Over the years, it grinds away and dissolves away the chalk.
From a wildlife point of view, it's great if it gets broken up because you get nooks and crannies that other animals can use for shelter from drying out but also from predation.
From a wildlife point of view, a bit of erosion's lovely.
Above the beach, these buildings are threatened by erosion.
The last house on this row was demolished.
Experts say the whole row is at risk.
The future of these cottages may be bleak because they're not architecturally unique and protecting them would be too costly.
But there is a building further up the coastline over that hill that was deemed special.
Ten years ago, it was physically moved back from the cliff.
David, we're standing level with where the lighthouse used to be.
It was moved back just under 20 metres.
I understand it was quite an engineering feat.
They underpinned it, burrowed underneath and built a concrete support.
28 jacks all synchronised with a computer jacked it up two feet and pushed it back on greased slides.
The people that were here then had quite a nice collection of glass ornaments and not one got broken.
So, David, what on earth made you want to buy this lighthouse?
There is the potential to move it back again as and when necessary.
The reinforced concrete supports were left in situ, so it could be jacked up again and moved back a similar distance.
Which gives the phrase "moving house" a whole new meaning!
A few weeks ago, we saw Adam battling to save the lives of some of his new-born lambs.
The bluetongue disease is a huge worry for us livestock farmers.
I've spent my whole life living and working on this farm in the Cotswolds.
It looks idyllic, but each week, presents its own set of challenges.
I rear livestock and grow crops and it takes a huge amount of effort to make it work.
Farming is a serious business and it's not just my livelihood, but the whole team rely on its success.
Get a bit of straw and tickle its nose and it goes...
It's hard work, but I love it.
The one that got away!
I started lambing about a month ago.
It's a manic time of year for me and now the end is almost in sight.
That ewe there with the twins are the two lambs I helped give milk to when they were very small.
I said they were a bit rubbish.
Aw, you're rubbish, aren't you?
LAMBS BLEAT Actually, now they're allowed to grass with their mother, they're doing very, very well.
They look very similar to most of the other lambs.
It's moments like this when you can come and see them and how well they've done that makes it all worthwhile.
There's plenty of vital work for me to get stuck into.
Needless to say, not everything is straightforward.
This ewe is having triplets.
She's got one already.
Now she's got two.
Then there were three.
When I get a triplet, I try to get a mother who's only had one lamb to adopt it, so it gets plenty of milk.
This ewe is only having a single lamb, so she'll be an ideal foster mum for the triplet.
It's a huge lamb.
So, I'll just rub this lamb all over this one.
The idea is to get both lambs smelling the same.
Particularly under this one's tail, where the ewe sniffs a lot.
It helps dry off the freshly born lamb too.
Ideally, she'll rear two lambs.
When they give birth to triplets, the lambs run to suckle at the same time and the smallest one gets there last and misses out.
Then, it gets smaller and weaker and misses out time and time again.
Really, it's quite difficult for a ewe to rear three lambs.
They're much better off with two.
The lamb has been accepted by its new mum.
We turn these out into the nursery pen so they learn to find their mother in a crowd.
If they go up to the wrong ewe, she'll sniff them and realise they're not her own and butt them away.
They've got to learn to find her now.
Tomorrow, they'll be out in a field with 50 ewes and 100 lambs.
If they get lost on a cold, wet night and haven't got a belly full of milk, they'll die.
There'll be plenty of other obstacles facing them when they do get outside.
Today, I have a special job for my rookie sheepdog Millie.
Alongside trusty Maude, she has to round up some young ewes or yearlings, which need to be vaccinated against bluetongue disease.
For me, it's pretty easy.
My handling pens are fairly close and I can gather my sheep with my dogs and vaccinate them all by myself.
But, hill farmers with thousands of sheep on the mountains, who they don't see from one month to the next, it's a completely different kettle of fish.
For a young dog, she's doing very well.
This is the bluetongue vaccine.
They get one ml each under the skin.
I'll work my way down and vaccinate them.
I'm gonna do all the sheep, cattle and goats on the farm.
Bluetongue can be a killer in sheep.
I saw the effects of it in Belgium two years ago, where it's killed up to 40% of those infected and left many others infertile.
Now that the weather's warming up, the midges will become more active.
That's how the disease is spread, by midge activity.
We check round our sheep every day to make sure they're all fit and healthy.
Bluetongue can show itself in various forms - the animal can be lame, off-colour, off its food...
Occasionally, they get a swollen blue tongue, but that is only very occasionally.
You know, sheep are often lame and off-colour and feeling ill.
Every time I see one, I think, "Crikey, I hope it hasn't got bluetongue."
Last year, with lots of us vaccinating - and a bit of good luck - we stayed free of an outbreak here.
It's like vaccinating for any disease, really.
If not enough of us do it, there's a risk that the disease will spread.
I've just gotta hope that everyone's in it together and we all get on and vaccinate.
That's all my yearlings done, they're now protected against bluetongue.
It's gonna be a month and a half before I do all my lambs, so I hope the disease doesn't strike before then.
Despite the threat from diseases like bluetongue, there are plenty of reasons for me to be cheerful.
Farmers are doing well despite the recession.
The price of lamb is sky-high.
Hopefully, this will make all my hard work worthwhile.
Next week, I'll be seeing if I can find a way of making my rare-breed porkers pay.
Still to come on Countryfile: James Wong has some natural remedies for hay fever sufferers.
Julia and I will be putting our best foot forward when we put Nordic walking to the test.
Earlier on, woodsman Ben Law showed me how to make charcoal destined for our barbecues.
Now, we're off to find some food we can cook with it.
In Ben's wood, he hunts... the grey squirrel, but he's got good reason to.
This is three years of regrowth...
This one here, shredded by the grey squirrel.
Just ribboned up completely there.
Yeah.
In some years, they'll come through and strip every other pole.
So, a serious and real threat to you?
If I didn't control the grey squirrel, I couldn't earn a living from these woods.
The grey squirrel has no predators, so I have to become the predator.
And if I kill the grey squirrel, I'll eat it.
There are two million grey squirrels in the UK.
Ben uses an air rifle and searches for his quarry with the help of his trusty dog, Oily.
So three is quite a good number.
You never know how many.
A really good day, maybe we'll get six, seven, eight...
With my apprentices here, I'd eat squirrel at least every fortnight.
It's a good-quality meat.
With the squirrel cleaned and skinned, it's ready for the barbecue.
Ben's using his own charcoal, of course, but he's also assembled a very green-looking woodland salad.
That's wild garlic flowers.
Hedge garlic.
Quite a lot of garlic...
Garlic-tastic with the squirrel today!
So about six different leaves in here?
Yeah, a woodland salad bag.
You can pick one out any time from spring through to summer.
Shouldn't be too long, three or four minutes.
Try and describe the flavour to me.
It's like rabbit, but not so gamey.
It's a unique flavour, put it that way.
Can you see a day where we'll have squirrel in supermarkets?
I'd much rather see a bit of squirrel on a supermarket shelf than a piece of meat imported from the other side of the world.
Serving up the squirrel couldn't be easier.
Just add some of Ben's woodland salad and a drizzle of chilli oil, and it's a forest meal fit for woodsmen - and me.
I don't even want to know how many times YOU'VE had squirrel...
..But this is my first.
What do you recommend I should go for first?
Chew on a leg.
Mm, great flavour, isn't it?
Mine's tender, I don't know about yours.
Sorry!
12 million people in this country suffer from hay fever.
If you're one of them, you're probably dreading the next few months.
There are plenty of over-the-counter remedies, but James Wong, our plant expert, has been looking at some natural alternatives.
For a true plant geek like me, walking around this forest is absolute paradise.
But for people who suffer from allergies, there's stuff waiting on every turn to ambush you.
This silver birch and the grasses in front of me are real culprits.
Hay fever is an allergy to pollen.
Most plants, including grass, trees and some weeds produce pollen.
Pollen carries male DNA to the female plant.
A quarter of all hay fever sufferers are allergic to tree pollen, and their symptoms can start as early as February.
But 95% of sufferers are allergic to grass pollen, and that season starts right about now.
I always think it's funny, when you buy hay fever medication, on the packet, there's always pictures of flowers.
But it's usually pollen from trees and grass, much more than flowers, that cause the issue?
I think because flowers are nice and brightly coloured, we think it's the flower pollen that's affecting us.
Flower pollen is designed to be carried on insects from flower to flower, so it doesn't travel very far, and allergy to flower pollen is not much of a problem.
Most people think think of hay fever as a mild, inoffensive condition, but in some situations it can be considered quite severe.
Yeah, it is regarded as something trivial, but for many people it really does affect their lives.
People with hay fever take time off work, and even when they are at work, they don't function effectively.

We know that schoolchildren can drop an exam grade if they've got symptoms at exam time, and after all, hay fever is largely a problem in teenage and young adult years, so that could affect you at university as well.
One in four of the population have hay fever.
Teenager Alice is just one of them.
My eyes swell up and I get a really sore throat, where the pollen gets to the back of my tonsils and closes up my throat.
I get a really sore nose, and it's always running and then it goes blotchy and I can't breathe.
You're a really outdoorsy person, you've even got your own horse - is it difficult to be different from your mates?
It's quite hard.
I go to the stables every day in the summer holidays and you're in grass, hay, fields, dust...it's really...

The hay fever is really bad, and when everyone else is coping fine and running round the fields, I have to sit back and watch sometimes because it gets so bad that I'll end up not being able to breathe out of my mouth or nose.
If YOU have hay fever, it's recommended you start taking your medication early, and continue throughout the season.
Use petroleum jelly to trap the pollen and stop it going up your nose... wear wraparound shades so the pollen can't get into your eyes, and...
If you've got a dog like this guy, if you take him for a walk, he's basically gonna act like a giant piece of living Velcro, trapping pollen which can later be distributed through your house.
A good idea is to rub him down with a damp cloth just to trap some of that pollen and get rid of it and to prevent it from getting indoors.

It had happened before, of course, all those Edwards and Richards violently done in by their subjects, but this WAS different.
Now the British monarchy itself had been exterminated.
Now there was just the people and its Parliament, the keepers of the liberties of England.
But what was the point of freedom when you were frightened?
What the people really wanted to know was - who would keep them safe?
Who would stop the soldiers from burning and pillaging, allow people to sleep quietly in their beds?
Who would protect them from the wars of religion and politics that seemed to go on and on and on?
Would it be Parliament?
Or would it be a great general, like Oliver Cromwell?
It doesn't matter, said the hard-headed philosopher Thomas Hobbes, a royalist who'd come back to Cromwell's England.
"What the country needs is a strong ruler who embodies all of the people.
"Whatever or whoever can save the country from anarchy, "whatever can save you from yourselves.
"Never mind about what's right or wrong - put yourself in the hands of the power that protects, "the all-powerful leviathan.
"If that's Oliver Cromwell, then so be it.
It's the reasonable thing to do."
But the Scots, English and Irish were not about to be reasonable - because they were too busy being righteous.
Over the next 50 years, righteousness would kill a lot of the British.
At the end, reason would appear, but not before a lot of tears had been shed, tears of rapture and tears of grief.
Not everyone was lying awake at night, biting their nails about the plight of kingless Britain.
For many, this was the dawn of a new age.
It's true no-one had foreseen this during the civil wars, but, in giving them victory, the Almighty had shown them that Albion must be turned into Jerusalem.
He had lain the Stuart kings in the dust.
The only king to follow now was King Jesus, and the only true government that of his saints.
The Kingdom of God was at hand, the most blessed revolution of all, and no-one was more convinced of this than Albion's holy warrior, Oliver Cromwell.
"Religion is not at first the thing contended for, "but God brought it to that issue at last and at last it proved that which was most dear to us."
Cromwell called himself a seeker, and what he sought all his life was God's destiny for himself and for his country.
At first, he'd been innocent of the Lord's design.
For years, he'd just led the life of an obscure East Anglian country gentleman.
Just as Cromwell was beginning to make his way in the world, some sort of crisis happened to his modest fortune.
But what the world might have seen as misfortune was, through the cunning of the Almighty, his saving grace.
He underwent some kind of religious conversion.
The vanities were stripped away so he might be opened to the light.
"Oh, I lived in and loved darkness and hated the light!
I hated godliness, yet God had mercy on me.
"Oh, the riches of his mercy!"
The sense that God had some special service for him made a new man of Cromwell.
He knew where he was going and what had to be done.
What had to be done was to tear the sword out of the hands of the untrustworthy, Papist-loving king.
He went to war as a complete novice, with no military experience whatsoever, but his sense of divine appointment was his armour.
It made him supremely confident, cool under fire, but never reckless.
An aura of invincibility began to cling to him.
He became the driving force of the godly revolution.
When the vanquished king defied God's judgment, his blood was needed to expiate the crime.
But it became obvious that doing away with the monarch was no guarantee of doing away with the monarchy.
For if Charles couldn't be among his subjects in person, his proxy could.
The Greek word "eikon" means both an image and a copy, and the Eikon Basilike, the spitting image of the king, appeared within a week of his execution.
It was an instant bestseller, going through 35 editions in a year, and it made Charles an imperishable martyr, a latter-day Christ, sacrificed for the sins of his people.
Like Christ, Charles too would be resurrected wearing his heavenly crown, and made flesh in the person of his son Charles II, awaiting the call from exile in France.

The poet John Milton, an ardent champion of the Parliamentary Commonwealth, was hired to attack the cult of the king-martyr as "so much wicked idolatry", to persuade the fearful and the gullible they didn't need a Charles I, nor any Stuart monarch.
"Look," he wanted to say, "Just stop worrying about the dead king.
"Come to think of it, you've always been the sovereign.
Kings have been yours to hire or fire."
But when Cromwell and Milton told the people that it was time for them to govern themselves, they didn't, of course, mean to be taken literally.
What?
Every jumped-up weaver or ploughman with some sixpenny-book learning announcing he'd just appointed himself magistrate, granting himself the vote?
Heaven forbid!
No, the people should put the government of the state into the hands of the kind of men God saw fittest to exercise it - incorruptible men of substance and piety.

"Oh, I see," said freeborn John Lilburne, the Leveller, an ex-army officer who wanted to level the distance between the mighty and humble, the rich and poor, "You mean the same kind of people who got us into this mess?"
We've all known a John Lilburne, haven't we?
Some of us have even been John Lilburne - first to the barricades, first to be arrested, won't shut up, but, love or hate him, you know he won't go away.
To Squire Cromwell, he was a pain in the neck, a dangerous loudmouth, capable of wrecking army discipline.
Lilburne, for his part, detested the new regime.
"All you intended when you set us a-fighting "was merely to unhorse and dismount our old riders and tyrants so that you might ride in their stead."
The soldiers read freeborn John and believed they should have the vote.
Give them an inch and they'd take a mile.
Pretty soon, the men would start believing their officers were the tyrants Lilburne said they were.
An army was not - repeat, NOT - a commune.

I tell you, you have no other way to deal with these men, but to break them or they will break you, yea, and bring and all the guilt of the blood and treasures shed and spent in this kingdom upon your heads and shoulders, and frustrate and make void all that work that, with so many years' industry, toil and pains, you have done!
I tell you again - you are necessitated to break them.
Off to the Tower went the Leveller leaders, like so many traitors.
But then something astounding happened...
A petitioning campaign to demand the release of the Levellers was mobilised by Leveller women.
Now, for the Puritans, the cardinal virtues of women were silence and meekness, but these women were shameless, obstinate, loud-mouthed and, it has to be admitted, brave.
Leveller women had always been involved in the movement's political campaigns.
Elizabeth Lilburne was politicised through her efforts to spring her husband from various prisons.

Mary Overton had been brutally punished for printing and distributing her husband's tracts, tied to the end of a cart and dragged through London's streets with her six-month-old baby, pelted like a common whore.
But the most impassioned and articulate of the sisters was Katherine Chidley.
She started as a charismatic preacher and turned to politics in an attempt to make the Commonwealth understand the particular sufferings of her sex.

"Considering that we have an equal share and interest with men in the Commonwealth, "and it cannot be laid waste, "and considering that poverty, misery and famine like a mighty torrent is breaking in upon us, "and we are not able to see our children cry out for bread "and not have wherewithal to feed them, we had rather die than see that day."
This was not what Oliver Cromwell had expected from Jerusalem.
It got worse.
In May 1649, some hundreds of soldiers mutinied and tried to combine forces in Oxfordshire.
Cromwell rode hell for leather, 50 miles in a day, and caught them in the middle of the night at Burford.
One of the prisoners, Anthony Sedley, locked in the church, expecting the worst, carved his name into the font.
The next morning, three of his comrades in arms were led out into the churchyard and shot.
Then Oliver went off to get an honorary degree in law from Oxford.
He made sure the mutinous soldiers were shipped off to a place where they could vent their frustration on someone else.
"Want to know who's to blame for prolonging the civil wars?"
"Say hello to the Antichrist across the Irish Sea."
The target of Cromwell's march through blood was an army of royalists holding out in Ireland in the name of King Charles's son.
In fact, it was as much Protestant as Catholic, but in his conviction they were the legions of the devil, Cromwell was not about to make nice distinctions.
At Drogheda, on the main road between Dublin and Ulster, he made it only too clear what he had in mind.
There is no point sidestepping this horror.
This was Cromwell's war crime.
This great atrocity has contaminated Anglo-Irish history ever since.
But we need to get right just what this atrocity was.
It wasn't indiscriminate butchery of women and children.
No eyewitnesses ever claimed to have seen any such thing.
What Cromwell DID order, unhesitatingly and without any mercy, was, in any case, an act of unspeakable murder.
At least 3,000 royalist soldiers were butchered at Droheda.
The vast majority after they had surrendered and disarmed.
At St Peter's Church, Cromwell's soldiers burnt the pews beneath the steeple, to smoke out the defenders, who were incinerated in the flames.
The general saw no need to hang his head about the massacre.
"We have come to break the power of a company of lawless rebels...
"..Enemies to human society, whose principles are to destroy... all men not complying with them.
"We come by the assistance of God to hold forth and maintain the lustre and glory of English liberty "in a nation where we have an undoubted right to it."
This is absolutely authentic Oliver Cromwell, and today it makes for unbearable reading.
No, it's not the confession of a genocidal lunatic, but it IS the confession of a narrow-minded, pigheaded, Protestant bigot and English imperialist, and that, surely, is bad enough.
Cromwell treated Ireland like the primitive colony he thought it was, moving the Irish off their farms and using the land to pay his soldiers.
Before he could finish pacification, if that's what he thought it was, another piece of unquiet Britain rose up to mock him.
For the Scots had invited the 20-year-old Charles II to come and be their king, and went to war on his behalf.
Cromwell lured them into England in the summer of 1651, where the Scottish army found itself caught between two bigger forces.
At the Battle Of Worcester, on the 3rd September, it went down to a ruinous and irreversible defeat.
Charles went on the run, hidden by royalist sympathisers until he could get smuggled out of the country.
So when Oliver Cromwell returned to London in the Autumn of 1651, it was as an English Caesar - the like of whom had not been seen since the days of Edward I.
If Cromwell was God's Englishman, it was because he felt that England was God's true promised land, and it was best for Britain to become as English as possible.
The Stuart dream of a united Britain had been what had started the civil wars.
Now Cromwell had ended them by making that dream a reality, not as a united kingdom, but as a united republic of Great Britain.
But what kind of republic was it supposed to be?
Cromwell knew the country was exhausted from almost 15 years of war.
It was time, as he said, to heal and settle.
This didn't mean business as usual.
Surely God didn't mean for so much blood to have been spilled only so that ungodly lawyers and money brokers could get richer?
That was the way things were under the government of the Parliament - the keeper of the liberties of England, as it styled itself.
It sat as it had when its members had been purged by the army to allow the trial of the king to proceed, ridiculed by enemies as the "Rump".
To Cromwell, the Rump was a monstrosity - a bastion of selfishness and greed, more like Sodom than Jerusalem.
Worst of all, it showed no signs at all of wanting ever to close down.
When it came up with a bill designed to keep itself going indefinitely, this was the last straw.
On April 20th, 1653, Cromwell marched down to Westminster with a troupe of musketeers.
Moses was descending from the mountain, and he was not a happy prophet.
At first, it seemed as though the Member for Cambridge would behave.
Cromwell sat in his usual seat, he doffed his hat, he asked if he might address the house, and he commended the Rump for its care of the public good.
But, as he warmed up, the niceties were tossed aside, and he began to berate the astounded members for their indifference to justice and piety.
"I expect you think this is not parliamentary language," he said.
"Well, I confess, it is not, "and neither are you to expect any such from me."
The hat went back on - always a bad sign.
And Cromwell started to march up and down, shouting that the Lord had done with them and had chosen instruments more worthy of their calling.
Someone tried to stop him in full spate, but, by this time, Cromwell was in exterminating-angel mode and brushed him aside.
"You are no parliament!"
The boots entered heavily, noisily.
Parliament was shut down.
It was a depressingly modern moment - a classic coup d'etat, in fact.
Cromwell had crossed the line from mere bullying to dictatorship.
In so doing, he undid at a stroke the entire point of the war that HE had fought against the King's unparliamentary conduct.
Cromwell claimed he was striking a blow against ambition and avarice, but what he wounded, and fatally, was the commonwealth, itself.
This is the point at which Cromwell could have seized power, and everyone expected him to.
But he wasn't working for himself - he was working for God.
In Parliament's place, he would set up an assembly of men chosen for their piety.
His language was very different as he exhorted them to go about their business.
"Love all the sheep, love the lambs, "love all, "tender all."
But mystical rapture and politics don't go well together - at least, not in Britain - and in a few months the unworkable assembly collapsed - its leaders begging Cromwell to end it.
He duly obliged.
Now there seemed no alternative but to take the crown - to become Oliver I.
But this was still a step too far for a man whom God had told to punish the haughtiness of kings.
Instead, he chose to become a lord protector.
He was king in all but name, but a constitutional sovereign, ruling with a council and a newly elected parliament.
His great hope was for a settling, but the Protector himself was unsure in his own mind about the direction he should take the country.
Should Britain be righteous or reasonable?
It was a civil war that he fought over and over again in his own head.
Squire Cromwell saw the virtues of a reasonable state of affairs.
Given a little breathing space, the old world of the counties was coming back to life.
Magistrates were sitting at courts, gentlemen riding to hounds, war-damaged houses being repaired, children being married off, friends and neighbours asked to dinner.

And when some gentlemen were elected to the Protectorate parliaments, the old connections between Westminster and the counties - the secret of English government - were at last being put back together.
The righteous Cromwell fretted.
This return to older methods was only too successful.
It was not so much healing as backsliding - royalism by the back door.
So, in 1655, Cromwell turned his mastiffs loose.
The major generals.
It was their job to take righteousness out into the shires - the Protestant Taliban on horseback.
Muffle the bell ringers, snoop on the ale houses, lock up fornicators, cancel Christmas.
John Evelyn, royalist and gentleman of letters, who endured the leviathan of the Cromwellian state, was one of many who found themselves the victim of the general's bullying.
My wife and I went to London to celebrate Christmas Day - Mr Gunning preaching in Exeter Chapel.
As he was giving us the holy sacrament, the chapel was surrounded by soldiers.
All the assembly surprised and kept prisoner by them - some in the house, others removed.
It was a public relations disaster for the Protectorate.
Cromwell reasserted himself over the pious, and got rid of the major generals in a hurry.
There were some places, though, where the two instincts worked together and changed Britain as a result, and this is one of them - the synagogue of Bevis Marks in London.
Historians claim it's difficult to find hard evidence of any good at all that came out of the Protectorate.
This is hard enough evidence for me.
It was on these unforgiving, backless oak benches that the first Jews to be admitted since the expulsion 360-something years before parked their behinds.
It was under the Protectorate that Jews were allowed finally to worship openly and to live openly in what became a piece of multi-cultural London.
Cromwell is to thank for that - for opening a new chapter of Anglo-Jewish history - MY history.
His apocalyptic timetable told him that the conversion of the Jews would herald the coming of the last days.
But he saw that with a network in the Dutch and Spanish trading world, the Jews could be a priceless source of commercial and military intelligence.
Piety and pragmatism - those twin qualities so often at odds inside Cromwell's personality - this time came together to make him, as far as the Jews were concerned, a true lord protector.
In the end - and so unlike the king he had destroyed - Cromwell could not lose his sense of unworthiness.
It was what saved him and Britain from a true dictatorship.
Cromwell believed he worked for God - real dictators think they ARE God.
It was THOSE men who fancied themselves as little gods - Charles I or the republican oligarchs - who most aroused Cromwell's contempt.
Simplicity was a word he used about himself, and it was the highest of moral compliments, but to prolong the Protectorate, Cromwell needed to be more of a leviathan than he could stomach.
And that is both is exoneration and his failure.

It's one of the most extraordinary ironies of British history that Cromwell's Protectorate, demonized by both royalists and republicans alike, ultimately formed the blueprint for our constitutional monarchy.
A chief executive chose his government, but both were answerable to a regularly elected parliament.
But Cromwell himself would not live to see this happen.

On September 3rd 1658, the anniversary of the Battle of Worcester, Cromwell died, while an immense, black tempest was raging over England, ripping out trees and sending belfries crashing to the ground.
It was, the old wives said, the devil coming for his soul.
What Oliver Cromwell left behind was not a workable political system, but a vision.

He may have been an angry, ruthless, overbearing man, perhaps even a manic depressive, but that vision was something of startling sweetness, a sighting of Jerusalem, a place where everyone would be free to receive Christ in their own way, provided they did not disturb the peace and conscience of anybody else.
After all his marches and slaughters and fits of table-pounding, red-faced fury, what it turned out Oliver Cromwell wanted for everyone was a quiet life.
But Catholics were excluded from this vision because for Cromwell, and the country at large, Catholicism meant tyranny.
The Protector left the country safe from despots, but not from anarchy.
After his death, it returned - power swinging between the soldiers and the politicians, sleepless nights, the nagging questions from ten years before.
"Where do we find a sovereign to protect us?"
It took another hard-headed soldier to see the only way to restore order.
General George Monck had been a royalist in the Civil War, and a Cromwellian when it seemed that only the Protector could keep the peace.
Now he realised that with the Lord Protector gone, there was only one person who could take his place.
Ironically, Charles II came to the throne not because England needed a successor to Charles I, but because England needed a successor to Oliver Cromwell.
There was universal rejoicing, bonfires and feasting.
The chaos brought by Cromwell's death was ending.
This new Charles seemed just what everyone had hoped for, a model of sweet reason.
Pepys was a pure product of Cromwell's England.
He was present when the new king boarded his flagship home.
On route, the tall, dark-haired man told the story of his escape after the Battle of Worcester.
Here was a king full of charisma.
But would his reason survive the emotions stirred by his return?
The diarist John Evelyn recorded, with unrepentant royalism burning in his breast...
"This day came in His Majesty to London after a sad and long exile.
"With a triumph of above 20,000 horse and foot, "brandishing their swords and shouting with inexpressible joy, "the ways strewn with flowers, the bells ringing.
"And all this without one drop of blood, and by that very army which had rebelled against him."
The King was crowned at Westminster on 23rd April 1661.
His reign was backdated to the day after his father had been beheaded.
But even before the coronation, there were those with long memories who were looking for revenge.

On January 30th 1661, exactly 12 years after Charles I's severed head dropped into the straw, the remains of Cromwell and the regicides were taken from their tombs and hanged from the common gallows at Tyburn before being buried in a deep pit.
Over the next months, eleven other king killers were hanged, drawn and quartered.
The old Cromwellians watched all this in tactful, furtive silence.
They wondered just how reasonable this new regime might actually be.
Killing the kill-joys, Charles knew, would not damage his popularity.
Given a free vote, the people would, especially after the major generals, vote for pleasure over piety.
And leading the dance, of course, was Charles himself, constitutionally incapable of being so churlish as to spurn any woman generous enough to invite him into her bed.
They all did.
If Puritan England had been governed by the ear, wide open to receive the Word of God, the Restoration restored the sovereignty of the eye.
Its ruling passion was scopophilia, the addiction of gaze.
Whether eyeballing an outrageous wig, a plunging neckline, a louse caught in the lens of a microscope, or the constellations of the stars.
Charles's boyish enthusiasm with the latest optical instruments suggested he might be a new kind of Stuart.
One whose vision dwelt not in cloudy realms of absolutism, but which was precisely focused, concerned to observe reality, political as well as physical.
He might even turn out to be a reasonable Stuart king.
This was the Stuart for whom the physical world was his alpha and omega, who was earthy in his realism.
All too earthy, some thought, as they looked down in disgust at the theatre of indolence punctuated by debauchery that had become the court.
They were not SO worldly, as to be free of the fear that some day there would be a reckoning.
In the summer of 1664, a comet appeared in the skies over England.
Its sallow tail could be seen with unprecedented clarity through the lens of the new telescopes, owned among others by the King.
What most people saw was disaster in the offing.
They had all read their almanacs.
They knew the Apocalypse would be heralded by pestilence, fire and war.
A year later, thousands of bodies, into the great pit of Aldgate.
And there was nothing that science could do about it, except count the dead with a care demanded by modern statistics.
One-sixth of London's population perished.
The infection ebbed with the onset of autumn, but the trepidation hung around, for the number of the beast was 666.
And sure enough, up from the smoky regions of hell, in the first week of September 1666, came the diabolical fire.
In the early hours of Sunday, September 2nd, the Lord Mayor of London was woken from his sleep to be told that a fire had started in a baker's shop in Pudding Lane.
A woman might piss it out."
As he snored on, the flames reached the warehouses flanking the Thames between the Tower and London Bridge, brimful of tallow, pitch and brandy.
A monstrous fireball came roaring and sucking out of the narrow streets, feeding on the overhanging bays and gables.
In another hour, 200-300 houses had been swallowed by the flames.
John Evelyn, who'd been saying for years that overcrowded London was a disaster waiting to happen, took no joy in the fulfilment of his prophecy.
"Oh, the miserable and calamitous spectacle!
"God grant mine eyes that I never behold the like again, "who now saw 10,000 houses all in one flame.
"The noise and crackle and thunder of the impetuous flames.
"The shriek of women and children.
The fall of towers, houses and churches, like a hideous storm.
"London was, but is no more."
When the rain started, a week after the outbreak of the fire, allowing an early stocktaking, the scale of the devastation horrified even the pessimists.
13,200 houses had been destroyed, along with some of the most famous buildings of the city.
St Paul's Cathedral was in ruins.
The new leviathan, it seemed, had no fire insurance.
Still, there were those who were determined that London would rise as a Phoenix from its ashes and, like the reborn, rebuilt Rome, astonish the world.
This sort of thing had long been on the mind of Christopher Wren, mathematician, architect and prodigy of the Royal Society.
So when Roman antiquities were found in the debris around St Paul's, one of them a tablet bearing the Latin inscription, "Resurgam" - "I shall arise," Wren took the message to heart.
London had once been a great Roman city and now would outdo the ancients, with great piazzas, broad avenues, calculated to afford geometrically satisfying vistas and up to 50 new churches.
And at its heart would be a new St Paul's, a cathedral the like of which had never been seen in northern Europe.
He even built a giant wooden model to show the King and clergy just what they would be getting.
How could they not be awestruck by the huge dome that used the same technology as a microscope to flood the interior with light?
But there was a problem.
Wren had designed his cathedral as a Greek cross, sacrificing the traditional design of a Protestant church in favour of perfect acoustics and light.
You can almost hear the mystified, angry complaints of the reverends, "And where exactly is the choir supposed to go?
And how do we process up a nave which isn't there?"
Most of all, they said, "Call us old-fashioned, but this looks to us like a Catholic basilica.
"We'll be, if you pardon the phrase, damned, if we're going to let St Paul's turn into St Peter's."
When the King joined critics, telling him to go back to the drawing board, Wren's normally very dry eyes are said to have filled with tears.
He would have his chance to build his domed cathedral, but only when it was joined to a long nave, something like a traditional church.
The irony was that, for all his Roman enthusiasm, Wren believed he was building a truly Protestant church, but his timing was terrible.
Ever since the days of the Reformation, Britain had been victim to anti-Catholic fear.
And once again, in Charles's reign, it erupted.
Not all of it was misplaced - Charles was suspected of having secret Catholics in his government, and so he did.
He was also suspected of making secret treaties with the militantly Catholic Louis XIV of France, and so he had.
But there was worse... much worse.
The King's own brother, James, Duke of York, had actually converted to the Roman Church, and he made no secret of it.
With no children born to the King, the first Catholic ruler since Bloody Mary was an imminent prospect.
They were shivering in the Shires.
A century before, England's Queen Elizabeth had been threatened with Catholic assassination plots.
The Jesuit lurking in the shadows was a permanent fixture in the popular nightmare.
So when an ex-Jesuit called Titus Oates concocted a pack of lies about a plot to murder the King, invite a French invasion and create a Catholic state under James, he tripped the Guy Fawkes alert.
And when the magistrate investigating the charges was found mysteriously murdered on Primrose Hill, it seemed obvious that Oates knew what he was talking about.
It sent the jittery country right over the edge.
Anti-Catholic violence swept the country - riots, burnings, lynch mobs, kangaroo courts.
For some politicians, the country's ugly mood was a golden opportunity to press their favourite cause - James, Duke of York, should never be allowed to sit on the throne.
Anything to stop the cycle of religious wars from breaking out again.

It was an extraordinary crisis in the history of the British monarchy, for at stake were not only the lives of hundreds of those victimised by all the lies and hysteria, but the fate of the polity itself, because to concede exclusion was to accept that Parliament had the right to judge who was fit or unfit to occupy the throne.
And THAT was a concession Charles II was absolutely not about to make.
But Charles met the most serious crisis of his reign with his most powerful weapon - reason.
His brother would be allowed to succeed IF he agreed to be a private Catholic and not to lay a finger on the Church of England.
Riding the wave of paranoia, the newly elected Parliament, summoned to Oxford, turned him down.
They assumed that memory was on their side, that this Charles would remember the fate of his stubborn father, who had triggered a war when he, too, had been suspected of being soft on Catholicism.
But historical memory is a double-edged sword.
When the Commons filed into the Great Hall of Christchurch to hear what they THOUGHT would be the royal capitulation, they found themselves instead confronted by a leviathan in ermine.
"This is the King's will," he said, in effect.
"Take it or leave it."
Backed up by the House of Lords, Charles had left the Exclusionists in the Commons no alternative but to go to war.
And he was betting that the memory of the last round would be a deterrent.
He was right - the granite and marble tombs of the dead from Edgehill, Marston Moor and Worcester were still being carved.
That war had begun as a parliamentary protest and ended in Puritan crusade.
Who wanted that back?
Not the Exclusionists.
THEY blinked first.
James did get the keys to the kingdom when his brother died, in 1685, and he inherited a new parliament with a massively royalist majority, along with widespread public sympathy.
Within three years, though, he had squandered it all.
James never had any intention of hiding his faith.
His Catholicism wasn't just a private comfort to be celebrated away from the public gaze.
No, James was going to be a visible Catholic king, but he was playing a dangerous game.
When James tried to reverse anti-Catholic laws, the pillars of the Establishment - the country gentry in the Church of England - were horrified.
When the bishops complained, the King declared, "I shall find a way to do my business without you."
The protesting bishops were locked up in the Tower.
James's timing was disastrous, for he was doing all this when Louis XIV, the militantly Catholic King of France, was threatening Europe.
By January 1688, James had managed to alienate all his natural allies, and to turn himself into an even more dangerous version of his father, Charles I.
He was even filling the officer ranks of the Army with Irish Catholics.
The only consolation was that, at 52, he had no son.
The next in line to the throne was his daughter Mary, a staunch Protestant who'd married the Dutch Prince William of Orange, hero of the resistance to Louis XIV.
On June 10th 1688, all this changed.
James's wife, Mary of Modena, gave birth to a boy, who was duly baptised with Roman rites.
Now not only was the king Catholic, so was his dynasty.
What could be done?
A group of seven leading statesmen sent a message to Holland with an explosive request.
"Prince William," they asked, "would you mind invading Britain and saving us from a Catholic king?"
William wanted to save his country from Catholic despots all right, but the country HE had in mind, first, foremost and always, was the Dutch republic.
English politics were a sideshow, for William, to the main event - the great European war against Louis XIV.
There would be British troops in that war.
To make sure that they'd be fighting for him, not against him, exactly 100 years after the Spanish Armada failed to do the same thing, William set out to conquer Britain.
60,000 copies of William's manifesto blanketed England in an effort to present the planned invasion as a response to a spontaneous uprising against the Catholic tyrant.
It was so persuasive that he succeeded in making James seem the foreigner in his own land and the Dutchman the TRUE Brit.
The fate of the Armada was a sobering thought, so his Dutch invasion force made the Spanish one seem puny.
This time there were 600 vessels and up to 20,000 troops.
He landed at Torbay on November 5th - Guy Fawkes Day.
When he realised that this Protestant invasion was really going to oust him, James' courage failed him.
His resolution in melt-down, his nights haunted by the ghost of his beheaded daddy, he fled the kingdom.
William claimed that he'd come just to restore English liberties, but now he had Dutch soldiers in the streets.
And if he'd decided to be king after all, who was going to say otherwise?
In February 1689, William of Orange and Mary Stuart were proclaimed King and Queen of England.
But during the ceremony, something profoundly novel happened.
A declaration of rights was read out, listing the conditions under which the new monarchs would be allowed to sit on the throne.
Parliament had changed the job description of the ruler.
It wanted a chairman of the board.
Dutch William fitted that role to a T.
William III would fight HIS wars by asking, not demanding, funds from the elected representatives of the people.
And ruling together with Parliament, his government looked remarkably like a reasonable version of Oliver Cromwell's Protectorate.
History has called this a Glorious Revolution.
It was probably neither.
But afterwards, the British monarchy would never be the same again.
But the old monarchy had one last, desperate, play to make.
In March 1689, James landed in Ireland with 20,000 French troops.
The Catholic Irish flocked to their king.
Like the English, they had become pawns in someone else's chess game.
Outside Drogheda, two armies - two worlds - faced each other across the River Boyne.
One belonged to the old world of faith and fervour.
The other - Dutch and German professionals - were part of a modern war machine.
No prizes for guessing who won.
Nobody.
It is the patriotic duty of Irish men and Irish women to engage in that legitimate armed struggle.
Never...
CHEERING I would appeal to Unionists to engage fully in the search for a lasting peace.
I, too, am an Ulster man, and we don't need British ministers to rule us...
