For details of activities, call the history line on 08700 106060.
Don't look as fat as you should be.
You haven't already laid some eggs somewhere?
They're hard-working, dedicated and very efficient.
Did I say it was slippery?
They do it for love, not money.
Absolute beauty.
Four different creatures, four amateur naturalists, four inspiring stories.
I've just been bitten, for my pains.
Reptiles and amphibians are linked with dark, dank places, warts, witchcraft and sliminess.
Many people loathe or even hate them, but a few stalwart individuals love them.
Chris Davis' lifelong passion for reptiles has gradually taken over most of his time, and all of his Sussex garden.
It started when I was three.
My mother, with immense bravery, rescued me from a slowworm on our rockery.
I say immense bravery because although slowworms are totally harmless, she was convinced it was a deadly poisonous snake and chopped it into a million fragments with a spade.
Fortunately, we learned better very quickly.
And when I was 15 I saw my first sand lizard, and then the great love affair started.
Sand lizards are simply a gorgeous animal.
People who aren't familiar with them have been quite convinced this is some strange beast escaped from the Amazonian jungle.
They are out of this world.
In 1999, Chris began to build a sand-lizard empire in his back garden.
The object of this is simply to keep these animals as healthy as possible, with a view to their breeding.
Unfortunately, sand lizards, as far as their young are concerned, are cannibalistic.
They don't differentiate between a small moving insect and a small moving hatchling lizard, they're both food.
Chris needs to move pregnant or gravid females to a safer enclosure, but first he has to catch them.
Of course, one of the problems is trying to make sure I don't tread on any other lizards in the process.
She's very close to egg-laying, so she does need to be caught.
And...a spectacular miss!
Now, can we see anyone else?
Lovely young male clambering in the heather, but I'm not looking for a male, I'm looking for a gravid female.
There's a young female down here, and obviously gravid, quite plump...
She's not quite ready to lay yet.
She will be laying, probably, if this weather continues, within the next week, I think, yes.
I suddenly saw her, and this is a much bigger female, when you look at the bulk.
Even though it's a larger animal, you can see she's really massive, and she's very close to laying eggs.
Again, rather a beautiful animal, they're both beautiful animals.
I'll take these down to the egg-laying, Viv, and I've just been bitten, for my pains.
Chris' sand-lizard sanctuary was desperately needed.
The species was in dire straits.
People began to notice that they weren't seeing sand lizards in the same numbers as when they were children.
Their two specialist areas of habitat, which were dry lowland heath and coastal dunes, were historically seen as being completely valueless.
One of the biggest dune complexes that used to support sand lizards is now called Liverpool.
Conversely, one of the biggest lowland heath systems which used to support sand lizards is now called Bournemouth.
By the mid 1970s, only three populations survived in England, and they have disappeared from Wales.
Chris' pregnant females are part of a plan to reverse the decline.
The young will then be reared by me for a short while.
Release will take place, back end of August, early September, by which time they'll be equivalent in size to one-year-old wild animals, which gives them a real kick-start in life.
Chris has reintroduced his home-grown sand lizards onto several local heaths.
To measure their survival, he checks the release sites.
Finding nine-inch-long lizards in a dense hectare of heathland is never easy, and they'll melt away at sudden movements.
But at least they're not bothered by noise.
You can talk as much as you like, you can walk along singing songs if you felt like it, the lizards wouldn't care less.
They're not great music critics, in any event.
Probably the best one of the lot was two years after we'd done our first introduction to Wales, and I was looking around the release area and I saw a hatchling sand lizard.
Now, this was a magical moment, firstly because this was the first of the lizards to breed in the wild, or the first product, for 50 years.
And secondly, because I knew I myself had bred all of their parents, so the sense of accomplishment and pride was absolutely enormous.
Mark for occasion.
Truly magnificent beautiful animal.
Most nature lovers seeing their first male sand lizard in particular in full breeding colours is a memory that stays in their mind for ever.
These wonderful green flanks with the silver lines down the back, it makes for an incredibly exotic-looking animal.
Is the population doing well?
It's that simple, if we see a population deteriorating we know there has to be a cause, and we look for that cause.
The surveys show that sand lizards are thriving.
For Chris, it's fantastic to see all his hard work pay off.

At long last there's this animal in such serious difficulty which we're putting back into the countryside, and to see it there and thriving, you really feel as if you're putting something back into the world.
Chris' lifelong passion has helped turn things around for sand lizards.
But other enthusiasts come to their favourite reptiles and amphibians much later in life.
It was only after retiring that Richard and Phil King were able to fully indulge their particular passion.
It all started years ago with a small pond at their previous suburban home.
Minute, isn't it?
Newts suddenly appeared in it, so we spent a lot of time watching them and became quite fascinated.
This was just the start of their passion for newts.
Richard and Phil moved to Herefordshire.
They put ordinary small garden ponds behind them.
Now, they have the space to create something really grand.
We wanted bigger ponds, we had to get planning permission, and we had to get contractors in, so it was a bigger exercise than the original little pond in the home garden.
18 months after we dug these ponds we were doing some weeding round our patio beside the house, and suddenly discovered a large newt creature we hadn't seen before.
What I noticed particularly that first time was it has yellow-and-black striped toes, just like having yellow and black stripy socks on.
I think many tales of dragons in the past were probably about great crested newts.
The great crested newt is Britain's largest and most threatened newt.
To keep a protective eye on their pond's new residents, Richard and Phil count the tadpoles and eggs.
They lay them on underwater plants, so what we're looking for is the leaves of underwater plants that have been folded over, and the egg is caught inside.
Earlier in the year we'd find a lot more, and these leaves would be under water.
Oh, have you got one?
On water parsnip?
Let's have a look...
It's empty!
Oh, no, there it is, it's a tiny little... just hatching.
There we are, he's gone back.
I like the way we call them "him" all the time!
Oh, here's a folded leaf.
Let's see what's in there.
It's white and it's quite large, that's a great crested newt egg.
Oh, look, oh, we've got a big one!
That's three great crested newt larvae.
Whoops!
It's great to know the newts are breeding, but to check on the adults calls for a night shift.
It's not really dark enough yet, but we'll have a look and see what we can find in the ponds.
This is where we normally find them, down here.
Have to be a bit careful of the mud, it's really slippery after the rain.
All very quiet at the moment.
Come on, where are you?
They come out at night, they're very inactive in the day, and come out in the evening for finding food and finding mates and so on.
This is the time when they're most easily seen in the pond usually.
We have seen 18 in this pond.
We've got one!
You can see those yellow bands on the feet very clearly there.
Actually, that one's a male as well.
(Where, where?)
The stripy toes.
So that's number five to record along with the two tadpoles.
So what are we, about ten o'clock, is it?
I think that's pretty good for this time of year.
Did I say it was slippery?
From small beginnings with one small pond, Richard and Phil have really branched out.
But their zeal for helping newts hasn't stopped there.
They now have the whole county of Herefordshire in their sights.
In Herefordshire, there have been a lot of ponds and a lot of them have newts, they won't be big populations, and a lot of the ponds could be in much better condition.
And so we've identified five ponds for restoration.
One of them is at this local cider orchard.
Richard and Phil join the County Pond Officer, Darrell Hardy, to assess the work that needs doing.
The idea is to, as well as extend it, take out most of that bulrush and at the same time de-silt it.
Five ponds now, but this is just the beginning.
Richard and Phil have high hopes for the future.
Ponds have been through a bad patch, but I think that hopefully they're coming out the other side.
This tiny dinosaur is a barometer of pond life.
Slimy, odd-looking and rarely seen by day, great crested newts are a curious obsession.
Richard and Phil love them.
One of our British reptiles is even harder to find, and to love.
In fact it's our most feared wild animal.
Learning to love this elusive creature made one woman an expert.
Sylvia Sheldon is 70 years old.
She lives in a cottage deep in the Wyre forest in Worcestershire.
It's extremely remote, but it's the perfect spot from which to keep an eye on some of her neighbours.
I photographed my first adder in...
I think it was 1978.
SHUTTER CLICKS I was wary when I first started photographing them, but then realised that they were very timid.
Lexy might be around somewhere.
My favourite adder is a female I call Lexy.
I first photographed her as a juvenile eight years ago when she matured at five.
I witnessed her first mating, and followed her progress through the summer.
This is her spot.
If we're going to see her, she'll be in here.
Wait a minute, I can see that she wants to dive, really...
That was good, though, I'm sorry if you didn't... !
Sylvia knows more about the adders of the Wyre Forest than anybody, so what does it take to study them?
They can't hear airborne noises but they're aware of ground vibrations.

They'll pick up your movement very quickly, so one has to walk stealthily, usually downwind of them, because they pick up your scent very easily, and you know when an adder has detected you scent-wise because their tongue flickers in and out, and they quickly disappear into the vegetation.
This is no idle hobby for Sylvia.
In the early '80s a discovery she made rocked the science world, and made her a well-respected adder expert.
I noticed all the head patterns were different.
I thought, "I'm bound to find two adders with identical head markings," but I never have.
This was pioneering work.
Sylvia was the first person to identify adders from their individual head patterns.
The most distinctive head patterns are what I call horse-shaped, a horse looking left or a horse looking right, so it's a silhouette of a horse.
You also get rounded ones and pointed ones.
It became of more interest when I knew I was looking at individuals, rather than just another adder.
I was seeing who was mating with who, which female gave birth to which babies, monitor babies through to maturity.
Being able to study the snakes as individuals fired Sylvia's interest in the adders even more.
So Sylvia started doing her own surveys.
In 1990 she gained a diminutive but determined assistant.
Alonsa, my grandson, was only five or six years old when he used to come out with me.
And although he was a little bit impulsive and I used to try and get him to stay behind me, he wanted to be in front.
Over the years he's become very good at spotting adders, and as he's got bigger and taller he can see them better than I can now.
She gave me a camera when I was ten, I photographed them and loved it, they're a creature that got a lot of bad press, and when people say, "Oh, it's a snake!"
You can say, "They're not that bad", and, yeah, it's different, I enjoy that.
Oh, look, Alonsa, there's a sloughed skin.
Sloughing is when a snake sheds its skin.
Because Sylvia knows them so well, she knows who this male is without even seeing the actual snake.
I think he must be nine or ten years old now, yeah.
Once the females emerge from hibernation, the males start getting distinctly frisky.
They vie for dominance in a spectacular dance that Alonsa is lucky to have witnessed.
These two males came out of the blue and started right in front of me dancing, it was fantastic, the dominant male pushing the smaller male to the floor.
And it can last two or three minutes, and it is very exciting.
They get as high as they can off the ground to push the other male down to the floor, and once that male becomes subservient, he slinks off and the dominant male then goes to his female to breed.
I still get a thrill every time I see an adder.
It's a thrill, it's great to see them, especially because they are declining in numbers.
We had over 300 when we started doing surveys in the late '80s, and we're now down to 100 adders.
I feel you've got to appreciate it while it lasts in case the time comes when they become extinct.
Sylvia noticed that some types of forestry work were actively damaging to the adders.
Because adders cannot burrow, they use existing holes.
If the machinery goes over those holes and compacts the ground they cannot get out, so they are basically buried alive, suffocated.
Sylvia's dedicated work is having a positive effect.
Because of her expertise, she's now consulted about forestry work before it happens, and adder numbers seem to be on the way back up.
The future for adders looked dire a few years ago... ..but I think over the past few years their requirements are being taken into account.
THEY CHAT And her influence doesn't stop there.
Alonsa has been inspired by her passion and now helps with the survey work and report-writing.
I'm very pleased that he's become as fascinated by the adders as I am, because it means he'll follow on my studies, I hope.
Sylvia's love for adders has grown over the years, and now Alonsa is hooked too.
Having an animal on your doorstep means that you are perfectly positioned to study and protect it.
Sometimes just stumbling across a local creature can be the start of something big.
It was on a dark and damp misty marsh that Richard Irvine made a discovery that would change his life.

You might wonder why I was wandering around at night in the dark, but that's what it is, probably out with the dog and hearing this noise, a sort of "barrup"-type noise, it's like crickets in the jungle.
It's not always easy to find out where the noise is coming from.
Richard has been living in Anthorn on the Solway Firth for 34 years.
He traded in a job in the city to become a farmer.
His sheep graze on the salt marsh at the edge of the estuary.
The strange noises he heard at night made it obvious there was something else living here too.
I just went to investigate it eventually.
I was totally surprised when I found out, because as you know when you walk up to a toad it keeps quiet, doesn't it?
You see a toad there, and it's not making the noise when you see it, so it's quite surprising to find a little toad like this making such a big noise.
Richard called English Nature, who told him that they were natterjack toads, Britain's rarest amphibian.
It was realised that the population was very small, probably 20 or 30 toads, so the population was struggling.
Richard became fascinated by them.
This is a beauty, he's got a fantastic stripe right down his back, lots of warts, and lots of different colours of brown and green and yellows.
The males also have little suction pads on the inside of their fingers at the front, which is where they hold onto the females.
They're all beauties, but this one especially.

Toads need somewhere to breed, that is a pond which will hold water long enough so they have time to turn into toadlets, and it was decided to actually physically change and improve their environment by digging new ponds.
The main string of ponds is a series of seven or eight which runs down slowly, and the water now cascades from one pond down to the others.
We're not trying to farm the natterjacks, but we are trying to make sure that some at least do survive.
Richard's sheep are unwittingly helping the plan to save the toads.

The best way to manage the surrounding habitat is grazing it, so we get a tight short sward, like a lawn, and then they can travel, because they move up to two kilometres from the breeding pond during the winter to hibernate.
Spawn strings and tadpoles show that the toads are successfully breeding.
But not always in the right place.
This is what we call a suicide pond, because the water in here will evaporate in about a week if it doesn't continue to rain.
And there are actually three strings in here, which you can just make out.
They're probably about three days old.
You can see they're starting to change from round to oval and they're turning into taddies, so there will be tadpoles in here.
We'll probably have to let these hatch out into taddies now, then catch the taddies and move them somewhere else.
Not all the spawn will go on to develop into toads, but Richard knows that his adult population is doing well.
Oh, there you are, four here...four little ones.
They don't start breeding until they're three years old, so these are juveniles.
There's another one, chubby little fellow, he must be doing rather well.
I'll just put this down there once we make sure that we're not going to squash anyone.
By day the toads hide away, but at night they really come into their own.
It's the males that make the noise, they compete for the females, just go down there and sing away and the girls come along and choose the one they like.
You can see their little white heads.
Their bodies are floating in the water, and there's one there and one there.

25 years ago, the population was down to about 20 adults, so when a toad called it was more or less an individual toad that you were hearing, whereas now we've got a complete chorus of probably a couple of hundred toads down here.
Counting toads at night is quite difficult, and of course they hide as soon as they hear you coming.
They tend to dive down to the bottom, making it very difficult.
We know we don't get them all, but it gives us a rough idea.
Nice one there.
You can certainly see the gold stripe right down his back beautifully, can't you?
It's a fairly slow job, and you just have to go around and shine a torch on them and hope you don't count the same one more than once.
18 toads on this side of the pond, probably similar numbers the other side.
Seven or eight ponds similar to this.
Could be a colossal number of toads, couldn't there?
Richard's care of the natterjacks has spawned a recovery in his toad population.
The best thing is that I'm here and they're here, and I'm lucky enough to be able to look after them.
From idle curiosity about a strange noise, the toads have become an important part of Richard's life.
They'd probably be very boring to everybody else, but I quite like them, probably just because they're on the doorstep and we don't have to go very far to be entertained.
It's through the work of Richard and hundreds of other people like him that we know so much about Britain's scaly and slimy creatures.
Far from loathsome, these people find reptiles and amphibians highly lovable.
It's only by knowing what we've got, where it is and how it's doing that we can spot trends and changes in British wildlife... ..and know when to step in and help.
It would be an impossible task without the work of our British wild army.

Welcome to Countryfile.
The New Forest National Park lies mainly in south-west Hampshire.
When it was designated a national park, in 2005, it was the first to be created for more than 50 years.
But there's disquiet in the normally tranquil air, because some local residents and park users are unhappy about controversial plans to safeguard its future.
Also on Countryfile today, the village churches that are reinventing themselves to avoid closure.

What we're going to do is create a community shop in an area behind the screen at the back there, we're going to remove all the pews and put in comfortable seating and we're going to re-order the choir area as a primary worship space.
We're back in Bavaria with the Wildwood Trust on the hunt for a female beaver to bring home.
If it's a male, we'll leave it here and go with him to the other place.
And Miriam risks life and limb to celebrate a late New Year's Eve.
The fire's really taking off now and still the Clavie Crew are getting really close!
For nearly 1,000 years, ever since William came here and conquered, the New Forest has been managed in some form or other.
King William turned the land into a hunting ground and cleared away whole villages to do so.
In the 20th century, with people more mobile, it became a tourist destination and was recognised as an internationally significant habitat for wildlife.
In the 21st century, to give it extra protection, it's been made a national park.
But a few months ago, the Park Authority published a blueprint for the next 20 years, looking at the big issues facing the forest.

A useful document, you might think, but some people who live and work around here are claiming that the Authority is behaving like a modern-day William the Conqueror and threatening the way of life in the New Forest.
It seems that the park plan has been drawn up by people that know nothing about horses, certainly not from a horse-rider's perspective.
The national park would rather we just stuck to selling our wine, and for us, that's no longer economically viable.
A lot of people think you've been rather heavy handed.
That's unfortunate, and I'm very concerned about the level of anxiety some of our documents have created.
It can't be heavy handed, because it's only a draft plan.
We're putting forward ideas, and they emerged from a very long and quite in-depth focus group exercise.
We've now put forward the proposals for consultation.
Ponies and horses are inseparably linked with the New Forest.
Though many of the animals roam free, they all have owners, and riding for pleasure is very popular here.
If you want to keep horses, as they term it, "in a recreational manner", as most people do...
..You'll need a minimum of one hectare per head - that's 2.47 acres, for those who still work in old money.
They've said there'll be no rugging allowed, as we have on this girl, to keep the worst of the weather off, and no feeding - they'll be allowed only the grass growing in the fields.
There could be a welfare issue for many horses if they can't wear rugs and have supplemental feeding.
And giving one New Forest pony 2.5 acres could cause problems - there'd be too much grass for most of the year, and you'd end up with a disease called laminitis, which can be fatal.
I'm concerned about the number of people upset by the proposals for recreational horse-keeping.
I've talked to a lot of them and they fear for their livelihoods.
The plan doesn't propose anything that they need to worry about.

Right now, though, they are very worried that unless the proposals are relaxed, there'll be too many horses and ponies for the available land, and that many may have to be got rid of - and that could mean the knackers.
As well as being a rich natural habitat, the New Forest is also home to 34,000 people living in small communities, and 9,000 of them actually work in the forest in 600 different enterprises.
Now, the report says it wants to develop a sustainable local economy, so what do businesses think of it?
The draft policies have not been welcome.
They'd seek to restrict expansion of existing businesses and curtail the activities of a number of others.
They've created a number of zones where they would wish to put certain types of use, and relocate existing businesses, which would not be acceptable to the local business community.
75% of New Forest businesses employ less than four people.
And you think these plans are discouraging business rather than encouraging it.
If they were implemented in their current form, they would do more than discourage business - they would actually stultify a number of business initiatives.
They would ensure that people did not wish to expand their current operations and they'd deter people from starting up.
At this shop at his vineyard in the forest, Paul Girling sells wine he produces, but he's running into problems with the National Park Authority.
We sell a number of different products here.
Principally, what we do is we make English wine.
We also sell a lot of other local produce under the New Forest marque, which the National Park Authority don't seem to be too keen on us doing.
They would like it to be solely products which are actually produced on site here, and the economic reality of that is simply a situation where our business becomes unviable.
Is the national park more interested in ecology than economics?
The right way forward is to work as closely as we can with the people of the forest and those who visit the forest.
Richard Lemon took over the job of implementing the plan after it had been written, and he's got quite a job on his hands now convincing a lot of people here that it is needed and that it's right.

Fresh investigations into the welfare of pigs both in this country and on the Continent are about to hit the media spotlight as Jamie Oliver and other celebrity chefs turn their attention from chicken to pig rearing.
And for an industry which is just starting to recover after a few disastrous years which have seen many farmers forced out of business, could this be the final nail in the coffin?
The last decade has been one of the worst periods in the history of British pig farming.
Half of our pig farmers have gone out of business, largely as a result of the escalating cost of feed and having to compete with much cheaper imports from the Continent.
But the current financial crisis may bring a reprieve for pig farming.
Grain prices which were sky-high are much lower because fuel prices are lower, and a weak pound means it's not cheaper for retailers to import pork.
But the pig industry is about to come under intense media scrutiny, and some of the methods used to rear pigs could have serious repercussions for the future of pig farming.
TV chefs are planning to focus their attention on the welfare issues surrounding intensive pig farming.
If the public reacts to their findings in the same way as they did to chickens that are intensively reared, it could have a drastic effect on sales of pork.
For Staffordshire farmer Rob Mercer, the last 12 months have been a struggle.
He breeds free-range, intensive and outdoor-bred pigs.
Many pig farms went out of business last year.
Hopefully, we can go forward and be sustainable.
We lost money last year on the pigs we sold on.
Up to sort of £20, £25 per pig.
Despite the economic situation, Rob has maintained a good standard of pig welfare.
His pigs have straw, their tails aren't docked and on this farm, they have access to the outdoors.
For this, the shopper pays about two pence extra at the supermarket.
British consumers don't make that choice in the supermarket or the shop where they buy meat.
If they go for the cheapest, if they go for imports with poorer quality welfare, then British pig farmers will be pushed out.
The Netherlands is one of the major importers of pork to the UK.
Over 90% of the pigs farmed here are intensively reared, compared to fewer than 60% in the UK.
This is a family-run farm in the east of the Netherlands.
Andre Wikkerink has been farming here since 1994.
He sells around 5,000 pigs a year.
There's no straw in this intensive unit, and his pigs have their tails docked.
Despite this, he's perfectly happy for us to show his farming methods.
At the moment, I think this is the best way for me to rear pigs.
It's the most welfare-friendly way that's provided by the government and our financial backers.
But it's our customers who decide, in the end, what we produce.
If large groups of consumers are prepared to pay much more for pork, many pig farmers in the Netherlands will be prepared to provide straw for their pigs.
Along with tail-docking and no straw, Andre has sow stalls on his farm.
Sows are confined to metal stalls for up to five days after insemination.
The stalls are legal in the Netherlands but have been banned in the UK on cruelty grounds.
If Andre's farm was in the UK, it would have been closed down.
Compassion in World Farming wants to draw attention to this practice.
Why do they believe it matters?
There are many things we would like to see changed in the Netherlands.

At least all piglets, all pigs, should have straw to live on, to give them bedding to lay on, more comfort to lay on, and to play with, to root, because that gives them activity and brings an end to their boring existence.
We have seen a lot of mutilations in the Netherlands.
All young male piglets are being castrated.
These practices should end and, of course, the pigs should be given more space to live.
But poor animal welfare isn't just an issue for pig farmers in the Netherlands.
Compassion in World Farming filmed in six European countries.
Investigators visited 60 farms and we have witnesses to poor welfare practices in the UK as well.
In the British pig industry, we've got the highest welfare standards in the world, and certainly in comparison with some of our competitors on the Continent, where standards aren't the same.
We're doing all we can to publicise our own high welfare standards.
But we do dock the tails of pigs in this country and we castrate them.
Surely there are welfare concerns there.
92% of all the pigs in the UK go through farm assurance schemes and it's illegal to castrate pigs for farm assurance.
But some still are castrated on some farms.

Tail docking is only on the advice of a veterinary surgeon where there's a concern that you might get a problem with tail-biting, so, again, it's on the advice of a veterinarian that you'd do that and it would done by a trained stockman with the tail being cauterised.
But do you not concede that if the public were to see some of these farms, it would put them off buying British pork or bacon?
Um...certainly, you know, some people would have concerns with some systems, but that is what we offer in this country - consumer choice.
So we've got, you know, free-range pigs, outdoor pigs, indoor pigs straw-finished, so we've got a complete variety.
If we lose the British pig farmer, we're only going to have one common denominator, which is the Continental pig systems where sows are kept in stalls, all the pigs are castrated.
So what we offer the consumer here is choice.
According to the RSPCA, most people are pig-ignorant, not knowing the difference between outdoor bred and free range.
Labelling has a lot to do with the confusion facing British shoppers.
I bought five 250g packs of bacon.
This one from ASDA and this one from Tesco were produced in Holland.
They cost the same at £2.38.
This bacon here I bought in Waitrose.
It's British bacon, and Waitrose has become the first supermarket to stock only British bacon, but it's a bit more expensive at £2.49, so 11p more.

It was the cheapest at £1.29, but there's nothing on the label to tell me where it was produced or how it was produced, and that's one of the problems for British consumers - not enough information on the label to give them a clear indication of what they're actually buying.
40% of your business, Rob, is outdoor-bred pork.
And these pigs are outdoor-bred, but they're inside.
These pigs all come from breeding stock which have been outside all their lives.
These pigs, as well, have the first half of their life, up until about 11 weeks old, in outdoor kennels.
If I saw "outdoor bred" on a packet of bacon, I would think that meant those pigs lived outdoors.
There is work being done at the moment to clarify what is outdoor bred, what is free range.
The other 40% of our pigs we produce are actually free range, and they're out in the field all the way until they're ready to go for slaughter.
The forthcoming media spotlight on the pig industry could benefit British farmers like Rob.
Once we learn of the harsh facts of pig production, we may look favourably on paying extra to buy British pork.
70% of the pig meat that's imported from the Continent comes from pigs it would be illegal to produce here.
I think that's something the consumer would want to know.
You cannot compare what we do in welfare terms with the Continent.
I think our standards will speak for themselves, definitely.
January marks the end of the breeding season for seals.
But not all of the pups are going to survive.
Some will succumb to injury or separation from their mother.
Luckily, there's a place in Cornwall which rescues seals in distress.
Our video diary this week comes from Claire McGowan, who's a care assistant there.
This is one of my favourite places to come and see seals.
It's an ideal location for them here, because hardly any public can get down to them, so they're pretty much undisturbed.
I'm one of the lucky ones, I get to work with seals and sea lions every day.
My name's Claire McGowan, I'm an animal care assistant at the National Seal Sanctuary.
I was at university, studying marine biology, and for my third year, I studied seals, at Scarborough Sea Life Centre.
Just by working with the common seals there, I got the passion for seals and marine life, really.
At the seal sanctuary, we have a number of seals and sea lions.
We have grey seals and common seals, which you would natively find here around the UK.
We also have a hooded seal, two very cheeky fur seals, and we have two species of sea lion, we have a Californian sea lion and a Patagonian sea lion as well.
The reason why I love seals so much, I think it's cos they're all just... they're just so different.
Each and every one of them has a different personality.
They're so cheeky, and they're so mischievous, but yet they're so loving as well.
When a seal pup comes to us here at the sanctuary, we generally give it a full clinical assessment to start.
It's only when they're fit, healthy, feeding well for themselves, they've come off all their treatment, that they'll finish their stage in the hospital and make their way down to the pools outside.
OK, so we're here in the convalescence pool.
This is the really big pool, where the seal pups come for the final stage of their rehab.
The way we feed this pool is quite unique.
We don't come in with the buckets of fish, we hide behind the pillars, just behind me, and we throw all the fish into the centre of the pool.
The reason why we do this is so the young pups learn to associate that fish comes in the water and not from us humans.
Last year, we actually had a seal pup come in to us in April, which is very unusual, but what was more unusual was this seal was only just born.
She was only a couple of days old.
April is still with us today, but sadly it took her a little while to get the hang of eating her fish.
So she has been with us a little bit longer than we hoped.
We're hoping to release her soon, she's up to her release weight now.
We're gonna head down to the beach to assess it, see whether it's ideal conditions for a release today.
Sadly, as I expected, the weather is truly awful.
It's just so windy, if we release them today, they wouldn't stand a chance getting past any of those waves.
We don't want them to be bashed against the rocks.
It looks as though it'll be another couple of days at the sanctuary, lots of fish, and hopefully in the next week or so, if the weather improves, we can release them then.
This is all that's left of Beaulieu Abbey in the New Forest.
When Henry VIII dissolved the monasteries, he handed the Abbey and all its lands to the ancestors of the present owner, Lord Montagu.
But there's one thing that the King should have held on to for himself.
And it's this.
The six mile-long Beaulieu river.
And as a result of that oversight all those years ago, any craft anchoring here, in one of the top sailing areas of the country, has to pay a fee to the Montagu estate, not the Crown.
So is this the only private river in the country, then?
That's what makes it such a special place.
Has it ever been challenged?
It was challenged back in the '20s by a yachtsman.
The Board of Trade went over the original documents.
They upheld the decision, found in Lord Montagu's favour.
And so he actually owns the rights to the river bed as well.
How much does it cost to drop anchor here?
In the lower reaches of the river, it's £5 for up to 24 hours.
And how many boats might you get on a busy day?
On a busy Saturday, you might have 25, 30, 40 boats at anchor.
And this small river has played a big part in naval history.
The Mulberry Harbour, used on the Normandy beaches during the Second World War, sailed from the Beaulieu.
And in the 18th century, some of the ships that served at Trafalgar were constructed in the boatyard at Buckler's Hard.
And I think Lord Nelson's favourite warship was built right here, wasn't it?
In that dock there, the Agamemnon, which took part in the Battle of Trafalgar.
And also, two other ships that were in the Battle of Trafalgar were built here, the Euryalus and the Swiftsure.
So this was a big naval shipyard?
The oak would have come from the forest?
Yes, one reason for the shipyards here was that there was plenty of oak from the forest, some from the Beaulieu estate, but a lot from the New Forest as well.
Buckler's Hard is a rather unusual name for a village.
Originally, it was just a tiny hamlet, one or two cottages, on the banks of the Beaulieu river, where a family called Buckle lived.
And the "hard" refers to the gravel beds at the riverbank, which made it a good landing place for boats.
It's a bit of a remote place, even when all the shipbuilding was going on, isn't it?
Were there any plans for it to be bigger?
Oh, yes, indeed.
In the 1720s, John, Second Duke of Montagu, had a grand plan.
He was going to build a big town here, and call it Montagu Town.
You can see the streets are wide...
He was quite far-thinking, it was going to be a model place, with fountains, and really attractive.
And where was the money going to come from for that big town?
He was going to send an expedition to the West Indies, grow sugar and bring it back through Montagu Town and make a lot of money.
But, unfortunately, the French got to St Lucia first.
And so the expedition came back empty handed, and he actually lost a lot of money.
And that was the end of Montagu Town.
It reverted to its name of Buckler's Hard.
Tonight, as any Scot will tell you, is Burns Night.
Celebrations and Scotch whisky will be in full flow, as people fondly remember the Ploughman Poet Robert Burns, on the 250th anniversary of his birth.
A while ago, I was in his home county of Ayrshire.
Scotland's national poet, Robert Burns, has a reputation that stretches way beyond his homeland.
Poems such as My Love Is Like A Red, Red Rose are known throughout the world.
And he wrote much of his best work here in Ayrshire.
The man who became known as the Ploughman Poet was born in this cottage in Alloway on 25th January, 1759.
It had been built by his father, who was a gardener on a nearby estate.
So what would this room have been?
We're in a two-room, traditional Scottish cottage.
An area to cook, also an area where they slept as well.
And we think this box bed was where Robert Burns, the poet, was born, on a cold January day in 1759.
He wrote his first poem, a love song to a local girl, when he was 15.
Ten years later, he was farming a few miles away at Mossgiel, and he produced so many poems that he put them together in book form.
He wrote them in an attic in this house.
Robert Burns was a poet by night and a farmer by day.
One afternoon he was out here in this very field in November 1785.
He came across a wee mouse.

He was out ploughing and unfortunately his heavy plough destroyed the nest that the mouse had built so carefully and he identified the catastrophe that had happened to the mouse with his own hard life that he was enduring at that time.
He turned that experience into one of his best-loved poems.
"Wee, sleekit, cowran, tim'rous beastie "O, what panic's in thy breastie "Thou need na start awa sae hasty Wi' bickering brattle "I wad be laith to rin an' chase thee, "Wi' murd'ring pattle."
And here from 1786 is a first edition of Burns' first ever book.
A great local reaction.
Burns sold out almost overnight and became a household name in the west of Scotland.
Hot on the heels of the Kilmarnock edition came a much fatter edition, published in Edinburgh the following year.
He was persuaded to go to Edinburgh to frequent the salons of the eminent, the literati, and he became a big name very quickly.
Tam O'Shanter is one of his best known, and some would say greatest, poems and for it he drew heavily on his childhood haunts in Alloway.
It tells the story of the accidental encounter between our drunken hero, Tam O'Shanter, and a coven of unfriendly witches and the devil who are partying in the grounds of this ruined kirk.

"A winnock-bunker in the east "There sat auld Nick in shape o' beast "A towzie tyke, black, grim, and large "To gie them music was his charge "He screw'd the pipes and gart them skirl "Till roof and rafters a' did dirl."
Now, the witches spot Tam on his trusty steed Meg and give chase.
But he rides across this bridge, the Brigadoon, and evades capture because witches can't cross running water.

"Now, do thy speedy-utmost, Meg "And win the key-stone o' the brig "There, at them thou thy tail may toss "A running stream they dare na cross "But ere the keystane she could make "The fient a tail she had to shake!"
So famous did the poem become that Tam O'Shanter gave his name to a Scottish beret.
Robert Burns died at the age of 37, and five years later, his friends all gathered here at the cottage where he was born to celebrate his life and his work.
It was a forerunner of the Burns suppers that are now held all over the world every year on his birthday.
Still to come on Countryfile, we return to Bavaria in search of a female beaver who'll make her home in Kent and Miriam celebrates a fiery late New Year in Scotland.
There's a growing need for urgent repairs to thousands of historic churches in England but, as congregations decline, so does the ability to pay for those repairs.
But a recent policy change by the Church of England allows the space inside churches to be shared with the local community, saving many of them from closure.
St Leonard's Church in the little village of Yarpole, just north-west of Hereford.
It's a good example of the problems faced by the Church of England which has around 28,000 churches on its books.
Many of them just aren't suited to the needs of today's congregations.
It is a fabulous, well-maintained, beautiful building bang in the centre of its community.
We have for many years been using it for community purposes as well as for worship.

But it has some huge practical problems, in that the seating is hopelessly uncomfortable, it's immoveable, and the heating system is inadequate and has now broken down, and so we need to do a massive fit-for-purpose modernisation.
Until quite recently, the Church of England had a pretty inflexible, all-or-nothing approach to the problems faced by St Leonard's.
Churches had to be used purely for worship.
If the upkeep became too much for the local congregation, the door would be locked and that would be that.
In some cases, churches were sold on for another use, such as housing, or demolished, but now all that's changed.

The Church has recognised that we have to change the use of our buildings and recently what they've actually done is change the legislation that governs the use of church buildings so it's now perfectly legally possible to lease part of a building to another organisation and not make the whole church redundant.
So that's opened up huge possibilities for people.
What we're going to do in this building is to create a community shop in an area behind the screen at the back.
We're going to remove all the pews and put in comfortable seating.
We're going to create a new insulated floor with an under-floor heating system and we'll re-order this choir area as a primary worship space.
Above the shop we're going to create a gallery so that we don't lose any space in the building and that will be additional worship space and also a place for a cafe and other recreational events.
The new legislation will allow Yarpole's community shop to move into the back of the church, and that suits both of them.
We only have temporary planning permission to be here, so we've got to move some time this year and we've been looking around for some while for suitable places to put a new building.
At the same time, it turned out that the church was looking for grant aid to make itself rather more community useful.
So it was a real community effort, people just not wanting to lose their shop and everything that brings with it and putting it in the church?
The Government has also joined what amounts to a quiet revolution in the use of church buildings.
St Peter's in the village of Peterchurch is being converted for use as a local, Government-run community and children's centre, serving the Golden Valley area.
Gosh, it really is a building site!
What prompted you to do this?
Well, firstly, I have always thought that churches ought to be used for things for the community other than worship.

We will still be worshipping in here, but we also were approached by the local authority and have been given £255,000 from the Department of Children, Schools and Families and also we're hoping for funding from Advantage West Midlands.
So what is it going to be when finished?
It'll be a community centre as well as a place of worship.
What that means practically speaking is the walls will be lime-washed so it'll be much lighter in here.
We'll have better lighting than we have now.
We'll have kitchen facilities here, a mezzanine up there with a library in the bell-ringing chamber.
What's going on in here at the moment?

The archaeologists are in here because it is a very, very old church and we need to make sure there's nothing of real significance, archeologically, in here, so we're looking at the whole of the nave area and into the vestry.
And um...
What are those bones?
I suspect they were uncovered by the Victorians, cos there was a Victorian restoration in here.
And those bones were found under the flooring that was in here and, of course, we will hold a little service and re-bury them once the work has been done.
I think it's recognised very much from the top down, from God himself downwards, that we have to use these buildings and protect them just as they were meant to be done years ago.
If this place is going to be here in the next 500 years, then we have a responsibility to do something now.
The public money available for church upkeep falls far short of the sums required and private charities struggle to fill the gap.
We've had major restoration work done in the Victorian era and often after the Second World War, so a lot of things are starting to deteriorate very badly.
Heating and lighting is often extremely unsafe, roofs are often leaking, things are pretty desperate.
How important do you think churches are to communities today, particularly rural ones?
Because the size of congregations would suggest not very.
They're extremely important, especially for rural communities.
When you live in somewhere like the Golden Valley, there aren't many focal points there for the community.
The local church is often the only place left.
Can we keep our churches going?

We definitely can and we can see by the use of the church for the community in a wider sense rather than the narrow sense that has been for a few hundred years, we can definitely keep them going and they will thrive.
St Andrew's Church at Adforton near Leominster pioneered community use several years ago and has shown it works.
It serves as a venue for everything from parish meetings to parties and pantos.
It brought in a huge number of people that otherwise would not come into the building.
From being used only two Sundays a month, it's now used at least two or three times a week.

It seems as if there's a real commitment here to maintain and enhance the role of these buildings in the lives of the local communities which, if successful, could lead to a significant expansion of the whole notion of going to church.
Recently, we've been following the work of the Wildwood Trust, which aims to protect native woodland creatures on their reserve in Kent.
They also hope to reintroduce into this country animals which used to live here but which have been wiped out.
Last week we followed their conservation team to Bavaria in Germany to collect some European wild beaver.
And here's part two of the story.
Following an 800 mile journey, the Wildwood team had acquired three male beavers in Bavaria.
But they still didn't have a female one, so the race was on to find one.
It's great to meet the people who look after beaver and work with beaver, because these are the people who make beaver work in Bavaria.
If it's a female, we'll take it with us.
There's another trap.
It's hard to tell the sexes apart, but Bavarian beaver expert Gerhard knows how.
This one's another male.
Not the vital lady beaver, so the convoy hits the road.
Right, we're following Gerhard and we've teamed up with one of his colleagues.
The last beaver we had was a male, so we've got all males now.
We've got to find a female, so we're off to check some beaver traps so they might have trapped a beaver last night.
Back at their Bavarian nature reserve base, Martyn from Wildwood has stayed behind to get some snaps.
I have been taking some photos, specifically for our education department and also for signage around the park.
The one I'm photographing at the moment has a bell round its neck which is quite a European, German thing to do.
Part of why the cows are here, partly why the bison are here, and why this research centre's here, is that they're trying to manage the land in a slightly different way.
So they're trying to encourage local farmers to farm in more traditional methods so that it becomes a haven for wildlife.
It's this idea that agriculture and looking after the environment don't have to be mutually exclusive.
As you can see, this is really boggy and this is exactly the type of environment that beaver both create and protect, keep it nice and moist, and this also helps protect the environment.
This is locking away carbon, which is great, which is what we really want to encourage.
Meanwhile, Peter is on his way to check out one of the many traps designed to stop beavers felling trees along roads and embankments.
Right, the beaver trap's a very clever trap.
These flaps are held open and then they can come down and trap the beaver when it operates a little flap on the inside.
This stuff here is to help channel the beaver up from the river and into the trap.
You can actually see the beaver just there.
Now Gerhard's gonna persuade the beaver by blowing, and a little gentle persuasion, to come out and into the box here.
There he comes, there he comes.
Big one!
Let's find out if she's a girl.
It may look awkward, but this method is far safer than using anaesthetic.
Female, nice.
OK, now you've got everything you want.
Have a beer, wave goodbye!
We've got a female, she looks in excellent condition.
Prime of life, looks like she'll be perfect to go onto Ham Fen and do the job we need to do, so we've collected our beaver family!
So we've got everything we need now so we can get ready for the big journey home tomorrow.
It's early in the morning and all the beaver are packed up ready for their long trip.
It's a 14-hour journey, so the animals get regular checks along the way.
She looks good, there's a nice steady breathing, so we're happy with her.
They're all looking pretty good.
You can see them all here, all breathing nicely.
We've got the dad and the two youngsters.
Germany, Holland, Belgium and France all have to be negotiated with the beavers in tow.
If you put your torch through one of those holes, you can look down.
With such an unusual cargo, the port of Calais takes a bit of negotiating.
European beaver.
Castor, yes?
I thought that it was dog.
We've got to go to the tourism side.
A long three days, actually.
The only thing is, these animals would have been boxed up anyway and they would have been destroyed, unfortunately, because they're a problem.
So we're giving them a new lease of life back at Wildwood and then on to the Ham Fen nature reserve.
The beavers are already mini celebrities as they await transfer.
Then it's off to Wildwood's quarantine area, home for the next six months.
Everything has worked A-OK.
It's been a very, very long day.
But the beaver over there, they've paired up lovely.
The two young are playing in the pool.
Everything looks healthy, so we're really happy.
It all worked out in the end and we're all...we're all ecstatic.
And on next week's Countryfile, Adam will be looking at the issues surrounding the reintroduction of beavers into the British countryside.
Like me, you probably celebrated New Year with a little drop of something at midnight.
But in the north of Scotland, there's a village which delays its celebrations for more than a week and Miriam has been there to find out why.
Burghead sits on a headland overlooking the Moray Firth.
Every year the town celebrates New Year eleven days after the rest of us.
It's part of a tradition that goes back at least 1,600 years to a time when people worshipped the elements, particularly the power of fire.
On the night of the 11th of January, people turn out to witness the burning of the Clavie, a timber barrel filled with wood and tar.
The Clavie is paraded around the streets and pieces of charred wood are handed out by the Clavie Crew.
They're Burghead men born and bred, and led by the Clavie King.
Not royalty, no.
But very local.
What does it mean to Burghead to be able to continue this tradition?
Well, burning the Clavie is the most important night in Burghead.
We've just come from the old year into the New Year tonight, and it gives local people a chance to think of their ancestors, and to think of our links with our ancient past.
All the local people scramble to get a bit of burnt Clavie which will bring good luck for the forthcoming year.
It's in Dan's workshop that the Clavie is built on the day of the burning.
The men brought up in Burghead all take part.
And this year, that includes a few new additions to the Clavie Crew.
With the barrel cut in half and the central staff prepared, the sacrificial Clavie is put together.
The same nail is used each year, hammered in by an ancient stone.
So this is the completed Clavie?
The Clavie ready to burn.
It's good that everyone took a turn helping to make it.
We've got to encourage the young ones because they're our security for the future.
So these young boys here, they'll be the next Clavie carriers?
Do people really feel that it's the start of the New Year - you have celebrated one already.
We keep our enthusiasm for the Clavie Night, because this is the Clavie and this is Burghead.
Burghead has a rich history.
The town is built on the site of an ancient fort.
2,000 years ago it was occupied by the Picts and it's possible that the burning of the Clavie comes from the ancient fire ceremonies practised by them.
But the reason for celebrating the New Year eleven days late is known.
The 11th of January is the old New Year, the Julian calendar.
52, the Gregorian calendar was introduced to Britain.
We lost eleven days, basically.
The Gregorian year was eleven days shorter than the Julian year.
But in Burghead we thought, we'll keep our old New Year and so we kept our old New Year and we still celebrate it on the 11th of January.
Why does Burghead continue the ceremony when other communities stopped it?
Well, we're quite thrawn in Burghead in the broch, as we call it.
Thrawn's a good Scots word that means stubborn.
We have our own ways of doing things.
It's also another very good reason for having another celebration.
And when you see the winter up here, we need a celebration in winter, definitely.
The Clavie is going to be paraded around the town later on tonight.

Obviously it's important that the fire doesn't go out, so the Clavie Crew are busy positioning fuel at strategic points around the town so they can throw a bit more wood on the fire if it looks in danger of the embers dying down.
The final resting place for the Clavie will be Dourie Hill.
This is where most people manage to get their piece of it and where the safety-conscious Clavie Crew try to keep control of the fire.
Has the Clavie ever gone out?
It's never gone out and we don't expect it to tonight.
With such a strong wind, the wind will certainly fan the flames tonight.
So we have to be a bit careful.
And with the crowds assembling, Dan Ralph, the Clavie King, collects some burning peat from a local house to light the Clavie.
The Clavie is now a flaming beacon and you can tell...
Well, you might have been able to tell if I hadn't been pushed out of the way by the crowd.
And it's considered a great honour to receive a much-prized piece of it.
It's quite a flame.
And the Clavie Crew are pushing everybody out of the way, because if you get too close, it's too dangerous.
The guys carrying the Clavie are so close to the flames, it looks like smoke coming out of their heads.
We're on our way up now to Dourie Hill, where the Clavie will be placed on a stone monument.
That's where the fun really begins.
When the Clavie is put in place, more timber is added.
It looks dangerous for the Crew, but it doesn't seem to bother them.
Then fuel is thrown onto the fire.
The fire's really taking off now.
And still the Clavie Crew are getting really close.
The Clavie burns down and as the heat recedes, members of the Crew grab pieces to hand out to the crowd.
I've got my piece of the Clavie.
It's still very hot but they've given me a wet cloth to hold it in.
Have you ever been close to flames like this?
Do you really think that's going to bring you luck?
I would risk my life to come out for this.
It's the best Clavie for many years.
Sometimes with the wind, if the wind's so high, it'll be blown off, but not tonight.
It went very well.
I've had a great time, and I've got my piece of the clavie, I'm not giving it to anybody.
And finally, the clavie falls, signifying the start of a Burghead new year.
This is officially 2009.
You'll have to give me a kiss.
Clavie night is over for another year.
I'm hoping my piece of this ancient ritual brings me luck in 2009.
In a moment here in the New Forest, I'll be exploring more of its coast, and hopefully see some of the waving birds that make their winter home on the salt marshes.
This is where the sea, in the form of the Solent, meets up with the New Forest, but there are not a lot of trees, it's mostly scrubland, because not much can grow in this windy, salty atmosphere.
You know you're in the New Forest because there are ponies grazing.
Ever since the Bronze Age in this marshland, salt production brought prosperity.
It all stopped with the opening, 150 years ago, of the salt mines in Cheshire, which were much more efficient.

The seawater came into shallow large pans, or troughs, where the water could evaporate, Then it was moved across the landscape, pumped through small pumping stations with windmills into large tanks, and from those tanks, it would be taken down into salt boiling houses, where with the use of coal and fire, they could further evaporate the salt and crystallise it.
All the way along the south coast, particularly around Lymington, it was nationally important.
It could produce £25,000 profit in a good year in the 1820s.
Over here, a disused canal now, but where the barges came.
Absolutely, they'd come in with coal from the north east, and then the salt product would go out along these canals back out to sea and round the coast.
How many people would have been working in the salt business?
In a good season, you'd have 16 weeks of evaporation from the sun and wind.
It was a very seasonal activity.
When salt production moved to the Cheshire mines, what happened here?
A combination of the railways bringing cheap salt from Cheshire and the cost of importing coal here, the industry just fell to pieces.
That was in the 1860s.
Apart from the canal, this is all that's left of a once-vibrant industry Two brick salt barns.
The wild marshes are nature reserves run by Hampshire County Council and the local Wildlife Trust.
These lagoons, are they a leftover from the salt industry?
Well, no, they look like they've been here a long time.
This lagoon, Normandy Lagoon, was constructed in 1990.
They were looking to rebuild the sea wall and needed material to do it so they dug it out here, created the lagoon and islands, and here it is.
I can see the Isle of Wight ferry!
That goes past every quarter of an hour.
That's weird to see it on the horizon.
We've got a good range of winter visitors at this time of year, things like Brent geese and wigeon, which have come from Arctic Russia.
Also species like cormorants out there on the island, which are residents in the Solent, they loaf around there at high tide, digesting their fish supper - they're quite happy to sit there.
This is a red-breasted goose.
This bird has been in the area for a month or so now.
It's lucky that it's turned out today on the Normandy lagoon.
Handsome thing, is that deep crimson?
It depends what light you're in.
It's not quite the same colour as your jacket, John, pretty bright.
No, it could do with a bit more camouflage but it's not affecting the bird today.
Next Sunday, we're heading to Norfolk to catch up with an exciting new marine project in the Wash.
It was a world dominated by books.
From childhood, they all read voraciously, and in turn, they created their own stories.
The sisters turned their isolated home into a factory of the imagination.
From inside their minds, they conjured up new worlds and unique characters.
They were the Bronte sisters, authors of masterpieces such as Jane Eyre and Wuthering Heights.
For all their love of books, the Brontes could have had no idea what happened inside their brains when they read and imagined.
Only now, modern neuroscience has shown that the effects of reading can be more extraordinary than they could ever have dreamt.
New imaging technology, like fMRI scanning, allows us to observe the living brain at work.
It's shown that reading - something most of take for granted - can help unlock remarkable powers.
Reading builds new connections in the brain, which in turn allow us to use written words as stepping stones to understand other people's worlds.
A good book literally has the power to change you.
But the technological ingenuity that has given us brain imaging has also spawned fabulous new media - the internet, blogs and video games.
It is a digital revolution that some think challenges the old world of reading.
Time to show why, more than ever, reading matters.
I've always been fascinated by the way that things work, which is why I write about science.
The most fascinating thing of all is this - the human brain.
It's probably the most complex machine in the universe and in some ways it's the most powerful too.
In fact, it's so powerful, it's even starting to understand itself.
When I started writing about psychology, the brain was effectively a black box.
We knew what it looked like inside, but was going on in there was anybody's guess.
We could only surmise it from the behaviour that it produced.
But that changed in the '90s, when we got new imaging technology, which, for the first time, could look inside a working living brain and see what was going on.
Since then, we've learnt a great deal about the brain, including the surprising extent to which it's shaped quite literally by experience.
Lots of our cognitive skills, like speech, for example, are wired in, but others have to be custom built into each individual.
And these include what is perhaps the most crucial one of all - our ability to read.
And that's why, although most of us take it for granted, reading is so remarkable.
Reading and writing don't come naturally, so to do it, the brain must change.
Human beings were never born to read.
We were born to see, smell, hear, but never read.
What the human brain had to do was to rearrange its existing parts.
So how did the human brain, that evolved to speak, make the leap to literacy?
How did our brains get from recognising this... ..to knowing what these abstract marks on a page sound like, and understanding what they mean?
The first clue comes from the long history of our species.
That may not seem to have much to do with reading a book, but successful hunting depends on visual skills that would, tens of thousands of years later, prime the mind to read.
These early humans needed to recognise fine differences between shapes, say between a useful stick and a deadly snake.
Barely visible animal tracks could warn of danger, or of opportunity.
Then, 5,000 years ago, those skills were adapted to serve another purpose altogether, when we invented the alphabet and started to read.
Ancient hunters became modern readers.

Part of the reading process involves areas that were and are being used for object recognition, so our ability to use our visual areas to immediately know whether that object is prey or predator is actually being recycled for us in able to be automatically recognising symbols.
Today it's impossible to imagine a world without trillions of words, on street signs and hoardings, in newspapers, books, magazines, and on the internet.
So how did the brain get rewired to read?
To understand how we do new things, which we do do constantly, you need to know two key things about the brain.
One is that it's modular.
That is, different bits of it specialise in doing different things.
And the other is that it's plastic.
The modules work together to produce an almost infinite range of behaviour.
You could think of it as a sort of Lego set that can be built up to do one thing and then dismantled and built again in a different way to do something else entirely.
One of the most dramatic demonstrations of the brain's ability to reshape itself came from some surprising subjects - London cabbies.
Their brains provided the living data for a now-famous piece of neuro-scientific detective work.
It looked at a bit of their brains called the hippocampus.
And it's the bit that we all use when we are finding our way about.
It helps to code and retrieve knowledge about space.

Of course, taxi drivers know more about that than any of us, because they have to do this thing called the Knowledge, which involves two years of becoming familiar with all the back streets of London.
What the researchers found when they looked at the cab drivers' hippocampus was that that bit of the brain was measurably bigger than it is in ordinary people.
Right now, if you looked at this guy's brain in a scanner, you'd see that his hippocampus is firing away like crazy as he find his way around these streets.
And it's that constant firing away in a particular bit of the brain that builds that area up and makes the module particularly strong.
The taxi driver study shows that the human brain can adapt to fresh challenges.
In the case of these cabbies, storing an entire map of London streets inside their heads.
So does that mean that our brains have a special part, like the hippocampus, that gets muscled up to read?
So often in the study of the mind, the most revealing clues have come from brains that, for some reason, can no longer perform particular tasks.
'Last year, Terry Jones attended a friend's 40th birthday party.
'The day after, he woke to find the world had changed.'
The next morning, erm, got up, going to have a shower and, erm, I couldn't read what was the shower, what was the shampoo and anything else, it was just another language.
I said to my partner, "Oh, they've bought some cheap little shampoo, "can't read it, it must all be in a foreign language."
"Yes, love, don't be stupid."
I said, "OK."
Anyway, I wasn't, but I just couldn't read it, so we went downstairs to breakfast.
So, when you looked at the letters, what did you actually see?
I could see letters and it could say breakfast, and I could read letters, but those letters didn't make a word, if you understand what I mean.
So, could you understand that B was B and R was R?
I could understand the B and the R, and...but I couldn't put them together to make any sense.
It was, erm...it was, it was though it was another language.
I just couldn't read as a word.
Checked in the hospital and had the various tests and, erm, it proved that, erm, I'd had a small stroke.
Terry's case fascinated scientists at University College in London.
If you just want to lie back down...
In the neuroscience department, a team led by Cathy Price used an MRI scanner to discover which region of Terry's brain had been damaged.
They hoped it would help to pinpoint the parts of the brain normally involved in reading.
You can see it here, so we've got three angles of the brain here.
Where this blue cross is here, there's a big, black, mark, so this area of his brain has been damaged, and you can see, if you look on the right hemisphere, this is what it should look like.
And so what is the effect of that?
He's seeing it as a child would see a word.
They can see the word, they can see the letters, but it doesn't make any sense to them.
So it seems what's happened with Terry is that he can see the word, but he can't take that visual information forward.
Is this then the brain's reading centre?
To find out, Cathy sought out other people who had developed reading problems after a stroke.
Careful observation showed that their difficulties were intriguingly varied.
A patient might look at the word yacht, and say, um, "ship".
So there's no connection between the visual in the word yacht and the word ship.
And then there are other patients, still, who have a different strategy.

They'll look at the word yacht and they'll go, "Yach-t, yach-t," um, and they won't ever guess that it's, it's yacht and, for them, there's, they, they are, um... successfully trying to sound things, um, out, but they're never getting to what the meaning of the word is.
When Cathy scanned the brains of these stroke patients, each with a subtly different reading handicap, she discovered many different bits of their brains had been damaged.
This suggested that reading involves more than one small part.
So a lot of areas of the brain are involved, and they're all integrating together to transform visual information into auditory information into motor information and into the meaning.
And of course, when you read a word, and you can do so in a few hundred milliseconds, you've no idea how hard your brain is working.
So there's no single reading centre, but a highly complex network - a cerebral internet.
In tiny fractions of a second, the brain must decipher letters and connect them to sounds.
Another part of the brain connects sounds and letters to meaning.
Yet another stream of signals fires up parts of the brain that control the movement of our mouths and tongues, even when we're reading silently.
If a single one of these connections is broken, as it is in Terry's brain, the system gets jammed.
Or read a word and not know what it means.
And what is just as remarkable is that every part of our reading kit was originally designed to do something else.
There are no areas of the brain that only respond to reading, so all the areas that are reading are also involved in recognising objects, in speaking.
So, in order to read, it's the connections between the visual inputs and the component sounds that need to be linked together.
So this doesn't involve any new brain regions.
What it involves is stronger and more efficient links.
So how do our brains grow these intricate reading circuits?
These children are about to embark on a remarkable journey, the same one our ancestors took when they invented the alphabet 5,000 years ago, and that Terry has taken in reverse.
"Ou", "ing", "oo".
"Ou", "ing", "oo".

Their brains must learn how to break up a single word they can hear into tiny building blocks, and then link those sounds to the letters they see on a page, and, finally, put it all back together again.
For these young brains, forging links between sound and alphabet is one of the biggest learning challenges they'll ever face.
And for new readers, one language is particularly tricky.
I think English is very tough to learn to be literate in.
Most of the world's languages have syllables like, um, you might find in the word baby or cocoa - they're just a consonant sound, a vowel sound.
Whereas in English, we have very complex syllables.
We have syllables like stamp, or break or bridge, where you've got lots of sounds in that single syllable.

So a child learning to be literate in English has to first of all represent that package of sound very clearly, which is the phonological side, and then they also have to learn which bits of those sound packages correspond to alphabetic letters, when the letter sound correspondences keep varying.
But perhaps making them do that extra bit of work is also good for the brain?
Certainly, in these kind of brain imaging studies, you can see that extra architecture is built up by a brain learning to read in English.
And quite what that means psychologically isn't clear, but yes, the task is more complex, and the brain responds by building up a more complex system in order to cope.
And as with the London cabbies, the more time we put into practicing, the stronger the connections grow, and the better we get at reading.

We can make an analogy with your muscles that you might have the same muscles, but a body builder will build up their muscles so that they're bigger, um, than somebody who wasn't a body builder, and likewise, with the brain, you can see that when you become good at a particular skill, you can actually see the brain structure changing and growing to accommodate the new skill.
And likewise, if you give up on a skill, you can see the brain shrink back down again.
In other words, use it or lose it.
The reading brain is a precious thing.
And to keep it on top form, it must be maintained.
According to a professor of English Literature here at Liverpool University, there is no more powerful way of doing that than tackling the masterpieces of our tough mother tongue.
And he has looked to brain science to show why.
Phil Davis has taught generations of students how to read and understand Shakespeare, one of the most challenging and innovative writers in world literature.
Phil became fascinated by what was sparked inside his brain when it encountered some of Shakespeare's most testing inventions.
A father, says this speaker, and a gracious aged man, have you madded...
Not made mad, but that sudden electrical charge of turning what is an adjective into a verb at one shot.
Coriolanus says, This last old man, whom with a cracked heart I have sent to Rome, giving him no favours, loved me above the measure of a father...nay, godded me even.
Now this time we've formed a verb not from an adjective, but from a noun.
And I put it to you that is more primal, more exciting, more electric than deified me, the Latinate, or made a god of me.
This is sudden, compressed, electric.
So having felt these visceral effects of reading Shakespeare, what made you turn to a scientist to...?
I wanted to know more about what was happening to me.
This is not unusual.
In the play itself in Lear, Lear grabs hold of his head.
Oh, Lear, Lear, Lear, beat at this gate that let thy folly in and thy dear judgment out.
So he's trying to get hold of his head and I wanted, as I think we all do, to get hold of, to grasp what was going on inside.
So I took...knocked on the door of a neuroscientist and said, my instinct is that these shapes in front of our eyes have an effect on the shapes behind our eyes.
Thank you very much.
I'm going to strap you up, make sure you don't run away.
Phil turned to Dr Guillaume Thierry at the Neuroscience Department of the University of Bangor.
The size of the brain doesn't predict anything.

Guillaume used an Electroencephalograph, or EEG machine, to monitor what happens inside Phil's head when he reads a series of sentences, including one using Shakespeare's intriguing use of godded to mean deified.
EEG records brain waves, electrical signals emitted by the brain.
Thierry knew that if the brain is confused by the meaning of a word, it reacts by sending out a distinct electrical response 400 milliseconds after reading the word.
It's called an N400.
If, on the other hand, the brain is thrown by the grammar, it generates a different response after 600 milliseconds, and that's called a P600.
These distinct signals are saying in effect, N400, ignore that, it's nonsense!
P600, that's odd, but it means something.
Phil and Guillaume tested four different phrases, starting with a simple control sentence that both made sense and used correct grammar.
The next two sentences violated either grammar or sense.
The big question was how would Phil's brain respond to that odd word godded?
After analysing data from 20 other subjects as well as Phil, Guillaume revealed his results.
So let's take the first one - they thought so well of the hero that they deified him.
In that case, you get neither an N400 nor a P600.
There is no sign of grammatical violation or semantic violation.
Essentially, this is the brain saying, "Nothing special here, nothing to react to, this is life..."
It's our base line.
It's where we start from.
It's communication and honestly, it's dead boring.
So which one next?
I would leave the functional shift for the end.
I'd rather keep that.
Let's go for, they thought so well of the hero that they printed him...
It's obviously semantically inappropriate.
And what you're getting here is an N400...
An N400 because it doesn't make sense to say, they thought so well of the hero that they printed him.
So an N400 is basically the brain showing, "Oi, this doesn't make sense..."
That's the response we'd expect, that's what we got, so this is nice.
So here, in this collaboration, is sentence number three.
They thought so well of the hero that they candled him.
What we get here is both an N400 and a P600.
So we can tell that the brain is both shocked in terms of the content, the meaning, and about the form.
So the brain behaves differently if it's shocked because it's a syntactical error, as from if it's shocked from a meaning error.
So, fourth, last but by no means least, Shakespeare.
They thought so well of the hero that they godded him...
What we get is fundamentally a P600 effect.
Meaning is integrated normally.
But the grammatical disruption is produced.
So there's a big P600.
There's a big kick on that word, but nonetheless, unlike with candled, there is no N400.
The brain says, I can accept this.

So essentially, what Shakespeare is doing is, every so often, just when he thinks the reader might be getting a bit relaxed and think he knows what's coming next, he'll throw in a kind of oddball word to get attention?
You couldn't find a word that's more appropriate.
