The VOC brought huge prosperity to Holland and kick-started a sophisticated international market.
But in the nineteenth century, the failure to standardise maps began to hold back the development of an efficient global economy.
Navigation relied on comparing the time at your current location with the time on a fixed line of longitude called prime meridian.
Britain's prime meridian ran through Greenwich, where the time was marked once a day by the time ball at Flamsteed House.
Passing Flamsteed House as the time ball fell here, ships leaving the London docks could now quite accurately set their clocks to 1pm Greenwich Mean Time.
But that of course was just the British ships - trading nations all the way from France right through to Japan were still using their own measurements of time according to their own prime meridians.
So could the world's maps be standardised around a single line?
In 1884, representatives of 25 countries came together to decide where the world's prime meridian should be.
The meridian lines that had ranged across the world's maps since Ptolemy were now symbols of imperial prestige.
Proceedings were dominated by Britain and France, who were by now the pre-eminent imperial powers of the age, with each lobbying for the supremacy of their own prime meridian.
The French delegates regarded themselves as part of a long and extremely distinguished tradition of scientific map making.
They were going to fight their corner really hard.
But Britain's claim found support from the United States' delegate, Commander William Sampson.
Commander Sampson argued that, "The meridian should be selected which is now in most general use.
"More than 70% of all the shipping of the world uses the Greenwich Meridian."
Britain now had the advantage.
When it came to the vote, only San Domingo opposed the British claim.
Britain was absolutely triumphant, and this 1886 British Empire map shows Britain right at the centre of the world, with the Greenwich Meridian running right down the middle.
And across the map in red, British Imperial Dominions.
And just to make the point very clear about what is happening here, Britannia is shown lounging on a globe.
The French delegation returned home to Paris with their tails between their legs, but they still refused to concede defeat.
This French world map produced eight years after the Meridian Conference stubbornly sticks to Paris as the prime meridian and, by implication, France as the centre of the world.
It would be another quarter of a century before the French map-makers adopted Greenwich as their prime meridian.
The international battle over the prime meridian is long over, and the mapping of the whole world is almost complete.
But disputes over unclaimed territory continue.
In 2007, the age of discovery and plunder was given a new lease of life when a Russian submarine planted a titanium flag on the seabed directly beneath the North Pole.
And the rush by other nations to claim rights over natural resources beneath the Arctic ice is now putting today's map-makers at the heart of a new struggle for power and wealth.
The International Boundaries Research Unit at Durham University is drawing up new maps of the Arctic in an effort to resolve potential territorial disputes.
This is the political map and this is the physical map?
Why is this map so important now?
The need for the physical mapping is because so little is known about what lies under the Arctic because it has been covered by ice.
So global warming is creating a much more politically charged area around claims to the North Pole?
To some extent, the opening up of the Arctic waters means that areas where there are potential resources are becoming much clearer.
It's huge, I think it was something like 20 billion barrels of oil and gas in the Arctic in region.
Areas likely to be rich in gas and oil have already been partially mapped.
It all depends on who can establish their claim to the seabed.
The Durham team have created the first political map of the Arctic to show who is currently laying claim to what.
We have the land territories of Russia, which has the longest coastal frontage on the Arctic, the USA through its sovereignty over Alaska, we have Canada with the Canadian Archipelago.
Then we have Greenland under the sovereignty of Denmark, and finally Norway, through its sovereignty over the Svalbard Archipelago.
States have rights over the resources up to 200 nautical miles from their coastline.
But in exceptional circumstances, it's possible for a country to extend this boundary.
And that's what the Russians are trying to do.
They're laying claim to a raised area of the seabed extending all the way from Siberia to the North Pole.
It's called the Lomonosov Ridge.

The famous flag-planting incident on the North Pole seabed came as part of Russia's attempt to gather more evidence that the Lomonosov Ridge really is physically connected to the continental margin of Russian land territory.
Which caused quite a hostile reaction from some of its neighbours, particularly Canada, which said, "Why was Russia claiming the North Pole as Russian?"
Legally, it has no effect at all.
Planting a flag, certainly these days, does not say anything about title to territory.
I think having a good map on the table in a negotiation is extremely important.
As that ocean becomes more navigable, there is a risk of naval incidents and who knows what kind of geo-political games could be played in the region.
From medieval times to the age of discovery and the era of empire, map-making has always been bound up with conquest, imperial expansion and conflict.
This modern "map in progress" depicts the fault lines of the future.
It's a warning of potential conflict ahead as the Arctic ice melts.
The lessons of history would suggest that where there's a world map, plunder will surely follow.

But this time the map-makers are ahead of the game, because when the ice melts and the exploitation really starts, there will be an internationally recognised chart of the region to take the heat out of the conflicts over mineral wealth which will surely take place.
In the 21st century, map-makers have become peacemakers.
My travels will take me south through Powys and across the River Severn.
Along the way, I'll be looking back at the best of the BBC's rural programmes from this part of the world.
Welcome to Country Tracks.
Sometimes you have to climb up high to find out just why the border is, well, where it is.
And there you have it, the rolling Shropshire plains there, rising into the jaw-droppingly beautiful Welsh mountain ranges in that direction.
This land was fought over for centuries by ancient Britons, Normans and Saxons who all wanted to control it.
And in the 8th Century, the fearsome King Offa built his dyke.

Stretching from the North Wales coast to the Severn Estuary, it set a boundary which has lasted more than 1,000 years It's a landscape shaped by centuries of conflict and the spirit of the Borders lives on today thanks to those with a passion for its history.
Just watching these guys brings this whole landscape alive.
Now, Chris, you are a re-enactor, so tell me what's going on over here.
The ones coming up here in the mail shirts are the Saxon patrol coming along the Dyke.
They're on the lookout for Welsh raiders.
And the Welsh raiders would be coming in to steal livestock?
All it needed was a bad harvest and they'd be going hungry at the end of the winter and they'd be looking to come across the border rather than to steal off their own countrymen.
But the Saxon patrol has spotted them.
And the Welsh aren't going anywhere without a fight.
I don't quite understand, I thought that Offa's Dyke was supposed to keep the two sides apart.
Offa's Dyke is more of a boundary.
It could be patrolled but it's 175 miles long, you can't defend it all.
If I was going to get involved in this, what side do you think I'd be on, the Welsh or the Saxons?
I think you'd be a Saxon - tall, blonde hair, with a name like Fogle, I don't think that's very Welsh!
Do you think I could do it in these clothes?
But I've got some kit we could put on you.
OK.
First you're going to have to take that warm layer off.
I was liking that with the wind!
We'll start with the mail shirt.
Do you want to feel the weight.
You're now going to wear this, yes.
If you can get your arms right up into the sleeve holes first.
So you really did need someone probably to help dress you, you couldn't do this on your own.
How many links do you think are on this?
About 30,000.
It actually doesn't feel quite so bad when it's on the body, does it?
The weight's distributed so it's not all in one lump.
I'd rather wear it and walk five miles than carry it for one mile.
BEN LAUGHS That sums it up, it's very heavy.
Right, so what next?
If I put your sword belt on.
Then, when I put this on, this will actually take some of the weight onto your hips so it's not all on your shoulder.
Yes, sir!
It will stop a cut, but it won't stop a sharp point like an arrow or a spear because that would break a link open and go through.
Just one because you won't need one on your shield.
And we'll pull the sword hilt round there so it's ready for you to get it if you need it.
That is quite a weight, everything that I've got there.
I'll pass you over to the Saxons now who will give you instructions.
Hello, fellow Saxons!
'And every new recruit has to learn the basics, 'even if I'm stuck at the back!'
The Welsh that we're dealing with, are they an effective bunch?
They are very wily and good at running about which is what we won't do today.
We are going to keep a tightly packed shield wall and we'll drive them back to Wales where they came from.
'But we struggle to push the Welsh raiders back even a few feet 'and it's a standoff.
'Pretty terrifying too, so I'm more than happy to take a back seat.'
On this journey along the English Welsh border I'm sticking mainly to the Welsh side.
But over in Shropshire, Adam Henson took to the skies for a birds eye view of border country.
The Shropshire hills have a distinctive character of their own.
Here on the Long Mynd, the sloping hills and valleys make it a haven for those wanting to take to the skies.
Mark, why are the Shropshire hills so popular for paragliding and hang gliding?
I think, Long Mynd, this area itself is one of the best in the UK.
We've got all the British records from here.
It's central, it's easy to get to.
The views are spectacular and people from not just locally fly here, from all over the UK, world wide it's got a really good reputation.
Are the Shropshire hills really good for the thermals, the uplift?
The thermals obviously in springtime are at their greatest and they can go from a metre a second to 15 or 20 metres a second.
Really good lift and they work in the valley very well and the paragliders, because of the way they fly, can turn in them, like birds of prey.

It appeals to absolutely everyone, from climbers who are used to that sort of thing right through to people that have maybe disabilities who just want to have a go and experience the thrill of flying and so it has a massive appeal to everyone.
Well, it's got to be time for me to give it a go.
'I've chosen to have a lesson in paragliding.'
'After unpacking the wing, Mark and I do a spot-check.'
Make sure that there's nothing untowards in the glider.
'Next for some flight training.'
If you want to go right, you pull down on the right and push the left up.
Keep it to where you want to go and then you release back again.
You then pull both down and then the glider flares, slows down and you can step down nice and easily.
'All sounds simple enough, 'just a small matter of getting airborne.'
'So, a short run down the slope and up, up and away.'
'Well, perhaps not.'
'But after a few more goes, I start to get the hang of it.'
I was off the ground, not far - took off like a beautiful buzzard, landed like a duck!
The wind conditions have to be right to fly off the top of Long Mynd.
If it's more than 15 mph, it's not safe for us to fly.
27, wow!
'It doesn't look I'll get to test out my new found flying skills today.'
Well, against all odds, Mark has told me now that the weather has changed and the wind has died down enough for us to get up in a tandem flight.
I've had my training, now I'm going for the real thing.
Both done up OK.
Wow!
This really is a true sensation like a bird flying in the sky.
Amazing!
I'm exploring the border country between England and Wales and my journey takes me near Welshpool and across the River Severn.
There was a time when this river marked the border between England and Wales.
That was, of course before the native Welsh were pushed back into the hills.
So I've come to explore this stretch of water with a craftsman who knows all about life on the river.
My guide is Peter Faulkner and he's been making and paddling coracles for more than 20 years This looks a good spot here.
Just over on the South bank, on the right bank, there's the actual Offa's Dyke itself so we're very close.
Perfect.
So this is a good place to cross.
So this is a famous Welsh coracle, made with a cow hide?

Yes, well, it's a beef steer from the butchers and it's sort of like a big drum really, onto a hazel frame with willow and then it's lashed on with a horse hair cord, the black and white cord you can see, that's plaited horse hair.
It's even got a tail!
It's even got the tail, yes, that's to ward off evil spirits.
Now, Peter, I have been in coracles before but not for many years and I was never particularly good at it.
Can you give me a quick lesson again on dry land here?
What's going to happen is the paddle will go like a pendulum.
That hand more or less stays there.
What you'll do is pull with a slight angle and pull back with a slight angle so it's like a figure of eight, very flattened...
You're pulling with that and pushing with that.
If I remember correctly, I didn't fall in the last two times.
Can we please keep that record?
Yes, I don't like cold water.
Step in backwards?
You're coming with me, aren't you?
'I'm not that confident yet!'
Good, you're a brave man.
Nice and steady, not too quickly.
Then if you paddle then out across, as if you were going straight to the other bank.
That's good, well done.
What's the furthest distance you've done in one of these?
Well, on the Severn actually, 160-odd miles.
11 days.
I started at Llanidloes and ended up at Gloucester.
Do you think anyone's ever tried going across an ocean in these?
I know that a Welshman has been across the Channel.
I really don't want to fall in, that's my main thing.
Keep paddling toward the bank.
This is fun!
'It all comes flooding back and I must admit 'it's nice to take our time and pootle around on the river.'
OK, thank you, Peter.
Now that is the way to cross a river - in a coracle.
Now, when actress Jean Marsh came to Offa's Dyke nearly 15 years ago, she did so in a rather more conventional manner.
Well, I've just climbed to the top of beautiful Burfa Hill.
Having left my car behind me at the bottom and eventually I will leave behind the beautiful country of Wales as well because this walk spans two different nations.
And from the top, I can see just about the whole five miles that I'm going to walk.
It also has wonderful historical content.
That's why I want to do it and one of the main parts of it is Offa's Dyke, the path.
And I'm now going to set forth and see if I can find it.
This circular walk will take me down to Burfa Farm and through the naturalist's paradise at Knill Wood.
Crossing the border, I'll find Knill hamlet and then up to the great prize, Offa's Dyke.
An easy stroll then back to Burfa and back to Wales.
It may sound a bit dramatic, but after all I am an actress, but I don't think I can live without walking.
I was born in London and I'm a Southerner but I feel not English, I feel a part of the whole.
Wherever I walk in Britain, I feel as if I belong there.
Coming out of the forest from Burfa Hill, now this is our first sign of civilisation.
Old Burfa Farm.

Looking at this lovely house now, it is difficult to believe that in 1960 it was so derelict, in such a state of disrepair that it was used as a hen house and there was actually an ash tree growing out of the living room.
This is Knill Woods and it's the sort of woods I really love to walk in.
One of the reasons I like walking on my own, I think best of all, is because animals are aware of you but they're not as frightened.
I don't feel at all solemn about my love of the country.
It isn't a serious thing, it's a joyous thing.
In fact, I mean, utterly inappropriately for my age, I leap about and skip and hop and jump.
We've now approached passport control.
This is a small step for Jean, but a giant step for mankind.
I am about to walk into England.
I really like having a walk that has many different points of interest, that's why I like going into Knill.
Cul-de-sac villages are always well protected and Knill has that sort of feudal air about it with all the houses looking rather similar.
For me the countryside can be just as holy as any cathedral.
An important and integral part of any walk is to visit a country church.
Knill has one of the loveliest.
Is the church always full of such beautiful flowers?
No, we have rather a special occasion at this time of the year.
We have something called the Open Gardens and we decorate the church just for this occasion.
The three main gardens in this hamlet, they're all open for the public to come round, for one weekend.
Knill Court was the original house here so I suppose you could call that the original garden.
So, Knill Court which was originally the manor house, the centre of Knill, then became a girls' boarding school and it was burnt down in the 40s.
Rumour has it that it was from illicit smoking, which reminds me of being a wicked little girl in the film The Belles of St Trinian's.
Of course, this part of the world does have a reputation for a little more rain than most!
But I don't mind.
Who cares about the weather when I'm walking in such beautiful scenery.
And none more than the steep climb up Knill Garraway.
Very steep, but worth it for the first glimpse of Offa's Dyke.
Offa was the 8th Century King of Mercia who felt it necessary to protect his nation from the Welsh borderland tribes.
So, he had this famous demarcation line built between England and Wales.
This is Offa's Dyke.
But obviously Offa had a bit of a problem here.
There's a theory as to why it's at such an extreme right angle.
The theory is that in those days there were two separate gangs of labourers hired.
Well, probably serfs in Saxon times.
And they started at separate ends and they met here and had to finish off at this odd extreme angle.
You can tell you're on top of a hill, this is Garraway Hill, and the weather is wild and wonderful.
It's so exciting for me to be walking along the very path that so many thousands have before me since, well, the year 750.
All those people going about their various businesses and now me, just for pleasure.
Well, that's it.

Three hours ago, five-and-a-half miles ago I started my walk and since then I've been through every terrain, every kind of weather, I've been through two different countries and I'm about to step back into the other one, way back up there where I first started.
Jean Marsh there enjoying a hop, a skip and a jump around Offa's Dyke.
I'm also continuing my border country journey along the Dyke.
I started out in Shropshire and nipped over the border into Powys.
As I travel further along the border, I want to understand more about how and why England and Wales were divided.
And I think Offa's Dyke could hold the key.
To unravel some of its mysteries, I'm meeting a man who knows this area like the back of his hand.
So what exactly is Offa's Dyke?
Well, Ben, it's basically a big bank and ditch which we're stood on here and essentially it separates England and Wales or what we now call England and Wales.
In fact, at the time that it was built, over 1,000 years ago, it would have been separating the Anglo-Saxon kingdom of Mercia, behind you there, and the Welsh kingdom of Powys on this side over here.

It relates to a time when the Anglo-Saxons are expanding across Britain and they're basically fighting with the native British people who are represented by the kingdom of Powys and they get to a point where the English king, Offa, of this period, decides it's time to draw a territorial boundary and maybe a partly defensive one and that's really what Offa's Dyke is.
I think that's a good point.
Originally it would have been much bigger and a big ditch as well.
It would have been a big physical barrier but there were no soldiers patrolling it.
It's completely different to something like the Roman Hadrian's Wall.
It is making a massive statement in that sense.

It's just about the power and will of Offa and it's saying, people might be able to cross it, might be able to clamber across it but, you know, you might be in trouble as well if you do that because the guy who's built this thing clearly means business.
And it must've been a huge physical undertaking.
I think we're talking of the labour, and it would have been labour, of literally thousands of people to construct this thing quit probably in a short period of time.
You've been studying Offa's Dyke for years, what does it mean to you?
I think the most evocative thing about it is it's really a symbol of the first emergence of the modern nations.

We're right at the beginning really of our modern era and we're just in the time when the languages we speak - be they English as we speak, or Welsh, as people still speak over there - begin to emerge.
And here is Offa's Dyke as a very physical symbol of that connecting literally to our cultural origins, to our ideas of being English and Welsh.
There's virtually nowhere else in Britain where you can go and physically stand on a remnant of that time.
I've just about reached the halfway point on my journey in the border town of Knighton.
You can walk the National Trail all the way to Chepstow but, with night falling, I've arranged a lift.
Wow!
Now, THIS is my kind of taxi.
This is very cool.
Onwards.
While I continue my journey in this eye-catching set of wheels, let's go back a few years when I tried my hand at a very different type of four-wheeled transport.
You can't beat the tranquillity of the English countryside.
Yet here in Herefordshire, just over the hill there, there's a whole host of people getting an adrenaline rush.
This is now one of the fastest growing extreme sports in the UK with thousands of riders enjoying the freedom of the hills to perfect their jumps.
There are now more than 30 centres around the country.
It is a sport for everybody.
There's an element that everyone can try.
You can see kids as young as seven picking it up and starting to get on with it.
I've seen 55-year-olds riding down the hill.
And you're a course designer.
I do boardercross courses like the ones you can see in the distance, different types of jumps and freestyle setups like the slopes behind us.
Would you say this is a nice, safe environment for these guys?
We've designed this centre the same as all the other centres across the UK so that it is safe.
There is somebody at hand to do it and keep an eye on you.
It's in the countryside so there's fresh air and beautiful views.
How do you go about finding your sites?
At first, we advertised in a country magazine for farmers with redundant slopes to take a look at our website and check out what the sport was.
We've been going to places like the Earls Court Smithfield Show where 100,000 farmers go through each year over the four days.
For farmers to go through and see mountainboards instead of a tractor or a combine was a very eye-catching thing.

For a slope that can only be grazed or mown et cetera, then, for a small amount of money - you're looking at around £5,000 to £6,000 - you can set up a centre and have it successfully running for a season.
It is a cheap way, a fun way, it brings a lot of life into the land and it makes a lot of people happy.
Now it's my turn!
All of you are going to start from this pole here, and we'll head down and try, if you can, to do a powerslide, stopping within the boxes.
Once you get to the blue poles, start doing the powerslide.
Ben, do you want to come over now?
On my bum?
And then I'm going to push the weight and pull that foot to spin it around, do I?
OK?
Weurgh!
EVERY time!
Four years ago, Herefordshire farmer Roy Powell and his daughter Nicki decided to open up a mountainboard track to run alongside their pick-you-own farm.
Now they're attracting people from all over the country.
So whose idea was it to set up the mountainboarding?
Basically mine.
50 years ago I had terrific fun tobogganing down this hill and then about 20 years ago I looked into having a dry ski slope and unfortunately it was prohibitive cost.
So it more or less rested on its laurels until about 2001.
Surfing the net, farmers do surf the net...
..I came across mountainboarding and, luckily at that time, I found Maxtrack which specialised in setting up mountainboarding centres and that gave us, of course, a kick-start to this very venture.
And has it breathed new life into your farm, do you think?
Any additional enterprise, providing it's run reasonably well, is good and, of course...
It complements everything else we do on the farm.
You get parents coming up to pick fruit, drop their children at the boarding centre so they don't get bored, they're having fun.
It works well.
We've been very pleased with the way it's grown from year to year.
It's our fourth year this year.
We're seeing approximately 5,000 per season through the gates, um, and it is growing.
We're also hosting the national championship final later on this summer, which is really exciting.
Some of these guys behind me are world class riders, including World Champions Leon Robbins and his brother Austin from America.
The sport is attracting people from the States, Australia and New Zealand - all coming to Britain because it's the best place to do it.
Probably the best place in the world to ride is England.
They've got 40 places that you can go ride, slopestyle courses and boardercross tracks and all within three hours of each other so...it's a really concentrated place to come and ride.
Would you say that mountainboarding is still in its early stages?
It's been around for ten years.
It's still just now starting to catch on.
You see a lot of kids on the hill and they're into it and their parents are into it.
They have good places to ride now, so it's taken off.
Oooh!
Wahoo!
Well, we've had surfing, skateboarding, snowboarding... and now we have mountainboarding!
Woohoo!
I'm back on my road trip and getting to know my chauffeur, Andy Hazell.
He's a border-based artist and self-confessed magpie who collects all sorts of, well, junk and turns it into unusual art.
This old, retired hearse was a perfect canvas.
The funny thing is when I bought this from the undertaker in Anglesey, the other person who wanted to buy it was a goth rock band.
So, it's only me and goth rock bands who want to buy these things.
Because cars were once sacred things.
Cars were things your dad used to polish on a Sunday.
You can buy a car for £150.
It's the exact opposite of Pimp My Ride, where people spend a fortune turning it into something sexy and gleaming.
This is more about deconstructing the car, being playful with it.
Do you call yourself eccentric?
I think I'm perfectly normal.
And your workshop gives me the impression you're a bit of a Caractacus Potts?
I do collect an extraordinary amount.
The best thing is, people know I collect things.
One morning, somebody had left me an inflatable boat outside!
Nothing important.
How would you like to think people received your art?
I say that my job is to put a bit of mystery and wonder back.
I'd say by the reactions we're getting, you're definitely getting "wonder"!
All of those.
Obviously it's road-legal...
I got stopped twice, once by Cheshire police, once by Tyne and Wear, driving this to Newcastle last December.
Presumably, they can't believe it is road-legal?
I'm taking a risk.
Can we get up a hill like this?
I trust you.
It has taken the edge off performance!
Heading through Powys, we come to Presteigne and we're running low on fuel.
I'm glad you find that so funny!
The diesel pump is that far away.
The petrol pump is that far away.
The petrol pump doesn't reach by that much, so I'll take the spire off.
Lucky you brought the ladder.
This could be quite a long journey.
Have you ever seen a car that's had to remove its spire to get under your roof?
We've had a few horse boxes that haven't fitted well!
But that's definitely a first.
I think it's really good.
I especially like the lights in it.
I'd love to see that at night.
Have a good day.
My journey started in Shropshire, winding along the border, through Powys, and will eventually bring me to Chepstow and the Severn Estuary.
This is certainly a very unique way to explore the borders and I've finally reached the Wye River.
Not long ago, John Craven came here for Countryfile and explored the Wye Valley all the way to Chepstow, which is where I'm heading.
OK, onwards!

On my walk today, I'm going to be straddling the border between England and Wales, because I've come to the Wye Valley, a place of limestone gorges and dense woodland, of historic towns and dramatic ruins.
The Wye Valley makes a remarkable claim - that it's the birthplace of tourism in Britain.
The Valley is an internationally protected landscape of great beauty.
It's formed by a 72-mile stretch of the meandering River Wye, from just south of Hereford, to the rocky outcrop of Chepstow Castle, where it meets the River Severn.
Down there, through the mist, is Monmouth.
I'm looking at it from a vantage point called the Kymin, 900 feet above sea level.
Back in 1800, the gentlemen of Monmouth built a monument here, a temple, to the Royal Navy and its victories.
They also built a banqueting house where, once a week, they would meet and dine in great style.
Lord Nelson himself was invited here and he remarked on the splendid view.
No doubt he had a better day than this one!
One thing's for sure - he didn't use the kind of water transport I'll use for part of my journey down the river.
Before that, let's pop down to Monmouth and learn a bit more about the historic town.
It is pouring with rain now in the main street in Monmouth, but that's not deterring these people digging up a garden.
What's going on, Steve?
We had a chance to excavate here and because the archaeology of the street is so outstanding, we couldn't miss the chance.
What sort of things have you found?
But beneath that, there's something like 5' of medieval floors, dirt floors, full of the remains of hundreds of years of occupation.
What was going on at about the time people are digging now?
This is really a hiatus in the street and in the country, because that level is just after 1300.
They were about to build a large house here and they were overtaken by the terrible floods and the Black Death, which stopped everything in the street for a long time.
What kind of things are you finding as you're digging?
Yes, pottery and occasional coins, but not a lot here.
But we are getting very distinctive pottery of the early 14th century.
This is some of the pottery made in Monmouth.
A jug.
But it's decorated with different colour clays.
And that is distinctive of this period, just before the Black Death.
What about the most famous man ever to be born in Monmouth, then?
That's Henry V, of course, born in Monmouth Castle in 1387.
You've got Agincourt Square here.
Owen Glendower, who was the great opponent of Henry V.
It al...

I don't know what's going to happen next!
'But I needn't have worried.
I'm in Scotland.'
It's not that different to what people do when they are making whisky.
There's a long tradition round here of making your own whisky.
There is something very traditional about Scottish people inventing and engineering.
We engineered the world.
So we can do this, certainly.
This was steam, coming through, it was steam, it's been cooled down now.
So hopefully what we want to do is increase that flow slightly and eventually we will start getting just a little edge of oil sitting on top of that.
If we can make it work on this scale, then it gets really big.
This is quite small scale.
Having Boots there, is it almost like a double-edge sword because you have committed to them and now you've got to deliver?
You can't mess them around because all this wonderful potential could slip away if you don't get it right.
I'm reminded of that every single day.
'I really hope this project works.
'It's already moved on to the next stage.
'An American multinational has got involved to scale up production.'
'They've started growing bog myrtle as a commercial crop.
'If the industry takes off, this could be a farming bonanza for the Highlands.'
I don't think anyone can just farm here.
If you're not tough enough, if you can't make it work, you'll perish.

I think the farmers' very skills and ingenuity to come up with different ideas to get the very best out the land, to squeeze as much as you can out has been the key to their survival, and it's that very skill that's going to be so important in the future.
Because as we go along and our populations increase, every bit of land is going to be important.
And the farmers here are key to making it all work.
'The final part of my journey takes me to the west of England, 'where farmers have always gone their own way.'
This is the only underground farm in Britain.
'It's the home of mavericks and dreamers.'
I can't give this up, man, I love it.
'With a radical view about how farming should change.'
Everyone's got to think again about how we produce food.
That was a bad one!
My travels start at a farm distillery brewing English vodka.
I'll travel east to Great Malvern, once a favourite haunt of Florence Nightingale and home to the country's smallest theatre, housed in a former public lavatory.

I'll then head to Worcester, to find out why it was earmarked to be on the front line during the Second World War, before journeying to Inkberrow, the inspiration behind the much-loved radio soap opera, the Archers.
I'll end my journey in Birmingham in the recording studio with the actors.
And, along the way I'll be looking back at the best of the BBC's rural programmes from this part of the world.
The Malvern Hills create a spectacular backdrop in this part of the country.

Offering views over Worcestershire and Herefordshire, the hills are also famous for their natural mineral springs and wells, helping to make Great Malvern a popular spa town in the early 19th century.

But it's not the natural mineral water that's brought me to the Herefordshire side of the Malverns, I'm here for another type of local refreshment that's been winning awards all over the world, and it's made from this - the humble spud.
I've journeyed to a farm in Herefordshire where a third generation potato farmer came up with the idea of using his beloved potatoes to produce vodka.
Potato vodka isn't a new idea.
Countries like Poland have been producing it for years, but this farm is a first for the UK.
I've teamed up with Jamie Baxter, the farm's chief distiller, to see how the potatoes are transformed into award-winning vodka.
Good, good, good.
I've got to ask you, vodka in Herefordshire, from potatoes - I would never have thought of that myself.
You just need to try it, the proof's in the tasting.
Smells very nice, actually.
For drinking it neat like that, it's got a beautiful aftertaste That's right, that's characteristic of potato vodkas, because it's got that real creaminess, smoothness and a little hint of sweetness.
A little hint of sweetness, I definitely got that.
How many potatoes does it take to make one bottle of gorgeous vodka?
There's about 5.5 kilos of potatoes in every bottle.
Because we use the small ones like this, that means there's 125 in every bottle.
Because nobody else wants them.
The big ones get sold off to make crisps or chips or something like that.
Nobody else wants to buy them, so that's what I use.
They're clean, sound, wholesome, there is nothing wrong with them.
In actual fact, they're slightly better for the vodka because the small ones tend to be slightly higher in starch.
OK, so how does that get turned into this?
OK, that all takes place at the distillery over the other side there.
We'll go and see that now, shall we?
Jamie's spent the last four years perfecting the potato-vodka process at the distillery site on the farm.
It all looks pretty hi-tech in here.
Tell me first of all, what happens to the spuds once they're taken out of the fields?
We have four stages to making the vodka.
The first stage is mashing, that's where we have to convert the starch in the potatoes into sugars.
Mashing is a brewing term, but it's nice to be able to use it for potatoes because that's the first thing we do is make a very runny mashed potato.
The way we convert the starch into the sugars is through the use of enzymes.
The enzymes will only work if the starch has been gelatinised, it's got to be cooked.
Enzymes are broken down into starch, into sugars and then you've got to convert those sugars into alcohol.
That's the second stage - fermentation.
We make quite a horrible potato wine, and that's at about 10% alcohol.
Then the third stage, that's what we use all this equipment here for.
We've got mashing and fermentation going on in another room...
That's right.
Yes, that's right.
There's a common misconception that distilling creates alcohol.
All the alcohol is created in the fermentation.
The distilling is all about extracting that alcohol and purifying it and concentrating it.
How many times do you have to distil this alcohol and why do you have to distil it?
When we make vodka and gin in Europe we have to distil to 96% ABV.
That means it's very, very pure.
The only way we can get to that purity is by stilling multiple times.
So with our potato vodka we distil it four times.

It goes four times into this big hot still you can see behind me, but actually it's distilled hundreds of times because every time it goes up this rectification column it passes through a bubble plate, a mini distillation happens at every bubble plate.
Alcohol, or ethanol, at least, boils at just below 80 degrees centigrade.
Water obviously boils at 100 degrees centigrade.

As we heat a mixture of alcohol and water up like a potato wine, as the temperature gets closer to 80 degrees centigrade, the alcohol will start to boil off and we can just condense it and collect it.
For vodka, we just want the ethanol.
It's a massive column over there.
We're doing two things with this big, tall column here.
Firstly, we're concentrating alcohol and by law we have to take it to 96% ABV.
This is things like the methanol, the higher alcohols and algaecides and ketones.
That's the one that makes you go blind, yes.
It's got the lowest boiling point.
We use that property to extract it.

When we set this running first thing in the morning, we let it circulate round and round for two hours and then when we eventually reduce the amount of cooling water at the top of the column, we allow the alcohol to escape, as a vapour.
You can see it flowing out over a little spout here.
The first bit that comes off is the methanol, that's got the lowest boiling point.
We take a little sample when it comes off.
If you smell that, it's got quite a chemical smell.
Until that smell disappears, you're not getting to your ethanol yet?
Have you got a good nose?
If you look at the temperature gauge on the side of the column, it's reading just below 80 degrees centigrade.
What that tells us is that the column is chock-a-block full of ethanol at the moment.
That's just circulating round, coming out the top and we're collecting it in the tank over here.
We end up with three components that we call heads, hearts and tails.
The hearts is the good stuff - that's the ethanol, that's the only bit we want.
The heads is the methanol, and the tails is everything else.
Once you've got your 96% ABV, of course you've got to dilute that down before you can bottle it.
Do you use good old Malvern water?
It comes from our own borehole underneath the apple orchard.
Of course, we have to purify it still further.
That's the water that we use to cut the high-proof spirit down to turn it into vodka.
Right, Jamie, so is this the finished article?
How long from field to bottle?
We've got a week to ferment it, a week to distil it, batch by batch, and then a week to finish it and put it in the bottle using the filling head behind.
So it's all bottled by hand and finished by hand?
Of course, to be internationally recognised is something pretty special, isn't it?
Especially from the San Francisco Awards, which is the most prestigious awards for spirits.
Did you win Best Vodka In The World?
From a farm in Herefordshire.
Production of vodka is a new phenomenon for Herefordshire.
Traditionally, it's the water that's attracted people to this part of the world.
Famed for its curative properties, Malvern spring water became a daily prescription for health-obsessed Victorians and there's still a thirst for it today.
It's the unique geology of the Malvern Hills that produces this fabled water.
These rocks are Precambrian, so they're over 600-700 million years old.
The reason they're still here is because they're hard, they've not been worn away by any of the multitude of geological processes that normally grind down hills.
How does it make the waters so pure?
One of the reasons is because it's hard, it doesn't give much of its minerals to anything that falls upon it.
The rainwater that falls on the top just trickles down through all the cracks and fissures in it and comes out the spouts and absorbs very little in the way of chemicals.
There are over 100 wells and spouts in the Malverns... some of which have fallen into disrepair over the years.
Many have now been restored as part of a three-year project.
OK, this is one of 17 spouts that we've actually restored under this project.
I have to say it is the tallest one and I think it's probably true to say it's also the oldest.
The lower part was built in about the 1830s as a water supply for the surrounding houses.
A little later on, I think in the 1870s, they decided that not only did they need to drink the water, but they needed to tell the time.
It is absolutely massive considering there's, what... a few houses here.
I know, but they must have been big drinkers, I suppose.
It's cold, that's for sure.
That is good.
That's super.
Recently, there's been a decline in the sales of bottled water but here at Malvern it's free for you to collect, directly from these wells.
Malvern water was first bottled here in 1622, and at the bottom of Jubilee Hill is Holy Well and it's believed to be the oldest bottling plant in the world.
It was when Schweppes began to bottle here in 1850 that the rest of the world first became aware of Malvern water.
It's now owned by Coca-Cola, who moved to nearby Colwall and now produce over 18 million bottles a year.
But the current owners of the recently-restored Holy Well are keen to bring back tradition and plan to start bottling here again soon.
So how does it feel for you being the future of this Malvern water?
Well, I'm on top of 400 years of heritage and it's a privilege to be carrying this forward into the 21st century.
It's really important that it carries on.
It must be strange for you to see all this water just dribbling down the drain.
This is your business, surely you want to be...
This has to be here, unfortunately this has to be here.
We can't close this off and bottle it all.
It's really important that people come and visit.
They can sample the product themselves.
Now I understand the Queen likes to have a few sips of Malvern water, do you think she'll be round here?
Malvern developed a reputation as Britain's premier spa town in the mid-19th century.
The curative properties of its spring water became world famous after two Victorians, Dr Wilson and Dr Gully, pioneered methods of curing the sick with this water.
Dr John Harcup has written a book about the notorious Victorian water cure.
The Victorians over-ate and drank and didn't have enough exercise, so Malvern was a marvellous place for them because the environment was right, no pollution.
They went walking up the hills, before breakfast, I hasten to add.
And then they had breakfast after various other water treatments.
Much better than being bled, being purged... and being given heavy metal poisons, such as arsenic and antemin and lead.
It was much better than all the other treatments put together.
Why, do you think?
Um, people relaxed in the wet sheet.
They were stimulated by cold water being poured on them.
They got fresh air and exercise.
They socialised with other people.
And Darwin brought his daughter here, didn't he?
Unfortunately she died here, because she was suffering, we think, from tuberculosis.
Tennyson came and said he was half-cured, half-drowned by it.
John, as a doctor, do you think it works and are you still prescribing it today?
I think it works, but I recommend it - I don't prescribe it.
It is very good for relaxing you.
Cold water stimulates your immune system, so if you've got a cold I guarantee we can abort it by extra cold baths.
Right, well, I am feeling a bit sniffly.
Yes, let's go.
We've come to Hayslad Well, where I'm about to experience the full Victorian water cure, starting with the cold wet-sheet treatment.
Nice and warm for you(!)
I can't believe this.
Right, so you're going to wrap me up in that thing?
Right, you've got to remember this is...
Argh!
This is being done in a water-care establishment.
..Or, a lodging house, not out in the open, as we're doing it now.
Why would anyone want to be wrapped in this?
Six o'clock in the morning.
As the warmth of your body dries out your sheet...
..You relax, you go to sleep... for almost an hour.
Then you're woken up and stripped, because you're a bit like an Egyptian mummy at this stage.
I've got to leave you for an hour.
I suppose I can, there's some rocks over there.
I'll just hop my way over there.
Some ladies have just arrived to fill up their bottles.
Listen, let me give you a hand if I can find where my hand's gone.
I need to warm up, I tell you.
Right, you lead me to your car.
How much longer is he going to have that wet thing round him?
Why?
I don't know.
Next, John's got something even less appealing lined up for me.
You're sat in this for about 15 minutes and it relaxes you.
Very good for your nether regions, because the dear old Victorians didn't bath very often so they obviously had trouble with piles and itches and all sorts of things.
OK, so we're going to cleanse you up round there.
I'll do it for the sake of the experiment!
That's freezing!
Oh, lovely.
OK.
How long do I have to sit in here for?
15 minutes, or we could go onto an hour.
And there's worse still to come.
That's what you call a very cold bottom.
The finale is the Victorian descending douche, a torturous icy-cold shower.
This is to stimulate your nervous system and it should be going on for three minutes.
..But you're only getting a flavour of it.
Just surprise me.
Yes.
Oh...
This is the brandy and soda of the water cure.
Well, I tell you what, my nervous system is well and truly stimulated.
I'm sure I've got a few red patches on the back as well.
Yes, you look wonderful.
Have I finished the treatment?
Yes, just about, yes.
You should be having a rain bath now but we'll walk you up the hills, just to warm you up.
That's it for the water?
I'll get me gear on.
A very brave Matt Baker experiencing first-hand the chilly realities of Victorian water treatments.
I've now travelled to Great Malvern, following in the footsteps of a woman who used to seek the perceived curing properties of Malvern's waters over 100 years ago.
She became famous in her own lifetime for her incredible work during the Crimean War, and for establishing nursing as a true profession.
When she visited here, Great Malvern, she was actually looking for a cure for herself.
The history books tell countless stories of Florence Nightingale as an angel of mercy, helping the ill and injured and improving health practices, both in the UK and abroad.
What's not so widely known is that Florence was, at times, extremely unwell herself, and used to make regular visits here to Great Malvern seeking help.
Florence was a remarkable woman.
In 1837, aged just 17, she felt that God was calling her to work, but she wasn't quite sure what that work should be.
She began to develop an interest in nursing but her parents felt this profession was inappropriate for a woman of her class.
Florence's parents eventually relented and in November 1854 she arrived in Scutari in Turkey to nurse victims of the Crimean War.
By 1860, she had established the Nightingale Training School For Nurses at St Thomas's Hospital in London.
I'm meeting Cora Weaver, a writer and historian who has researched Florence Nightingale's visits to Great Malvern.
How many times did Florence actually visit Great Malvern?
Florence Nightingale came here at least 10 times.
Why did she come here so many times?
She came because she was ill, but different sorts of illnesses.
The first time she came was before the Crimean War and she probably had women's problems or digestive problems.
After the Crimean War, she had a variety of stress-related problems.
What was is about Great Malvern at the beginning, even before the Crimean War, that made her think, "Yes, I need to go here for whatever problems I have"?
It's because in 1852, she'd gone to a place in Warwickshire with her father and they had been treated by Dr Edward Johnson.
He was wonderful, and they were so impressed, and he came from there to Malvern, and that's why they came to Malvern.
They followed the doctor.
They followed the doctor to Great Malvern.
Yes, she stayed here with her mother in 1848 for about seven weeks, and this is where she took the treatment.
What kind of treatments was she getting while she stayed here during those few weeks?
In this house, she would have had a cold dripping sheet, she would have had foot baths and fermentations, which is basically being wrapped up in quite cool wrappings.
It's so special to actually be standing outside the house that Florence Nightingale stayed in.
I get really excited about it.
Florence visited Great Malvern several times for the water cure and this house was another of many she visited over the years.
So, Cora, at which point did Florence Nightingale come to this grand old house?
She came here in March 1857, but she wasn't very well then.
It was after the Crimean War and she came with her aunt and her cousin.
Right, OK.
We're talking post-Crimean War, so different types of ailments now, stress-related ones?
Stress, she had post-traumatic stress, she had brucellosis, which made her completely...very, very ill, she probably had shellshock, just stress after stress.
The thing is, she didn't want anybody to know about her illnesses, did she?
No, she was a very private, very secretive person.
Was she?
So she never told anybody where she was going.
Unfortunately, Dr Gully wrote her a little note and on the front was "Miss Nightingale".

There was only one Miss Nightingale in the whole world then, so everybody found out where she was and all the newspapers said, "Miss Florence Nightingale is now "staying at Dr Gully's water cure establishment in Malvern."
That's the last thing she wanted.
Because she was fairly well-known from her activities at the Crimean War and beforehand?
Before the Crimean War, she was very well-known because her family were very, very wealthy.
Very well-connected, they knew everybody.
Did she let anybody know about her visits to Great Malvern and the curative properties of her treatment?
She used to write to very close friends and members of the family.

The first time she came, for example, she would write home saying, "We feel much better for our ablutions", but after the Crimean War, she didn't write so many letters and they tended to be more miserable and factual.
They weren't the sparkling letters that she had sent before the Crimean War.
Her whole demeanour had changed.
So what treatments did she receive here?
Nowhere near as many as she had taken before the Crimean War, because here her ailments were stress-related and she needed sedation, she needed sedative treatments.
By and large, she would just take the Pack and that would bring down her pulse.
The Pack!
Let me show you.
You look at me as if I should know what the Pack is.
She had that.
"The Packing."
It's a wet sheet - a naked patient wrapped in a cold, wet sheet, like that.
Then wrapped all round with blankets and counterpanes.
So don't you just get a bit damp and warm.
You get very warm and very sleepy.
I've never seen that before.
Would you say that's very beneficial?
Extremely beneficial if you are stressed.
It's very good, but you do need somebody to do it to you.
Water can kill you as well as cure you, and you've got to know exactly what you're doing.
If you get that wrong, you could die.
What do you think of it?
It's OK.
Yes, the first time Florence Nightingale came, she had this douche at Dr Gully's douche baths.
Who was Dr Gully then?
Did he own this house?
Yes, this was Dr Gully's Ladies' Hydropathic Establishment.
Dr Gully was very good with women, not only did they find him extremely attractive, but he was a very good practitioner.
That's what made them well, nothing to do with the water.
He was just a handsome doctor, made them feel all perky again.
I think with Dr Gully, that might just have been the case.
Dr Gully was very rich, he was very clever, he was very well-connected and very attractive to women.
The first time they came here, Mrs Nightingale fell headlong in love with him as soon as she met him.
Florence's mum, to the extent that Florence had to remind her mother that her father was still alive.
On her visits to Great Malvern, the doctor that Florence came to see the most was Walter Johnson at Malvernbury House, a man, she claimed, saved her life.
Now, while in the care of Walter Johnson, she got very ill, didn't she?
She was extremely ill and her family, the whole family were very worried.
He was here...he wrote to his wife, Florence's mother, and said, "Her days may be numbered.
"It is a sad tale.
"I'm not able to say any more.
Adieu."
Oh, dear.
But, at the end of the day, she was fairly ill for a lot of her life.
It could be down to the fact the Crimean War took its toll on her.
Did the cure actually help her, do you think?
She wrote to a friend in 1860 and said, "I wouldn't be here if it weren't for Malvern."
You've done a couple of the treatments yourself, did they have good beneficial value?
The remarkable story of Florence Nightingale's visits to Great Malvern.
If Florence was drawn to this part of the world by the perceived curing properties of the water, others have been attracted by the inspiring landscape.
In the shadow of the Malvern Hills, in the summer of 1857, the son of a piano tuner was born.
From modest beginnings, he was to become one of Britain's greatest composers, Edward Elgar.
I'm climbing the Malvern Hills.
To the west, Shropshire, and to the east, you can see as far as the Cotswolds.
This extraordinary countryside and Elgar's life are inextricably intertwined.
The young Elgar spent hours amid these hills.
He received little formal music education but on summer days he would take music scores from his father's shop into the hills to study them.
Years later, Elgar recalled those childhood days.
He said, "I'm still at heart the dreamy child who can be found in the reeds by the Severn's side "with a piece of paper in my hand "trying to fix the sounds, longing for something very great."
That dreamy child's appreciation of nature would later be reflected in his music.
One of his favourite compositions was the Woodland Interlude from Caractacus.
This music really evokes woodland, doesn't it?
Yes, it's this, isn't it?
I mean, one of the things that's really striking about this, apart from the prevalence of green, is there are no colours or lights that stand out.
There's a dappled effect with the light, or everywhere we look.
Elgar's a genius at creating that kind of dappled scoring.

Everything's the strings, which, of course, is the archetypal woody resin-y sound but he mixes in the colours of the woodwinds and, at one point, the horns, so you can just hear them mingling in and out like the light.
Did he listen to nature?
Oh yes, on one occasion he said, "I listen to the sound of the trees, "am I writing their music, am I singing their music, or are they singing mine?"
He felt that kind of whole question of the nature atmosphere was what gave him the sounds he created.
So it's a partnership between Elgar and nature?
He would have seen it that way, definitely.
In 1889, Elgar married and married well, to Alice Roberts, the daughter of a general.
The couple moved to London with hopes that Elgar would succeed as a composer.
Elgar didn't get the recognition he desperately craved and, penniless, they returned to the Malverns.
Such failure could have marked the end of Elgar's career, but moving back to his beloved Malverns, the Malverns of his youth, proved in fact to be a new beginning.
In 1901, Elgar - conducting here - composed a tune which propelled him to the forefront of English music.
His Pomp And Circumstance March, Number One.
At King Edward VII's request, words were added.
The result - Land Of Hope And Glory.
But it became a rallying anthem during the First World War, which disturbed Elgar.
This wasn't what he had in mind when he'd composed it, this wasn't, he felt, in keeping with the huge loss of life.
The war depressed Elgar deeply, and his last major work - the Cello Concerto - reflected the despair that he felt.
He was mourning a vanished era.
Where better to hear this masterpiece than here in the very hills that nurtured him.
To the end, the relationship between Elgar's music and this landscape remained.
On his deathbed, he hummed this haunting tune to a friend and said, "If ever you're walking on the Malvern Hills and hear that, don't be frightened, it's only me."
Gyles Brandreth exploring Edward Elgar's special relationship with the Malvern Hills.
I'm in Great Malvern.
Leaving the trail of Florence Nightingale behind, my journey has now taken me to a different part of the town, in search of the smallest theatre building in the world.
It's called the Theatre Of Small Convenience which is perfect, because this actually used to be an old Victorian lavatory.
The Theatre Of Small Convenience is the brainchild of Dennis Neale, a keen puppeteer and theatre enthusiast.
He runs the theatre as an independent and non-profit-making project, performing here most Saturdays of the year.
This place is incredible.
Welcome to the smallest theatre.
I have to say, it's just not what I expected at all.
Now, I understand, it used to be an old gentlemen's lavatory in Victorian times.
When did you procure it and how did you get the inspiration to make it into this wonderful theatre?
I had the idea in '97, and, er... it was the silly season, I suppose.
I just liked the building.
I thought it would make a wonderful miniature theatre.
You've got to talk me through the incredible decor and the amount of props everywhere.
All the woodwork and construction work...
I was helped at the beginning by a committee.
We had people helping us but it's all recycled furniture from table legs, to the sides of old harmoniums.
..Bits of piano, bits of old basket chairs, old school chairs, insides of pianos...
What made you build this theatre?
I've no background in theatre but I did have a little interest in puppetry.
I thought it was something different and from then it took off.
I've been doing it for over 10 years now.
If people said to me, "It's rubbish, Dennis, finish", I would.
It's just taken me.
It's the short shows, the puppet shows I do, and occasionally we have other performances on of other things by other people.
Do you have to book a ticket in advance?
No booking, just turn up between certain hours.
It's £2.50 for adults, £1.50 for children.
It's cheap and accessible, that's the idea.
I like small.
It can be interesting.
It's accessible.
It's sometimes the only theatrical experience that some people will get.
I don't mean that condescendingly, but they can't afford to go to the big theatre or they don't want to or whatever.
It's a different experience.
If you've no background in puppetry or theatre, how do you come up with your particular shows?
I just had ideas, that's what it is, basically.
Not all of them work.
I think that's what all people do really, is be persuaded they can do things, but you need to experiment and try.
And be prepared to fail, at times.
And what's the capacity in here then?
And 16 open-plan, we can have if we have the chairs out, but we rarely do that.
But I'll do a show for one, or three or six or eight.
So whoever comes gets a show.
Now, it's just little old me but are you OK to perform for me?
Do take a seat.
The tide comes in...
The tide goes out.
FLUSHING In Cloud Cuckoo Land up in the sky, the Queen, she wants a filling for her pie.
Salt, pepper and add some spice Ah!
Instead of having meat aplenty, the pie, you see, was totally empty!
As for the pie, the King, he couldn't fill it.
His new friend, the turtle, he couldn't kill it.
Great Malvern's enchanting Theatre Of Small Convenience.
The hills which rise up behind the town are an awe-inspiring sight, a fantastic place for a winter walk.
Extraordinary view.
Richard, although it's a magnificent view, it's a fairly bleak one at this time of year, isn't it?
What does draw your eye, of course, beyond the rather vague, fuzzy browns and greys are those... blocked-out bits of dark green, the evergreens.
They are really the focal points of the landscape in winter.

And you can imagine that at a time when people were beginning to understand the seasonal cycles of plants, what they must have made of these trees and other plants that broke the rules, that didn't shed their leaves in autumn, that stayed mysteriously, and therefore probably magically, green throughout the winter.
Now, what's the significance of bringing ivy into the house?
Have people always been happy with bringing this potentially malignant, insinuating, dark plant into the house as part of celebrations?
Does it change its character as it crosses the threshold?
I think that one of the points about winter greenery was bringing the vitality of the wild world, the evergreen-ness, literally, into the house.
And by doing that, in some way you partook of its continuing vitality in the winter.
The flowers are a source of winter nectar, aren't they?
They are, yes.
The flowers are virtually the last bit of nectar for late bees.
The berries themselves are terrific food for birds - mistle thrushes, pigeons, whatever.
So it's not just a question of ivy not being a villain, but it is actually a great boon in the winter.
Now you'd be pushed to see more mistletoe than that on one tree, wouldn't you?

So what is it that people feel about holly that stops them cutting it down?
This superstition about things that can befall you if you cut down a holly tree is huge and ancient.
My own theory is that holly is seen as a kind of protective tree.

That as well as having that vitality that we've seen in all the evergreen winter plants, the prickliness of it, I think, suggests a kind of protectiveness and if we look after it, it will look after us.

That benevolence and protection as well as vitality.

I've now left Great Malvern and have travelled to Worcester to unearth an intriguing secret defence plan from WWII.

Worcester is your typical rural city, complete with its own medieval cathedral, so it's not exactly the kind of place you might pick for a battlefield, but when secret plans were discovered to place Worcester on the frontlines during WWII, and to sacrifice it in the event of a German invasion, this caused quite a commotion.
I'm meeting historian Paul Harding, a man who can tell me more about Worcester's secret wartime role.
So this is it - the very top of the cathedral.
And the views are spectacular, Paul!
It really is, you can see all away across the entire county, from the Malvern Hills all the way across into the distance, towards Birmingham in fact.
Absolutely stunning.
And looking at it, you'd never know that humungous plans were in place to possibly level this during WWII.
Yeah, Worcestershire itself was going to be an anti-tank island.
Worcester itself was going to be an anti-tank island, the whole county was to be also.
The River Severn there, we've got the Avon and the Teme as well.
The idea was if you can knock out the bridges, defend the banks of the rivers as well, then you could start any attack towards Birmingham.
And Birmingham being the great industrial area since Victorian times with the Black Country, you've got all the factories making munitions, aircraft.
So it's very, very important - the very industrial heartland to the north of here.
So the idea is you knock out everything, defend the riverbank, and there will be no attack on Birmingham.
We have a selection of maps here, this is a very good one because this shows you the Midlands defences, 1940, 1941.
The big key to the whole operation, really.
You have the rivers, Worcester's just on the River Severn that runs here.
These are marked on, a lot of them come through Worcester.
Yeah, looks like it.
And as we've got the River Severn and the Teme both coming in here, this is a very strategic point.
Add those together, that makes Worcester an important place to take.
It makes sense when you see it like this, it's strategically placed.
Worcester was to be on the frontline, defending any German attack from the west.
This included plans for British forces to sabotage some of the town's infrastructure.
In a major emergency, the bridge would have been blown.
But in the distance, you can actually see the avenue of trees next to the county cricket ground.
The last few, closest to the bridge there, the idea was they would have explosives set on them.
You've also got the trees here marked in dark text, purely because these would be blown to form an anti-tank...
Trees to be felled to form a block?
And you'll see the machine gun posts, MG, marked on there.
Part of the defence plan for Worcester was a central role for the Home Guard.
The Home Guard had a very important job to play.
In May 1940, they were formed.
They were meant to be local people that knew the area, knew where all the alleyways were, and they were to put up as much resistance against the Germans as they actually could.
They were meant to be too old or too young to join the army, but to go with that, you also had people in reserved occupation.
People working in munitions factories, people working on the railways, all those key roles.
They weren't stood down till 1944, but they did an enormously important job.
People watch Dad's Army and see Captain Mainwaring bumbling around with his platoon.
Generally speaking, they were a little more professional than that.
There wasn't the pitchfork army that everyone thinks they were.
Because of the top secret nature of all this information, we weren't allowed to know.

So in the future, we'll know even more than we actually know today.
As an historian, this is like the Holy Grail for you!
It really is.
All this along with document evidence and speaking to members of the Home Guard, it all comes together to build a picture of how Worcestershire was to be defended.

And how close Worcester came!

Fascinating stuff.
Worcester's well-laid WWII plans, and thankfully, they were never put to use.
