One positive result of foot-and-mouth was that tourism and farming realised just how much they needed each other.
Well, there's no doubt that foot-and-mouth was an economic and an emotional disaster for this place.
This landscape was closed, to all intents and purposes.
And the tourist industry lost a huge amount of money.
That's right.
It was a vast amount of money compared to that lost by agriculture.
Yet the tourist operators, understandably at the time, were saying, "Well, the farmers are getting payments, "there's a scheme to compensate them, nothing to compensate us."
But we began to build bridges from that moment on, and it's really worked in Cumbria.
Tourism and agriculture realises how interdependent the two industries are.
Because a lot of farmers have diversified, into becoming tourist businesses, haven't they?

What the foot-and-mouth outbreak did was to encourage central Government and the general population as to how important these landscapes are, how important the role of the agricultural community in maintaining these landscapes will be, and also the importance of things like local food and produce, local events... and that's all helped to create a buoyant diversity of agriculture here.

And this year, thanks to a totally different crisis - the worldwide recession - rural areas like Cumbria might boom if the weak pound attracts more foreign visitors and British holidaymakers decide not to travel abroad.
When I was asked to help mark 1,000 episodes of Countryfile by choosing my favourite spot in the UK, I thought to myself, "There's no place like home."
The Cotswolds is where I grew up and still live today, and it's an area defined by two things - sheep...and stones.
The Cotswolds were formed around 170 million years ago, when a seam of Jurassic limestone surged out of the earth.
This is Cleeve Hill, the highest spot in the Cotswolds, and on a beautiful day like today, you can see the Malverns.

Where I'm stood now is known as the Cotswolds' Edge, where the limestone has risen up to the surface, and then it falls away gently eastwards for about 50 miles into the Cotswolds, and it's this limestone that's formed the platform for all that has been built and farmed above it.
You'll find limestone quarries all over the Cotswolds.
People have been taking stone out of the earth since Roman times to build the churches, houses, and walls that make the Cotswolds so distinct.
I've got walls and buildings on my farm made out of this stone, and it's this lovely colour, that even on a dull, wet day it is warm and welcoming.
Big machines are used, but for quality walling stone and roofing slate, it has to be picked out by hand.
David, we're in an Area Of Outstanding Natural Beauty, but there's this big hole in the ground - how does that match up?
Stone is a generally low-cost, high-bulk commodity, which is expensive to haul.
Um...and...therefore it's best consumed locally.
Cotswold limestone isn't all one colour, is it?
No, it's not, it varies tremendously.
It can go from a pale yellow through to a bright orange, even down to dark greys, which we've actually got here.
Once the stone has been selected from the quarry face, quarrymen like Jockey Taylor will carefully shape it using traditional techniques.
Start off there in the centre of the stone...
How hard do you need to hit it?
You might see it start opening up.
He's a master!
It's easy to find fantastic examples of how Cotswold stone has formed the landscape I grew up in.
This is my old school, where my kids go now.
This is St Mary's Church, in Temple Guiting.
Two of my sisters got married here, and lots of local characters are buried here, so it's full of memories for me.
It's a prime example of medieval Cotswold stonemasonry, and there's lots of churches like this round the Cotswolds.
Unique and very beautiful.
So where did the money come from, to build churches like this?
The answer lies in an animal very close to my heart.
This breed of sheep is a Cotswold.
The Romans brought them over to Britain because all this meat and wool kept the Roman legions well-fed and lovely and warm.
And on a day like today, you can understand why they needed good wool like this.
In the middle ages there was a wool boom, in fact it made up 50% of the national economy, and this area was covered in thousands of these sheep.
In fact, it was named after them - a sheep cot is an enclosure, and a wold is a rolling hill - the Cotswolds, named after this magnificent animal.
And when you've got a lot of sheep, you need a lot of walls, and that means even more Cotswold stone.
There's a staggering amount of dry stone walls in the Cotswolds, equivalent in length to the Great Wall of China, and the art of building them is a thriving rural skill.
John Nicholson is an old school-friend of mine, and he makes a living as a dry-stone-waller.
He can be found out walling, whatever the weather.
I've worked on farms all my life, and I've done a bit of gapping up, but never a full wall.
It is quite a skill, it takes a bit of time to learn.

The art behind a dry stone wall is to make sure it's wider at the bottom than the top, and the outside stones are sloped slightly away from the middle so the water drains out, and the middle's well-filled.

There's no cement in them because the idea of a dry stone wall is that it does move with the ground, it will settle over a few years, if it's a brand new wall it'll settle maybe three inches, and that wall has to move with the ground, if there's cement in the middle, that doesn't move, creating weakness.
As a waller, can you tell good and bad stone, then?
You can, really, with the ring of it and the shape of it.
Some stone had a real "ping" to it when you hit it, and others a bit of a dull sound.
The dull sound means that it's more porous, it will attract more water, and therefore in weathers like this it'll freeze, and then it'll crack.
And it'll stay here for how long, John?
I hope so, I would imagine it should be here for maybe 100 years, if I'm still here, there's something wrong, isn't there?
For me, the story of the Cotswolds is all about the limestone beneath us, the bedrock on which the villages and monuments have been built.
I've had the privilege of growing up here, amongst the amazing scenery and history.
Still to come on Countryfile - Juliet's in a retro mood for her scenic drive along the Cornish coast... ..and, it's a record-breaker - a Countryfile calendar for 2009, and it's all thanks to you.
Ask most people where they'd like to spend their honeymoon, and they'll talk about sunshine and beaches.
The Seychelles, maybe, or Italy.
We spent our honeymoon here, in North Yorkshire.
Now, today, up on the moor, it is mind-numbingly cold.
But it's also bleak, and beautiful, and grand, and I can't think of anywhere better to celebrate 1,000 editions of Countryfile... but I do wish it was a bit warmer.
Well, you don't come to Yorkshire for the weather!
At more than 500 square miles, the North York Moors is the biggest expanse of heather moorland anywhere in England.
It stretches from Saltburn in the north to Pickering in the south, from the Cleveland Hills in the west to the Yorkshire coast in the east.
The great thing about this place is that it's very easy to be alone - you can spend a whole day up here and not see a soul.
Now, it sounds very antisocial, but that's fantastic.
I blame my parents, who dragged me and my brother here when we were kids.
Now I drag my own family as often as I can.
This is a wonderful place to roam, with villages nestling in a seemingly wild landscape, which in fact owes much of its appearance to farmers.

A lot of people, I think, don't realise that it's a very managed landscape, they see the wilderness aspect of it... and I guess in lots of ways it is quite a wild landscape, but it's very much a managed one, because if the sheep weren't there, it would turn back into woodland.
It's not the greatest time to be a sheep farmer, so have you got a problem actually keeping sheep on the moor?

The economic situation is pretty dire if you're a hill sheep farmer, particularly moorland sheep, because they require quite a lot of labour, and labour, as you know, is the expensive part of a business.
So what can you do?

Fortunately Natural England and the North York Moors National Park are working very closely with farmers and land-owners and the shooting tenants on the moorlands, to try and get the sheep farmers into agreements - basically, pay them to keep the sheep on the moor.
Well, nature, with a little bit of help from sheep, is responsible for a lot of the beauty here.
Look at that.
Rievaulx Abbey was founded in the 12th century by Cistercian monks.
They were on a mission to conquer England and so started in Yorkshire.
Maybe they got held up by the good food on offer, but they stayed and grew rich on the proceeds of sheep farming.
This abbey flourished for 400 years, until Henry VIII dissolved the monasteries.
John, I've been here at all times of year and in all weathers, and I've never seen it look quite so stunning as it does in winter light.
Yes, it looks fantastic, and at the end of the day you get the sun picking out this part of the church, So why did they build it here?
Cos there are lots of abbeys in the area, aren't there?

They wanted, really, complete solitude, they wanted to be away from the nearest civilisation, they wanted somewhere that was specifically remote, and Rievaulx, in terms of this landscape, was pretty remote, heavily forested, and they could then turn that into productive land, Cistercians were great agriculturalists and great civil engineers.
Well, I've been here occasionally, and to me it is a magical place, I do get a sense of peace and calm when I come here.
In a sense it's easy to get blase when you've worked somewhere for a long time, but I think the difference with Rievaulx particularly is this monumental scale, even as a ruin today.
Obviously the natural setting is so dramatic, so, no, I don't think I do, and also because it changes, on any given time of the year.
It's a beautiful ruin, and the monks who settled here chose their location well.
It is the perfect place for spiritual nourishment.
But as the Yorkshire weather sets in, I'm in search of more Earthly pleasures - warmth, and food.
'Here at the Appletree Inn, TJ and Melanie Drew have been bringing cheer to the hungry for eight years.'
You're very lucky to be in North Yorkshire, aren't you, cos you can get so much good food locally.
We're rather spoilt, I would say, up here - definitely!
Why do you think there is that foodie culture up here?
I think Yorkshiremen like to eat!
There's the classic saying, "Yorkshire portions", you know, plates piled high.
It's probably a little bit pink for you, but it's perfect for me.
'I wouldn't've chosen goose liver, to be honest, but it looks good...'
Oh, that's lovely...
What's next?
This place is unusual in that TJ is the entire kitchen staff.
'He even butchers his own locally-sourced meat.'
Why do it like this?
Aren't you just making a hard job even harder?
For starters, we source it from a lovely guy, Tubby Turnbull, who breeds fantastic animals.
We then hang it for a good three weeks, so you've got real good, intense flavours, and then I spend a couple of days sorting it out.
I find...chefs are losing the basic skills these days.
It's not difficult to do.
'And for a really simple dish, allTJ is doing here is braising the beef with some local beer.
'It takes five hours, and I'm not that patient, so here's some he prepared earlier.
It's topped with home-made red onion marmalade, and horseradish cream sauce.'
That is lovely.
Now, the scenery in Yorkshire is fantastic, the people are wonderful.
But for me, if I'm really honest, one of the main reasons for coming here - a lot - is the food.
And it's guilt-free - there is plenty of room to walk it all off.
As far as Ben's concerned, it's islands that hold a special place in his heart.
It was as a castaway on Taransay that he first made his name, and, for Countryfile a while ago, he was on the Channel Island of Alderney.
I'm going to the largest island after Guernsey and Jersey with a population of 2,000.
Technically, it's the only Channel Island actually in the English Channel, as all the others are in the bay of St Malo.
It's closer to France than mainland Britain, although it's determinedly British, and its position is also why it's been heavily fortified ever since Napoleonic times.
'I've got a short walk into the harbour to catch a ride on the Channel Islands' only railway.'
Somewhere along the way, it picked up two London Underground carriages.
It's run by volunteers, and only takes ten minutes to travel the length of the island.
'It's certainly a surreal experience, watching the sea go by while riding on the Northern Line, 'and you'll never guess who I'm expecting to meet - someone who swapped South London for Alderney.'
Hello, Eliza!
What are you doing on here?
Well, I thought Alderney ought to come for a ride.
Actually, I used to be a guard on the train, at weekends.
And I thought I ought to take a refresher course.
You are the writer and the inspiration and everything behind the Wombles.
They are all members of my family.
The one that people always laugh at, actually, is Orinoco - is my son, who used to be - I have to say this - used to be very lazy and very...greedy, and is now very successful...
And Great Uncle Bulgaria was the old one with the spectacles...
I remember him.
..He was my father-in-law, who I simply adored.
Next, I'm off looking for puffins.
I've hitched a ride with a man better known as the Puffin King, and he's taking me to Burhou Island, a rocky, uninhabited bird sanctuary, that you can visit between the end of July and March.
All you need is a boat to get you there.
50 years ago, this island was a teeming puffin colony.
In 1950, there was 50,000 pairs of puffins recorded here.
As you come with the boat they just seem to open up, and let you go in, and close back in with the tides.
And then gradually, '68, it went down to, er...about 20,000 pairs.
In '75 it went down to 1,000 pairs, and at the moment, we're scratching, there are about 200.
No-one really knows why the puffins have declined.
The reasons are likely to be very complicated.
Although Midget is convinced that since egg-collecting was banned, it's these large black-backed gulls that are pushing out the smaller puffins.
Midget has been so passionate about the puffins for so very long, that he was actually made warden of the island.
I just love it, you know.
You know, and the lads that've been with me, the three of us have built this place and two of 'em are gone now, like I said, but they really enjoyed it.
They used to come, and lovely evenings we've had in here, good laughs, you know.
Now, outside of breeding season, you can come and stay on Burhou Island, in this very cottage, for just £10 a night.
Sadly, it's time for me to leave, but not before I leave one little reminder of my visit here.
Well, this is the 1,000th edition of Countryfile, a big milestone for us - and so is this.
A big cheque, in fact a record-breaking cheque, which we're handing to Children In Need - the proceeds of the Countryfile calendar.

That's a whopping £1,000 more than last year.

But now here's Juliet, in a really wild and wonderful place - the coastline of Cornwall.
Cornwall is England's most coastal county.
It's got over 400 miles of spectacular shoreline.
But it's the north coast that's particularly close to my heart.
Now, granted, I probably couldn't've picked a worse day, weather-wise, to come up here.
But believe me, this landscape is wild, rugged and stunningly beautiful.
The sea, on a clear day, is just over there.
Currently, it's in the mist.
Now, the north coast is famous for its surf - it's got a great swell.
So what better way to get around this area than in a trusty...campervan.
It's a journey I find particularly beautiful.
The scenery's dramatic, with the ocean on one side, and moorland on the other.
I'm travelling 17 miles from St Ives, through Zennor, and ending my road trip in St Just.
This is St Ives.
It's always been a Mecca for artists, and it's not difficult to see why this place has inspired people for generations.
Even on a day like today, there's something very special about the light here.
The small town has exploited its large artistic heritage.
There are now 25 galleries in St Ives, and it's said you can't swing a cat here without hitting an artist...or five.
The Atlantic waves along the north coast can be great fun, particularly for surfers, but they can also be incredibly dangerous.
Much has happened along this coastline, including a lifeboat tragedy which occurred 70 years ago.
It left William Barber without a father at the age of five.
What do you remember about that night, William?
Well, on January 23rd 1939, the rockets went off.
When one rocket goes off, that's to stand by.
When two rockets go off, you know the boat is going out.
When the rocket went off, I said to my sister, "I hope Daddy isn't out tonight."
My mum said to my dad, "You're not going out tonight, are you?"
"Yes, Grace, I'm going out to do my duty."
Why was the lifeboat called out?
There was a ship called The Wilson off Zennor and the Zennor lifeboat couldn't go out, and their lifeboat went out, but just as it went around the island so it hit this gale, which was over 100mph.
Next morning we were waiting anxiously for news and yet we knew in our hearts, or I did, that Dad wasn't coming back.
So you lost your dad that night, didn't you?
The lifeboat here is the centre of St Ives.
Always has been and always will be.
It's the heart of the town.
They don't get paid a penny, yet they regularly risk thier lives for us.
The next leg of my journey takes me to Zennor where, famously, DH Lawrence once lived.
Lawrence raved about Zennor, calling it, "A most beautiful place.
"A tiny village nestling under high, shaggy moorhills, "a big sweep of lovely sea beyond.
Lovelier than the Mediterranean.
It's the best place I've ever been in."
I've got to agree with him - there is a lot of loveliness about this place, although it doesn't really feel like the Meditteranean today.
So I'm taking refuge in a pub where the author once stayed.
Tell me about DH Lawrence's stay here.
He came here with his German wife, Frieda, in about 1915.
When he first stayed in this pub, he was looking for somewhere quiet to create an artistic community.
He was here until the end of 1917, by which time local suspicions had worked against him.
Being married to a German, people said his cottage was used for spying, cos his curtains were open and there were lights.
He was finally ordered to move away from Cornwall and not to live anywhere near the coast in England.
Yes, I think the whole country was anti-German, not necessarily people in Zennor, but he was viewed with a little suspicion being an artist, rather than an ordinary working person.
Back on the road, I'm heading to Cape Cornwall, across Penwith Moors, one of the oldest continually farmed landscapes in the world.
We've reached the end of the line.
This is the most Westerly tip of Cornwall.
It'll be nightfall soon.
Not the sort of sunset I'd anticipated or hoped for, but you can't win them all.
Just look at the majesty and power of nature.
I'm not the first to fall in love with this coastline, and I know it won't be last.
'It's been a wonderful journey.
What better way to end it than in a pub with the Cape Cornwall singers?'
On this, the 1,000th edition of Countryfile, I've been updating what is perhaps the biggest story that will be covered in that time, that was the foot-and-mouth epidemic of 2001.
One of the lessons learned from that was the crucial importance of tourism to the rural economy.
It's worth far more than farming.
And looking down here onto Derwent Water in the Lake District, it's easy to see why so many people flock to the British countryside.
Few people come to Keswick without taking the short walk down to the shore and the boat landings, and these traditional wooden motor launches kept running throughout the crisis.
But, because people stayed away from the Lake District, ticket sales dropped sharply until the outbreak was over.
I'm very well, thanks.
'This is what they missed - the best possible way of seeing the magnificence 'of one of England's most beautiful lakes.'
This is fantastic - my own private boat ride down Derwent Water.
Only at the weekends in winter.
During the week, we're doing maintenance on the boats.
Tell me about this boat.
This one is called the Annie Mellor.
It was built back in 1935, for a Lord Mellor.
And it was like a houseboat.
And then the company purchased it round about 1948-1949.
And it's been on here with passengers ever since.
And what's your favourite place along this route for your passengers?
The main place is Hawes End on the western shoreline.
It's a stopping-off point for people going up Catbells, one of the most-walked fells in the Lake District.
That's a fine looking house over there.
It's Fawe Park, where Beatrix Potter stayed when she was a young girl, and it's where they made the film Potter.
You can only actually see the house from the lake.
You can understand why this area attracts so many writers, and it was here that Beatrix Potter created many of her much-loved characters.
I'm going to pop ashore in a moment because the land over there played a pioneering role in preserving and protecting the natural beauty of the Lake District.
The 46 hectares of Brandelhow Park was bough in 1902 by the recently formed National Trust to stop housing development.
It was its first big public appeal, 'and its success led to the way the trust raises money 'to protect our heritage to this day.'
It needed to raise £6,500, which today doesn't seem very much, but in those days was a lot ofmoney What kind of people contributed to it?
At that time we had a contribution from Rudyard Kipling, who was perhaps the most famous of the contributors.
But we also had contributions from factory workers and from mill workers.

We had a family of mill workers who contributed three shillings, and a factory worker from Sheffield who, although he'd never seen the lakes, and never would see them, he contributed two and sixpence.
And that's it from the 1,000th edition of Countryfile.
And on behalf of our whole team, I'd like to say a big thank-you to everybody who's supported us from programme one, onwards.
Next week we'll be in Kew Gardens, which has a celebration of it own - its 250th birthday.
For now, for the Lake District, goodbye.
'He is a leaf on the stream, free at last from his petty little purposes in life.'
For some people this would be the ideal swimming location - clean and modern, with convenient changing rooms, big fluffy robes and, best of all, hot water.
But a growing number of people across Britain are looking for a completely different kind of experience.
To a 'wild swimmer' secluded rivers, lakes and rock pools are where it's at.
And over the last few years there's been a steady flow of books, magazine articles and TV features feeding a growing obsession with swimming in the great outdoors.
And if one book can claim to have rekindled our passion in wild swimming, then surely this must be it.
Roger Deakin's Waterlog.
Roger Deakin was an environmentalist, broadcaster and writer and worked for a variety of papers and wildlife magazines.
In Waterlog, his first book, he recorded a series of journeys that he made in an attempt to swim in as many British rivers, lakes and pools as he could.
The result was an extraordinary, poetic discourse on the joys of nature and the delights of swimming in the wild.

'I wanted to follow the rain on it's meanderings about our land 'to rejoin the sea, to break out of the frustration of a lifetime of doing lengths, 'of endlessly turning back on myself like a tiger pacing its cage...
'I grew convinced that following water, flowing with it, would be 'a way of getting under the skin of things, of learning something new.
'I might even learn about myself, too.'
Waterlog is one of my favourite books.
It's this beautiful, lyrical evocation of the importance of water to an island nation.
And it's also a bit of an inspiration and a challenge to me.
An inspiration because it makes me want to swim in wild places, and a challenge because I want to understand that desire and to find out more about the relationship between humans and water.
To do that, I'm going to swim in some of the wildest locations the country has to offer.
I'm going to examine the enduring fascination water has held for artists and writers.
And I'm going to look at how water has made its mark on myth and legend.
But, before I do all that, I'm going to have a cup of tea.
I don't actually remember learning to swim, which presumably meant I was very young when it happened.
But I do have some lovely memories of swimming from my childhood and, in particular, this pool that we used to go to.
It was a friend of the family and we used to go down the garden into this dip.
And hidden away in the dip was this swimming pool with little huts to get changed in.
And it was like going back into the '30s, I think.
I remember really vividly that fantastic feeling of swimming outdoors.
The days of just turning up at the neighbour's with a costume and a towel are long gone.
For this trip, I'm packing all manner of wetsuits, costumes and spare changes of clothes.
And I'm also bringing some copies of radio recordings that Roger Deakin made for the BBC after Waterlog was published.
Sadly, Roger died in 2006.
But, through his writings and recordings, I hope to get a clearer insight into the man who's inspired me.
'The warm rain tumbled from the gutter in one of those midsummer 'downpours as I hastened across the lawn behind my house in Suffolk and took shelter in the moat.
'Breast-stroking up and down the 30 yards of clear, green water, 'I nosed along, eyes just at water level.
'It was at the height of this drenching in the summer of 1996 that 'the notion of a long swim through Britain began to form itself.'
There are more than 1,000 lakes and 8,000 rivers in the UK.
So, in terms of potential swimming locations, I'm more than spoilt for choice.
So, I've decided to start at one of the oldest river swimming clubs in the country, the Farleigh and District Club on the River Frome in Wiltshire.
He's got his towel with him.
'Giving me a guided tour will be Rob Fryer, club chairman and a vocal champion of river swimming.'
Good to see you.
Hello.
Yes, this is the Farleigh and District Swimming Club.
Well, yes.
But that's the charm of it.
You've got to... appreciate the simplicity of the pleasures of swimming in rivers.
Those simple pleasures are down to a pool, created by this weir, which has given club members and visitors nearly a century's worth of enjoyment.
I don't know what I was expecting, Rob.
But perhaps...some kind of pavilion?
Well, the swimming club pavilion, we call that the pavilion.
That corrugated iron shed?
That's a swimming club pavilion.
I would correct you on that.
The club was started in the early '30s when a local landowner invited a group of swimmers to formalise their activities.
What was this place like in the 1930s?
It was very much an important social hub of the whole community.
And everybody knew each other.
There were all these events, like diving competitions for silver tea-spoons.
And then there'd be water polo.
The '30s were the heyday of river swimming.
But after the war these clubs went into decline, as new municipal swimming pools sprang up across the country.
By the early 1990s, Farleigh was one of the few river swimming clubs remaining - and even they were under threat.
I know that Roger came here, because he writes about it in Waterlog.
And he met you as well.
Well, he came...
Quite honestly we were at a low point.
We felt embattled by public opinion and authorities.
And he was like a fairy godmother, giving us a standard to raise.
So he galvanised you to fight for the future of the club?
It's just simply the publication of his book.
When he came we just felt inspired and we just changed overnight.
Since the publication of Waterlog, membership of the Farleigh club has steadily increased and people come from far and wide to enjoy these beautiful surroundings.
It's not contrived.
It's not a part of the materialistic world.
If you can appreciate things that are non-materialistic, you are then able to live a truer life and get true enjoyment.
To embrace Rob's enthusiasm and to begin to understand more of Roger Deakin's passion for wild swimming, I need to plunge in for my first ever river swim.
It gets deep quickly.
S Oh, no.

Around the end of the 19th century, paintings like Ruby, Gold and Malachite by Henry Scott Tuke, which featured young men bathing, became very popular.
They were thought to celebrate the great outdoors and encourage the taking of physical exercise in a time when industrialisation was moving people from the land to the cities.
These images also provided an excuse to celebrate the sensuality of the human body.
Paintings like Thomas Eakins' Swimming celebrate leisure, life, and sex.
But artists are also drawn to water's more sinister aspects.
John Millais' Ophelia, one of the most famous pre-Raphaelite paintings, records the drowning of its subject in uncannily accurate detail.
John Waterhouse's Hylas And The Nymphs has a naive but handsome Hylas being seduced to an early grave by a group of water nymphs - a scene that captures both the attraction and the danger of water.

This contrast, this duality that water has, on the one hand we need it to sustain life, and on the other it can kill us, has driven successive cultures to worship water deities since the dawn of time.
The Greeks worshipped Poseidon and Triton, the Celts had individual river deities, and even today Hindus hold rivers sacred, none more so than the Ganges.
But no civilization better encapsulates the veneration of water than the Romans.

Right along Hadrian's Wall, the largest example of Roman remains in the country, one can find buildings, statues and carvings that attest to the spiritual importance water has had throughout human history.
